PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Minister:
Discrimination against Women

To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State' and whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)-
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the work force, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Cadman,Mr Cowan,Mr Drummond,Mr Lusher,Mr Millar and Mr Newman.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that United States, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as agents orange, blue and white, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Leo McLeay and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region, commonly called Scheyville, imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to RAAF Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Exploitation of Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the nation showeth that we protest strongly against the destruction of kangaroos and the commercial use of their remains. The practices associated with keeping wounded animals alive for days in order to keep their flesh fresh and the inhumane way in which they are killed to keep their skins unmarked have encouraged unspeakably cruel actions. This throws the shadows of shame over the whole nation and gives Australia a poor reputation in the eyes of the world. Your petitioners therefore pray that the commercial exploitation of kangaroo by-products be banned.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That the recent reduction in Federal Government funding to the States for the provision of public health care have caused, and will increasingly continue to cause, severe hardships to medical staff, nurses and other health workers of the Public Health System in New South Wales.
That the aforementioned reductions in fundings are severely jeopardizing the safety of patients through reductions in medical, nursing and general hospital staff.
That the resulting staff reductions and increased workloads thereby imposed on remaining staff are producing severe stress and deteriorating morale among staff at all levels.
That the concept of the user pays and the phasing out of the universal health scheme are a grave injustice to low and middle income earners.
and respectively calls for:

Reintroduction of the universal health scheme, and urgent review and reassessment of funding to the states for health care with a view to relieving the deficiencies in the provision of health care services currently existing.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Alcoholic Beverages
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. Noting that the 1982 national Budget includes increased taxes on beer and spirits, we draw attention to the fact that wines have a higher alcoholic content than beer and that wine consumption must be a significant factor in the mounting problems arising from the use of alcoholic beverages; we request that all alcoholic wines be taxed to a degree comparable to the taxes on other alcoholic beverages.
2. Whereas non-alcoholic wines do not cause social problems we request that no tax on these drinks be imposed.
3. That government imposts on all alcoholic beverages be adjusted annually so that the real price of the beverages remain constant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the citizens of New South Wales repectfully showeth:
Last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
alcohol is a factor in 50 per cent of road deaths;
alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
alcohol advertisements are glamourous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton and Mr Gorman.

PETITION.TITLE: Mackay Directory Assistance Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Mackay respectfully showeth:
that the intention of Telecom Australia to close the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre will:
downgrade telephone services to Mackay and district;
deprive customers of a personalized reliable telephone service;
reduce job opportunities in the area;
increase the likelihood of the eventual closure of the exchange.
We the undersigned believe that Telecom Australia has a social responsiblity to provide a sound, reliable, personalized telephone system.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will call on the Government to intervene to stop Telecom's proposed closure of the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: We the citizens of the City of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holdens, respectfully show-
That the management of General Motors-Holdens has failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.
That a recent statement attributed to the GMH Managing Director, quote:
'The overall objective of our South Australian rationalisation plan has been to eliminate all productive activities on the Woodville site' end quote.
This statement has not been refuted.
That the elimination of the Woodville Plant will cause enormous social dislocation, hardship and misery to the citizens of Woodville and South Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament of Australia will condemn this callous disregard for the citizens of Woodville and South Australia, and do all in its power to force General Motors-Holdens to retain its operations at the Woodville Plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House reprimands the Minister for Defence for his failure to-
(1) publicly reveal under what section of Commonwealth law the Royal Australian Air Force spy flights over Tasmania on 7 and 8 April 1983 were authorised;
(2) reveal whether the cost of the said flights would be met by the Department of Defence or the Attorney-General's Department; and
(3) indicate whether a full public apology, by the Hawke Government to the State of Tasmania, would be forthcoming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move :

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) is of the opinion that, in a free society, there are grave dangers in accepting the notion that a person is guilty merely because of an association;
(2) notes that there are many provisions of the Crimes Act which apply to espionage, associated with known spies and similar conduct, and
(3) calls on the Government, if there is evidence of criminal activity, to prosecute the person in a court of law rather than encourage rumour-mongering by Government Ministers and officials.
AUSTRALIA'S DEFENCE CAPABILITY
Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat to Australia's defence capability through the actions of the Labor Government.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no more fundamental area of concern I would hope for all members of this place than concern for the nation's defence. Yet it is in this area, perhaps more than any other, that already there are signs of the Government's withdrawing from undertakings given during the election. There are certain indications that there are problems in the system and that the rapport that supposedly came out of the National Economic Summit that has been categorised as a consensus within the nation does not exist within the Australian Labor Party itself.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three particular areas that I want to address. The first is the not unnatural concern that I think we all have about national security. This emanated from an article that was released in the National Times of 6 to 12 May which is presently the subject of litigation. However, the fact that there was reference in the article to a possible agent or mole in Australia's intelligence services cannot be taken lightly by any Australian. We then, of course, have had a series of revelations from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which equally concern us about the nation's security. It is amazing that one of the front benchers of the Labor Party found it necessary to rise in Labor Caucus apparently and, if I may quote from this morning's Australian, 'told fellow MP's he had been approached following a Press report which claimed ASIO had kept a close watch on ''one of the most important and influential figures in the party over the past two decades'' .' The article stated that that gentleman 'asked whether he was the person referred to in the report'. What an indictment of a party, that one of the front bench members of the Government felt that he might well be one of those who might be subject to Australian Security Intelligence Organisation scrutiny.

We then had, of course, the questions in this place yesterday. We had allegations in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald that a senior Labor man was a potential security risk and a friend of the expelled Soviet diplomat, Valeriy Ivanov. We were told this morning that the Federal Government has examined the prospects of charging a senior ALP figure whom ASIO has told the Government is a potential security risk. I do not propose to go down that track further. But I do think it is critical that this Parliament be told who that person is and if somebody is to be charged, with what that person is going to be charged. If there are allegations against any individual, that person ought not be maligned under the cover of parliamentary privilege in this place, as our friend John Reid was once maligned by the former Leader of the Opposition. If individuals are to have allegations made against them, these allegations should not be made in an improper way. If there is a suspicion, an innuendo, about Labor's competence in the field of governing this country it certainly cannot be at the risk of the nation's security.

The second area of concern is in the field of foreign affairs. What an indictment of the party it is that the former Leader of the Opposition and the present Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), at the beginning of his term as Foreign Minister, found it necessary to go to Indonesia and Papua New Guinea not because it was essential that he went there but to explain his party's left wing policy with respect first to the recognition of East Timor and the continuation of defence co-operation aid to Indonesia; and, secondly, on the subject of aid to Vietnam. I find it incredible that even as late as yesterday we had a newspaper report that the left wing of the Labor Party has said that the Australian Government has contravened its foreign policy platform by allowing a Royal Australian Navy attack class patrol boat to be handed over to Indonesia. The report continued:
'Labor's policy platform says there will be no military aid to Indonesia while they continue to occupy East Timor', he said.

It is quite critical that the Labor Party determines whether it is the left wing of the party or whether it is the Government that is going to determine its foreign policy. From this side of the House we have done a great deal to encourage closer relations with Indonesia and with the members of the Association of South East Asian Nations. We find it incredible that the visit of the Foreign Minister should not have been made as a matter of getting to know you but to explain discrepancies in his party's policy, to explain that in the circumstances of the implementation of the policy of his party there would be a very grave disparity between the acceptability of Australia to Indonesia under a Labor government from that which existed under our regime.

The other question, that of aid to Vietnam, is equally important. The fact that one of the leading figures in the anti-Vietnamese coalition of the Government of Kampuchea, Mr Son Sann, is in Australia is not without note. It is important that we keep Australia's position with respect to United Nations resolution 37 of last year certain for this Parliament. We need to make sure that we do not antagonise the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations in the way that seems likely under the Labor Government. Indeed, only this morning a statement that apparently emanated from Thailand would suggest that there are problems in Australia's preparedness to continue aid to Vietnam. These are matters that cannot be ignored.

So in the foreign affairs field we are running into the position where the Labor Government is already embarrassing the countries of our region and antagonising those on whom we must rely in the event of a development to the threat to Australia. It is prejudicing the continuation of defence co-operation aid to countries in the region and is creating a circumstance in which there must be hesitancy amongst those who are our closest geographic neighbours as to our future intentions.

Let us get down now to defence policy itself. There we have an incredible series of difficulties. There are two particular areas on which I want to speak this morning. The first is with respect to the Royal Australian Navy. The second is with respect to the Royal Australian Air Force flights over South West Tasmania. But let no one think that that is where the sad and sorry record ends, for it is an extensive and appalling one for a government so young in office. If we look first at the Navy, we all remember that immediately after the Government 's election the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes), in what I believe was his first news release, made the statement that the Cabinet had decided not to acquire an aircraft carrier to replace HMAS Melbourne. It needs to be recognised that that was apparently a decision taken by the Government without Cabinet submission; it was taken off the top of the Minister's head and without advice from the Department. Even if it was with advice from the Department it certainly was not with advice as to the character of what alternative naval capabilities would be required if a carrier was not purchased for the fleet. It needs to be recognised that there are two particular areas where the requirement for the fleet remains constant. One is to have, in some form, integral air support. The other is the need for an anti-submarine war capability.

Before the former Government went out of office it had sent back to the Navy a request that it advise the Government on an alternative structure of the fleet if a carrier were not to be acquired. It needs to be accepted that the cost of a Navy without a carrier could well be greater than the cost of a Navy with a carrier. We all recall that in the days when a carrier capability was first acquired the decision was taken to set aside the then larger vessels that were part of the fleet. We moved down to frigates and destroyers, ships of a lesser capability, supporting the naval air arm capability. If we examine the statement by the Minister with respect to the aircraft carrier we see that two elements are involved. The first is that the Minister simply does not go into the question of air support at all. It might well be that that can be maintained from forward air bases-if our friends, geographically in our region, will still be talking to us under a Labor regime. Secondly, in an incredibly naive comment, the Minister said:
Australian shipping has not been threatened by submarine attack since World War II and, on present indications this is still most improbable.

So he has gone down the track and said: 'Yes, we are going to acquire helicopter capability'. The former Government had already set that in train, but acquiring the medium helicopter for the fleet does present problems in the immediate short term. It will be two or three years, perhaps four, before that carrier capability can be acquired. There is little doubt that in that period we need to turn to an ASW capability for the fleet, but the Government has done nothing about that.

The second important part of the aircraft carrier decision followed a few weeks later when we were told by the Minister that the Federal Government has scrapped the fixed wing component of the Fleet Air Arm. That decision was described by the Commander-in-Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, Admiral Sylvester Foley, as regrettable. He said:
From the operational viewpoint, your Government's decision is regrettable.
First it was the (decision not to replace the) Melbourne and now it is the air arm.
According to a newspaper report, he believed the overall effect of the change of the defences of this country and of the Indian Ocean and Pacific regions would have to be analysed closely.

The important aspects of that decision are twofold. First, we need to turn to undertakings given by the present Prime Minister in the presentation of the Labor Party's North Queensland policy. Honourable members will recall that on 24 February last, he said:
Again I draw attention to our commitment-
That is, the Labor Party's commitment-

for the establishment of a coastal surveillance force drawn from the place where they should be drawn-the Air Force and the Navy and not from Air Charter companies. We will ask the Royal Australian Navy to retain its fixed-wing capability-
That was said by the Prime Minister on 24 February 1983. He continued:
. . . and to station immediately three Tracker Aircraft at either Townsville or Cairns for coastal patrols, in addition to those aircraft already patrolling on Government contracts.
Yet on 3 May 1983, barely three months later, the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) announced:
Flying by fixed-wing aircraft of the Royal Australian Navy will be phased out-
There is one of the already broken promises of the Labor Government in this very short period of its office. The Minister for Defence also stated:
The 19 S2 Tracker anti-submarine warfare aircraft will be withdrawn by June 30, 1984, subject to Government consideration of their use for civil coastal surveillance tasks.

We then have the problem of the alternatives. Quite obviously, when Mr Hawke made his original statement he made no assessment of the cost of the alternative aircraft. It is quite demonstrable that using the RAN aircraft will be significantly more expensive. They have an operational cost of about $1,850 an hour. Frank Cranston, in an article in the Canberra Times on 8 March, stated:
A Shrike Commander operated by a civilian contractor costs a standing charge of $1,426 a day plus $145 per flying hour, the flying time taking the cost close to $2,000 a day.

That is in contrast to $1,850 an hour to operate the Tracker aircraft. The important part of that switch is not just the cost; it is the fact that we are then told that 349 jobs face the axe at the Nowra naval air base. The problem is that the Minister has not provided for an increase in the number of personnel in the Army and the Air Force. Although, as is proper, he is offering those who are going to be withdrawn from the Fleet Air Arm an opportunity to join the other two Services, as I understand it, at this time there is to be no increase in the complement of personnel in either the Air Force or the Army. Therefore, there will be no possibility for those Services to accommodate those who might wish to transfer.

The next field I will cover is the conflict over the Tasmanian dams issue. The only thing I want to say about that is that it is absolutely imperative that the people of Australia recognise that while the Minister has said he authorised the flights in the ordinary course of co-operation with the civilian elements of the Government, no approval was given by the Tasmanian Government. No effort was made to contact the Tasmanian Government before those flights took place. If we read the record tabled in the Senate by Senator Evans, we will see that the attempt originally was to be without the knowledge of the Tasmanian people. I believe that those flights may well have been against the powers of the Minister . He acknowledges-as indeed does the Chief of Defence Force Staff-that the flights were made without reference to the Chief of Defence Force Staff or to the Chief of the Air Staff. The Minister has acted without reference to his senior advisers in areas of very critical importance to the function of this nation's defence forces. There is no basis upon which the Minister should have acted in that way. There is a series of questions which he has as yet failed to answer. Why was the Tasmanian Government not advised? Why were not either other Government aircraft or civilian aircraft used? No answers have been given to those questions.

Finally, we have the problem of future Budget allocations. The Minister has already indicated that the operational activities of the Australian defence forces will be severely curtailed as a result of very stringent financial constraints about to be imposed by the Government. On each of these counts, the Government has failed to sustain the defence effort of Australia. The Minister, I believe, needs to answer to this country and to the members of the defence forces as to his future intentions. We cannot run into a situation in which the capability of Australia's defence forces are prejudiced because of the ineptitude of the Minister, his failure to consult with his senior defence advisers or by the failure of the Labor Government to allocate sufficient funds to maintain the defence forces in the state in which they should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I read that this matter of public importance was to be brought on I understood that the Opposition was going to bring forward a debate on defence policy and the activities of this Government. I think the last quotation by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) is probably indicative of the level of debate which took place. The quotation to which he referred was in fact from Frank Cranston, not the Minister. It is included in an article in such a way as to appear to come from the Minister but if the shadow Minister and former Minister for Defence, the right honourable member for New England, had read it he would have realised that it is a quotation from the author of the article. The Opposition spokesman started his remarks by making a fairly wide-ranging attack on the Government for a number of national security matters which are under consideration at the moment, including by the High Court.
—And general incompetence.

—I think 'general incompetence' is probably a good remark from the Leader of the National Party because honourable members opposite were in office when this happened. If there is a mole in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation it is related to a report which was made to the former Prime Minister shortly after the defeat of the Whitlam Government. I remind the Leader of the National Party that he was then a Minister of the Government. If there is incompetence it is his incompetence and the incompetence of his Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my province to debate matters relating to more recent ASIO activities but some of the things I have seen have the same substance, I would think, as the Hitler diaries. On the specific matters raised it is my understanding that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has been fully briefed and is fully aware of all the circumstances surrounding them. I think it ill becomes the Opposition to try to suggest otherwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you telling me they are forgeries now, like the Hitler diaries?
—I did not say that at all. I said the Leader of the Opposition was fully briefed on certain matters.
—You said earlier they were akin to the Hitler diaries.
—I said that some of the matters which I have seen have the substance of the Hitler diaries.
—Which ones?
—It is not my intention nor has it been my intention to comment on which. The Leader of the Opposition can make his own decisions. He is to be briefed, as is everyone else.
—Tell me which are the forgeries.

—The Leader of the Opposition seems to want to make all sorts of strange speeches in opposition that he was not prepared to make when he was in government. He does know what the facts are. He is constrained from telling his colleagues. Nevertheless, the Opposition is aware and will be kept fully aware of the situation. The second matter raised concerned foreign policy which does not fall within my area and I do not intend to deal with it. I wish to make one point to the House. It is easy to make a case if one makes it on projections on decisions which are to be made rather than on decisions which are made. That is the basis of most of the foreign policy criticisms which came forward in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The most significant matter raised concerns the Fleet Air Arm and the decision of the Government not to proceed with the acquisition program for a carrier which did not exist anyhow. The facts of this matter are that advice had been prepared by the defence forces relating to the future acquisition of a carrier. The former Minister for Defence is aware that in November last year the Defence Structure Committee provided him with a brief on which he prepared and presented to Cabinet a submission relating to the future of a carrier acquisition. That brief-the Royal Australian Navy dissented as I would expect-recommended that the Goverment not proceed to the procurement of a carrier. The defence advisers to the Government have also indicated that, consequent on that decision, it is proper to proceed to dismantle those sections of our defence forces which are dependent for their operations on the acquisition of a carrier, namely, the fixed wing operations. The former Minister has made great play about those. I quote from the minute:
If practical, the earlier phased out or transfer of assets will be achieved-
That is the transfer of those assets to other sections of the Defence Force. The minute continues:
subject to satisfactory arrangements for transfer and redeployment of personnel involved, the use of tracker aircraft for surveillance tasks-
That is a separate submission-
and proving an alternative towing low level high target for which four Skyhawks are indeed to be retained beyond June 1983.

Each of those qualifications as well as the specific qualifications about coastal surveillance are taken into account in respect of the decision to phase out fixed wing aircraft. I also draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that the Minister assisting the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Aviation, (Mr Beazley) has been asked by myself and the Minister for Transport ( Mr Peter Morris) to carry out a full review of coastal surveillance activities and to bring back a recommendation-this is a matter of some urgency because the previous Government kept deferring decisions on the use of charter aircraft and extended contracts to a stage where new contracting has to be considered-to the Parliament on all aspects to improve coastal surveillance, such as its adequacy and changes as are necessary to ensure an adequate coastal surveillance operation to protect Australia's coastline.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this really a serious exposition of defence policy?

—That was raised by the honourable member's colleague, the honourable member for New England. If he was talking about defence, I suggest the honourable member for Kooyong ask him what he was talking about. He raised the matter. I think a number of things should be said about fixed wing aircraft.
—What about your promise?

—Our promise was not to acquire a carrier, and that decision was made nearly two years ago. I inform this House that, at the time of this Government taking office, there was no carrier capacity within the Royal Australian Navy-a fact which seems to have been conveniently forgotten by former Ministers. There was no operational capacity for fixed wing naval aircraft to operate in the manner in which the former Minister says was essential to the operations of our fleet. HMAS Melbourne was tied up 18 months before we came to office and there were no plans in hand-nor would I have said that the Minister would have even suggested there were-to reintroduce HMAS Melbourne into service. If the former Government was concerned about the acquisition of a carrier and the timing of the decision not to go ahead with one, it should have been concerned about that over the last five years. It knew throughout that period that HMAS Melbourne was nearing the end of its life and decisions had to be made. But the former Government put off the decision because it was too hard and it was not prepared to face up to the political responsibilities to taking it. That is why the submission made by the former Minister to the Cabinet had not been dealt with four months after it had gone to Cabinet. I will tell honourable members why that is so. It is because the processes of government of this country were paralysed by a sore back and no other Minister had the guts to proceed with affairs of this nature. That is why the decision was not taken. The crocodile tears we see in this House tonight do not match the facts. The former Minister has said that we had to have fixed wing operational aircraft. The reason why the decision was not made was that no one in the Cabinet had the guts to go ahead without the presence of the former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser. This was his decision on HMS Invincible:

SPEECH.PARA: It will be used as a helicopter carrier and there shouldn't be any expectations in present circumstances that we go beyond that. We bought the carrier-

TALK.START.PARA: —Which carrier?
—Oh, God! If the honourable member had ears, he would know. If he is that dumb, why does he not just shut up and mind his own business? I said-

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I said-
—Order! The honourable member for Hume will remain silent. The Minister will address the Chair.
—If the honourable member would like to wake up and listen he will hear what I am saying. The former Prime Minister had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It will be used as a helicopter carrier and there shouldn't be any expectations in present circumstances that we'd go beyond that. We bought the carrier for its contribution to anti-submarine warfare, not for its capacity to have short takeoff and landing aircraft.

He was talking about the Invincible, as I said before. I wonder what that means. Firstly, we have a complaint in this House that we do not have a carrier capacity, a complaint from members of a government which tied up the carrier that we had 18 months ago and a government which clearly stated its intention not to have fixed-wing capacity for the Royal Australian Navy. That was a clear statement of government intent. Hypocrisy is the only word that can be used to describe that. There are a number of other aspects to defence policy. The present Government took office two months ago. It has made one major decision with relevance to the motion.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable members do not understand that we are talking about a motion, they ought to go out. That decision is that we will endorse the decision recommended to Cabinet by the former Minister. So the former Minister complains in this House that we agree with him and that what he said was an irresponsible act in respect of defence policy. If we are not to have a carrier capacity, it is necessary that a full examination take place of Australia's maritime capabilities, of the capabilities required for providing an adequate defence within the framework of our national capacities. I do not see any evidence, in any of the figures, that the previous Government placed that at a very high order.

SPEECH.PARA: I know what that Government said. I also know what it did. The average increase in defence expenditure under the previous Government was 1.5 per cent a year in real terms. Its stated policy, throughout its whole term of office, was for 7 per cent. It never achieved that. In order to maintain the 1.5 per cent, it ran down stocks, ran down equipments and deferred programs which were essential and have now reached critical stages. The stocks available to support the defence forces of this country now, which have been utilised as Budget substitutes by using fixed assets to supplement Budget considerations, are at dangerously low levels and it will take some time for them to be built up again because of forward commitments.

In respect to this motion, the Opposition has not come forward to criticise defence. It has used the motion as an opportunity to run a few hares, out of which it thinks it can get some political mileage. It has shown that since it went into opposition last, it has not changed one little bit. It has no consideration for the national interest and no consideration for putting facts before the Parliament. It is back at its old trick of accusing an incoming government of doing what it planned to do itself. The facts stay; they are there . The former Prime Minister indicated that his Government had no intention of acquiring fixed wing capacities for the Navy. The problem is that Opposition members did not have the guts to tell people when there was an election coming. The facts are that the former Government had no intention of acquiring a carrier for the Navy and Cabinet submissions were before the Government on that matter. It did not tell anyone about that matter because it did not want to tell anyone about that matter.

One of the other matters which concerns me is the degree to which people have been misled by statements by the former Government. It was, unfortunately, a practice to tell people that things would be done or had been done when they had not been done, and not the least of those matters was in respect of funds which would be made available. The former Government has run down the defence forces of Australia. It has-if the former Minister considers it such-neglected its responsibilities to national security, in that the former Minister says that the disclosures which have now become apparent constitute a danger to Australia in respect of the Australian Intelligence Security Organisation and other security organisations. The former Government had those reports in its possession for the last seven years and did nothing at all about them. If Opposition members are concerned about the national security of this nation, they ought to get a mirror and look at themselves to find out where the blame lies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me make one or two observations about the speech of the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes). I point out that it is morning, and not night time. Secondly, he talked about one decision every two months. I ask him whether this is what we can expect from him in the remaining months that the Labor Government may be in office-one decision every two months. Thirdly, I think it is a valid observation that the next speaker from the Government side of the House, a former Minister for Defence, is looking increasingly good to take over the Defence portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing here will be a repeat performance of the defence policies of this country in the years 1972 to 1975. During those years, I was a serving soldier in the regular Australian Army. During those years I saw the destruction of the armed forces of this country. One of the reasons I am here now and, I may tell the House, one of the reasons that my colleague, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) is here, is that when I left the Services and when he left them we determined to do something about the Labor policy for the defence of this country. The first thing I did when I left the Services was join the Liberal Party so that I could do something about getting the Australian Labor Party out. During those years we saw a run-down in the defence forces of this country-and I saw it because I was part of them. What we are seeing now will be a repeat of those disastrous years because, if for no other reason, the Government has a budgetary problem. The first thing that will be affected will be the defence forces of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about it. Tell us about your seven years.

—I would like to say a word or two about the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. I do not plan to apportion any blame in this matter but I will ask the Government what it intends to do about the leaks that are occurring. No country can afford to have the sorts of leaks that we are seeing throughout the media day by day. This situation has set back our national security God knows how many years. Will other countries trust us? The obvious answer is of course no. I urge the Government to repair the damages as soon as possible. As it is, it will take years to build up trust that others have in this country.
—What was the date of the leaks? You seem to know the date.

—I am not apportioning blame. As I said, I am asking the Government to fix this matter quickly. Let me turn to the Fleet Air Arm. For something like 50 years we have painfully built up our Fleet Air Arm so that it is the equal of any other force in the world. At one savage blow it is to be disbanded and destroyed. Does the Minister or do honourable members opposite really think that we can turn the tap on and off when we are talking about training personnel in the defence forces? If they do, they are very stupid. What is happening now is that 50 years of expertise is about to be disbanded. To say glibly that the people displaced can go to the Australian Army, the Royal Australian Navy or the Royal Australian Air Force is a lot of nonsense. They are specialists in fleet operations. What will they do if they choose to go to the other Services? Their expertise will be lost forever. On 4 May, in this House, the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have also given the local community a guarantee that the Albatross base will continue to operate at a level comparable with that which now exists.

There are over 2,000 people at HMAS Albatross. How in God's name will he maintain that level when we have no Fleet Air Arm? What is to happen to the helicopters, and the A4s, probably one of the most effective ground attack aircraft that we have? Also, I understand that the Trackers are to be sold. All this is happening at a time when our coastal surveillance system badly needs updating. This country cannot continue to hire civilian aircraft to guard its northern approaches. Anybody who has been in those areas recently will know that the fishermen and graziers around the northern coast of Australia set their watches when the civilian aircraft goes over. They know that the aircraft will be there at a certain time, and so do the smugglers and other people bringing stuff into Australia illegally. So why do we not use these Navy aircraft productively instead of selling them?

Let me say a few words about the aircraft carrier. The first point to be made is that the Australian Government had undertaken to purchase a carrier, the Invincible. Although it may have been designated originally for helicopter operations, there was no reason why in the long term it could not have been used for fixed wing operations. What concerns me most of all about the decision not to purchase a carrier is that we are going back to a fortress Australia syndrome or attitude which is not in the best interests of this country. We should consider the attitudes of all our friends and neighbours. The Americans are increasingly looking to Australia to partake more in the defence of this part of the world. Papua New Guinea, Fiji and Vanuatu are among some 36 countries and territories in our part of the world looking to Australia for help and guidance. So what do we do? We are the only maritime country in the world that is not expanding its seaborne operations capability. We decide that we will not get a carrier and, what is more, we will disband the Fleet Air Arm which means that presumably we will not have a carrier while this Government is in office. We are not just saying we are delaying the decision; we are taking the Fleet Air Arm out as well so that as far as this Government is concerned there will never be a carrier for Australia.

It is not just the protection of our sea lanes about which we should be concerned, important though that is. It is important that we demonstrate to our friends and our allies in this part of the world that we have a viable defence capacity should they ever request our assistance. I hope we are not in the business of just looking after Australia. It would be a disaster in the long run if we did not have the capacity to help our friends should they request it and were it in our interests to do so. What sort of friends would we be if Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu or any other neighbouring country requested our assistance and we did not have the capacity to help them? Honourable members should consider that.

The conclusion to be drawn is that it will be much more expensive for this country, in the long term, not to have a carrier than to have one. The Government talks glibly about the cost of a carrier and the cost of maintaining the Fleet Air Arm. The Fleet Air Arm is being disbanded. It will take years and years to build it up again, the same as it would after the destruction of any other fighting body of men. It takes a long time to produce trained personnel- the pilots and the expertise associated with running what is probably the most tricky operation of the lot, fleet operations. At a time when our friends and neighbours are looking to us for help, we are restricting our capacity to give it. The fact is that the weakness we are displaying will encourage enemies to take overseas adventures as has happened throughout history. The first responsibility of any government is to protect its territories and its national interest. On that basis, the decisions taken by the present Government indicate that it has failed this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a grave error in the drafting of this matter of public importance. It should read:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to Australia's defence capability through the negligence, incompetence and broken promises of seven years of the Fraser Government.

The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) walked into this House like Hamlet clutching poor old Yorick and talked about the problems in the system. In Hamlet terms, the problem in the system is that there is something wrong in the state of Denmark. What is wrong in this state of 'Denmark' happens to be the incompetence and the ineptitude of the seven years of the Fraser Government

For the benefit of the newer members of this House I will go through the historical record. In 1976 the Fraser Government brought in a White Paper. It was a pretty good White Paper as my dear friend, the honourable member for Moreton (Sir James Killen) will recall, because it was based fundamentally on the program of the Labor Government. At that time the Fraser Government said that it would pursue a policy of a real 5 per cent increase in the defence vote. The Government had it easy. It inherited a going proposition from the Whitlam Labor Government and in fact for five of its seven years it continued to parade in borrowed clothes.

I will go through the procurement program, and I invite the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) to go through it. I refer to the Rapiers, the guided missile frigates, the Leopard tanks and the Orion aircraft which were all put in place by the previous Labor Government. So for the first five years the Fraser Government had it easy. It had a program which it had only to implement because it was in place when it took over. The present Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) has no such luxury. But, having said that it would carry out this program, another broken promise set in. On 24 October 1978, after the great statement of 1976, the honourable member for Moreton-I do not blame him; he was under a very difficult leader-came into this House, after all the great promises of the White Paper, and said:
Outlay this year . . . will not be large enough for us to achieve in the time we originally contemplated all of the objectives and projects of the Defence White Paper of 1976.

That was a dismal confession of failure. But it does not end there. Having failed dismally in its first effort, in February 1980 it came in with a whole series of new propositions. This time it was not going to go for a real increase of 5 per cent which it had failed to do in the 1976 White Paper but proudly announced that the increase would be 7 per cent. But again the honourable member for Moreton had to come into this House on 29 April 1982 and say:
Consequently some planned objectives for the development of the Defence Force will not be achieved as early as originally intended.

The Fraser Government's programs of 1976, 1978 and 1980 were failures. In the seven years of the Liberal Government the defence policy of this country was a shambles. The Fraser Government could not maintain a sustained defence effort. The first time it promised 5 per cent and delivered 3 per cent. The second time it promised 7 per cent, but the historic average over the seven years of the Liberal Government was less than 3 per cent. This is the heritage that falls to the Labor Government at this time. The situation is very critical. As the right honourable member for New England said, there are problems in the system. There are problems in the system of the Force structure; there are problems in the system of financial planning. These continuous deferments are building up. Next year and the year after there will be a crunch point in the financial arrangements for the defence forces. Nobody knows it better than my good friend, the honourable member for Moreton. I have been through the five-year rolling programs. I have noted the tremendous impact that will occur when the purchase fo the FA18s comes in. The price of these aircraft has now reached $40m a copy. When one multiplies that by the number involved, one will see the critical financial situation that this Government has to meet because of the ineptitude and crass bad planning of the former Government.

For the benefit of newer members of the Parliament, let me recall the sorts of hypocrisies which were indulged in by the honourable gentlemen opposite. In the period from 1972 to 1975, we brought about a total restructuring of the defence forces. There was from the other side at that time carping criticism about the reorganisation, but I am delighted to say-I compliment the honourable member for Moreton on it-that some time later-in fact on 25 March 1980-the honourable member for Moreton had the decency to come into this House and say:

The defence administration in Australia was subjected in the 1970s to the most profound reorganisation in its history. I want it to be entirely clear that on the whole the Government is satisfied with the results.

I compliment the former Minister for Defence on that unsolicited tribute to the Labor Government from 1972-75. The honourable member for McPherson claimed that there was disruption in the defence forces in that period. I ask the honourable member to examine the record, a record of very tight financial controls to ensure that the five-year rolling program which we bequeathed to the previous Government in 1975 was workable and that the Force structure was solidly planned . That was the heritage we gave to the previous Government. This enabled that Government, when it came to power, to carry through the program which we had set up. But the great misfortune for us and for Australia was that the previous Government did not do it in full competence. So, as the right honourable member for New England pointed out, there are problems in the system. But these problems are of that Government's making and it becomes the very difficult task of this Government to try to rectify the mistakes which the former Government made. As I pointed out at the beginning of my speech-I believe it should be recorded in Hansard-this matter of public importance should read:
The threat to Australia's defence capability has arisen through the negligence, incompetence and broken promises of seven years of the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Em- ployment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill implements two important aspects of the Government's industrial relations policy which was so soundly endorsed by Australians at the last election. Our policy in this area is designed to improve industrial relations in this country, something which is essential if the process of Australia's economic recovery is not to be impeded. The proposals before the House will contribute to the achievement of that objective.

I draw the attention of honourable members to the background of the first area of government policy dealt with in the Bill, namely, the abolition of the Industrial Relations Bureau and the re-establishment of the Arbitration Inspectorate. The Bureau was established by the Fraser Government in 1977. It was ill-conceived and it was not wanted by employers or the union movement. From the outset, both groups have sought its abolition.

The Bureau was presented by the Fraser Government as the 'third arm' of the conciliation and arbitration machinery, to complement the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the Federal Court. It was described as being an independent body with the role of securing the observance of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the regulations and awards. It took over the labour inspection role of the Arbitration Inspectorate, and was also given responsibility for enforcing a battery of new provisions which intruded the Bureau into the internal affairs of registered organisations and applied new sanctions to employers and unions.

The Fraser Government believed that industrial relations could be controlled by legislative prescriptions, without proper consideration of the reality of industrial relations in Australia. The Industrial Relations Bureau was perceived as the machinery for implementing the Government's approach to industrial relations. Such an approach has never worked and will never do so. It is not an approach that will be taken by the Hawke Government which is committed to working with the union movement and employers and their associations to achieve better industrial relations in the interests of all Australians.

Moreover, the Government believes, and both the union movement and employers agree, that labour inspection will be more appropriately carried out if it is vested once again in an adequately resourced Arbitration Inspectorate which is ultimately responsible to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and within his Department. This is how the Inspectorate operated before the regrettable creation of the Bureau. The Bill restores this position, reflecting what was in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act before provision was made for the Bureau. There are some minor alterations to enhance the administration of the Inspectorate.

I should stress, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the proposed legislation will not give the Inspectorate the intrusive role that the Bureau had in respect of the internal affairs of registered organisations. It will, as it did previously, be required to secure the observance of the Act, the regulations and of awards. Its principal function will be to ensure that awards of the Commission are being observed. I point out to honourable members that, again as was the case previously, the powers and duties of inspectors will be as determined by the Minister. They will be open to public scrutiny by publication in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

I turn now to the second policy area covered by the Bill. This concerns the facilitation of amalgamations under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act of registered organisations of employers and employees. It is widely recognised that there are too many unions in Australia. This has produced many problems in Australian industrial relations. For example, there are difficulties in dispute resolution where many unions are often involved; demarcation disputes present their own particular problems.

The National Labour Consultative Council considered this problem over a number of years and in 1980 put forward proposals to encourage amalgamations of registered organisations. These recommendations were designed to facilitate amalgamations in the public interest where registered organisations could establish a community of interest between their industrial interests. Criteria were agreed upon for such a community of interest to be established before a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and, in such a case, the minimum voting requirements under the Act for amalgamation ballots were to be reduced. These proposals were accepted by the Fraser Government and indeed endorsed by the then Prime Minister in his election speech in 1980. However the then Government abandoned them in favour of unworkable proposals for industry unions which the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation last year concluded would increase industrial disputation.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Bill proposes the introduction of the 1980 NLCC recommendations, with some alterations which have been developed in a review of those recommendations by the Government in consultation with the NLCC to make them more effective. The NLCC has agreed that its earlier proposed community of interest criteria be widened to encourage desirable amalgamations, such as between the unions in the textile, clothing and footwear industries whose attempts to amalgamate have been frustrated by the existing provisions and may have continued to be frustrated if the community of interest provisions had not been widened beyond those originally proposed by the NLCC. The Bill will also facilitate amalgamations which involve more than two organisations, whether such amalgamations are under the existing provisions, which continue to operate, or under the proposed community of interest provisions. Honourable members will note that all amalgamations will also benefit from a further provision of the Bill to bring voting rolls in amalgamation ballots more up to date. These provisions also reflect the NLCC recommendations. It is important to note that there has been full consultation with the NLCC on all the provisions of the Bill and they are agreed with by the Council.

I now wish to outline these provisions in greater detail. In relation to the abolition of the Bureau, the Bill repeals Part VIA of the Act, which provides for the establishment and general powers of the Bureau and removes its specific rights and responsibilities. For the purposes of securing the observance of the Act, the regulations and awards, the Bill provides for the appointment of inspectors within the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations broadly along the same lines as applied to the former inspectorate.

As I have said, certain changes will be made to the former arrangements to enhance the administration of the inspectorate. In particular, appointments to the position of inspector are only to be under the Public Service Act and the power of the Minister to appoint inspectors to carry out their functions under the Act will be capable of delegation to a senior officer of my department. Inspectors will again be given powers to enter buildings, interview persons and inspect documents for the purpose of ascertaining whether awards and the requirements of the Act and regulations are being observed. However, the former power to require the production of documents is to be made more effective to allow inspectors to require employers, by notice in writing, to produce documents at the premises of the inspector. This power would be exercisable only where there was a failure by the employer to produce that material at his or his agent's premises at all or within a reasonable time.

Where breaches of Federal awards are detected, inspectors will be able, if it is necessary to do so, to bring proceedings before a court for a penalty under the Act. I again emphasize that, as previously, the powers and duties of inspectors will be as laid down by the Minister. As was previously the case, the Bill will allow for arrangements to be made for State and Federal labour inspectors to operate within the respective jurisdictions on a reciprocal basis.

There are some provisions of the Act in respect of which the Government believes that the role of the Bureau would more properly be exercised by the Industrial Registrar. Accordingly, upon the abolition of the Bureau, its responsibilities for investigations of deficiencies in the accounts and financial statements of registered organisations will be taken over by the Industrial Registrar. He will also take the place of the Bureau as one of the parties able to apply to the Federal Court for a declaration as to whether a person is eligible to be appointed or elected to an office in an organisation or to continue to hold such an office. The Industrial Registrar will also assume the sole responsibility for the conduct of investigations into irregularities alleged in applications for inquiries into elections in organisations, a role which he had prior to the creation of the Bureau.
The Bill also contains transitional provisions to enable proceedings under the Act in a court at the time of the abolition of the Bureau to be proceeded with at the discretion of the Minister.

I turn now to provisions of the Bill dealing with the amalgamation of registered organisations. Honourable members will be aware that the existing legislation requires that, for an amalgamation to be successful, each organisation must achieve a return of ballot papers in the amalgamation ballot from at least 50 per cent of members eligible to vote and, of those voting formally, more than half must vote in favour of the amalgamation. The Bill provides for an easing of these requirements in relation to organisations which can establish a community of interest in respect of their industrial interests.

Organisations which apply to the Industrial Registrar to amalgamate will be able, at the same time, to apply to a full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a declaration that the proposed amalgamation is in the public interest and in the industrial interests of those organisations. The Commission is to be empowered to make that declaration where it is satisfied that the amalgamation would further the objects of the Act and that there is a community of interest between the organisations in respect of their industrial interests.

The Bill sets out a number of criteria under which the Commission can determine whether a community of interest exists. Organisations will be required to meet only one of those criteria. For employee organisations those criteria are that a substantial number of the members of each of the organisations are either:
Eligible to become members of the other organisations or each of the other organisations;
Engaged in the same work, aspects of the same work or in similar work;
Bound by the same awards;
Employed in the same or related work by employers engaged in the same industry; or
Engaged in work, or in industries, in respect of which there is a community of interest.

Similar criteria will apply to employer organisations. Where organisations obtain a declaration from the Commission, they will be required in an amalgamation ballot to achieve a return of ballot papers from only 25 per cent of members eligible to vote-rather than 50 per cent as previously-and a simple majority of valid votes would be sufficient to approve the amalgamation.

The Bill contains two other initiatives which will apply to amalgamations whether under the existing amalgamation provisions or the provisions for community of interest amalgamations. First, in an amalgamation involving more than two organisations, provision is made for the applicants to provide for alternative schemes of amalgamation. If in a ballot one or more of the organisations fails to secure the necessary support for the amalgamation, the amalgamation may still proceed in respect of those organisations the members of which voted in favour of an alternative scheme of amalgamations. Under the existing legislation those organisations would be forced to repeat the entire amalgamation process.

The second initiative relates to the persons who are eligible to participate in an amalgamation ballot. Significant difficulties are faced by organisations in achieving a successful amalgamation because of the existing requirements in this area. Under the Act at present, the roll of voters consists of persons who were financial members of the organisation at any time within the 12 months before the day on which the Registrar gave his approval for the amalgamation to be submitted to ballot. Moreover, the ballot may not be conducted for several months after that date. Consequently, the roll may not accurately reflect the actual membership of the organisation. In order to overcome this problem, the Bill provides that the roll of voters will comprise those persons who, one month before the opening date of the ballot, were eligible under the rules of the organisation to vote in an amalgamation ballot, or where the rules do not so provide, persons who were eligible under the rules to vote in a rank and file election for an office within the organisation.

The Government believes, and is supported in its belief by both employer and trade union bodies, that these initiatives, together with the community of interest provisions, will do much to facilitate amalgamations which are both in the interests of the organisations themselves and the community generally. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Macphee) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Keating, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The major purpose of this Bill is to amend the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 to rectify technical deficiencies which have recently come to light. At the same time, the opportunity is being taken to include in the tax sharing base some newly imposed Commonwealth taxes. In 1981, an understanding was reached with the States that, following a transitional year, their tax sharing grants would be calculated by reference to a 'total' tax base rather than the personal income tax base used in previous arrangements. That, and other understandings between the Premiers and the previous Government, formed the basis of the tax sharing Act. Apart from the provision for certain taxes-or parts thereof-to be declared by the Treasurer to be a special surcharge and thereby be excluded from the tax pool, the Act did appear at the time to cover all major Commonwealth taxation collections. Moreover, to date, determinations of taxation receipts required under the Act have been made in accordance with the understanding with the States. Under section 27 of the Act, a determination once made is presumed conclusively correct.

I record these facts simply for the information of honourable members present and to assure them that, to date, determinations of tax collections under the Act have been made in accordance with the spirit of the understanding with the States. Recently, however, questions have arisen as to whether, stricly interpreted, the definition of income tax in the Act is in fact as broad as intended. Advice from Attorney-General's Department has confirmed the doubt that exists regarding this definition. The definition of income tax in the Act is derived by reference to section 6 (I) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, a section which deals with assessed income tax only. Collections of pay-as-you- earn instalments, company tax instalments or provisional tax instalments collected by the Commonwealth are not assessed, within the meaning of the Act at the time of collection. Late payment penalties would also not strictly be included under the present definition.

It is estimated that around $600m of the net income tax collections in 1981-82 would represent tax not subsequently falling within the definition of the Act. Because of the lag between personal income tax collections and the issue of related assessments, the determination which would have been made in that year, had the strict interpretation of the Act been adopted, would have been substantially below the determination actually made. Although previous determinations were consistent with the intention of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act, the Government now proposes to make the necessary amendments to bring it into line with those intentions.

As I have already indicated, in addition to amending the definition of income tax included in the tax sharing base, the present Bill also deals with newly introduced Commonwealth taxes. In recent times the Commonwealth has enacted two pieces of legislation, namely the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Act 1982 and the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982, which should, as part of the understanding reached with the States in 1981, be added to the list of taxes forming the tax base for the purposes of the tax sharing Act. Finally, I note that the amendments set out in the Bill also make allowance for the deduction from the tax sharing base of any payments which could be made by the Commonwealth under the proposed legislation for the payment of interest on tax overpayments. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is one of a package of Bills, the main purpose of which is to introduce a new system for granting tariff concessions. The new system, to be known as the commercial tariff concession system, is a modification of and replaces the existing commercial by-law system. By-laws have been an integral part of the customs tariff since Federation. Presently, under Part XVI of the Customs Act and particularly section 273, a concessional rate of duty can be applied to imported goods which comply with criteria prescribed in a by-law tariff item. In other words, the existing by-law system provides the legal means of removing duties, other than duties of a revenue nature, which serve no protective purpose.

The sole and long-standing criterion for concessional by-law entry is where suitably equivalent goods are not reasonably available from local production. Considerable difficulty has emerged with this criterion on economic, administrative and legal grounds and as a result the commercial by-law system was referred to the Industries Assistance Commission in April 1981 for review. This in fact was the first complete review of the by-law system.

The Industries Assistance Commission reported to the Government of the day on 2 July 1982 and the new commercial tariff concession system encompassed in this legislation is largely based on the Commission's recommendations. The Commission found that the commercial by-law system provides flexibility in tariff administration and has widespread support in the business community. Many production activities depend to some extent on the by-law entry of inputs and there could be serious disruption if the by-law system was terminated quickly without a prior comprehensive review of all assistance provided by the tariff. While one commissioner recommended ultimate abandonment of the by-law system, the majority concluded that the present system should be maintained in an improved form. The Government has accepted this majority view.

In broad terms the Government has adopted a new criterion which will provide that commercial tariff concessions will be issued where the Minister is satisfied that no goods serving similar functions are produced or are capable of being produced in the normal course of business in Australia. The key words in this criterion are 'serving similar functions' and new section 269B (4) provides an interpretation of them. The test will be the degree of cross-elasticity of demand between the imported and Australian produced goods. In practical terms, this means that these tariff concessions will be decided by determining the effect that a reduced rate of duty will have on competition or potential competition between the local and imported goods. This will be based on a practical and realistic assessment of the market situation. The onus will be on the applicant for a tariff concession to identify the goods involved, the market for the goods and the degree of competition or potential competition between the imported goods and Australian-made goods.

Notwithstanding this criterion being met, the proposed new section 269E provides that the Minister may refuse to grant a concession if he considers that such a concession would have a substantially adverse effect on the market available to goods produced in Australia or if it would not be in the national interest.

The Bill also provides in section 269D that concessional entry will not apply in respect of certain classes or kinds of goods. The classes or kinds of goods envisaged are those where there exists a wide and comprehensive range of both Australian-made and imported goods which, notwithstanding differences in construction, quality, price, et cetera, basically compete with each other in the market place. Included in this category are foodstuffs, motor vehicles, footwear and jewellery. These exclusions will be prescribed in an 'Exclusions Schedule' in the Customs regulations.

Comparing the new criterion with the existing one, the proposed new criterion conforms more closely with established industry assistance objectives and should reduce disagreement and legal disputation over fine technical points in respect of particular goods. It should result in a more predictable administration for users of the system. The new criterion reflects to a large extent the way in which the current by-law system has in fact been administered in recent years using the Minister's discretionary power under the existing legislation.

Other aspects of the system proposed in this legislation include the requirement for advertising applications for new concessions in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. This will make for better public scrutiny of the system, particularly by local manufacturers whose views will be taken into account prior to a decision being made on an application.

The effective date of new concessions is proposed to be a date no earlier than the date of receipt by the Department of Industry and Commerce of the application or a notice of intention to lodge an application. In the case of revocation of an existing concession, the Bill provides that concessional entry will be accorded to goods that are in transit to Australia at the date of revocation.

There are two other aspects on which I would like to comment. The first relates to end-use security and shortfall concessions and the other relates to the review of existing by-law concessions. The new system does not provide for concessions involving end-use under security provisions or situations involving shortfalls in supply. This is the only area of potential significant loss of concessional entry following the adoption of the new criterion. The reasons for the exclusion of these special concessions are contained in the Industries Assistance Commission report.

In respect of concessions for particular end-uses, the Commission found that these have created a number of problems in principle, in their economic effect and in administration. To illustrate these problems, if it is necessary to restrict the availability of a concession to a particular use, there must be locally produced goods available. End-use concessions also lead to different rates of duty being paid on the same product by different importers depending on the use to which it is put. Demand can be influenced as a result. The validity of entry under such a concession must depend on there being safeguards to ensure that the imports are used only in the specified end-use. It is a fact of life that this has created considerable administrative difficulties as these conditions are often costly and nigh on impossible to control. This also raises the question of the potential for erosion of the protection already accorded to local industry. Existing end-use by-laws will be phased out over the next two years and any future proposals for arrangements of this kind will be considered for reference to the Industries Assistance Commission as special by-laws outside the tariff concession system.

In respect of concessions to cover shortfalls, that is, where local industry is unable to maintain normal output, the Commission did not see these concessions as appropriate within the new concession system. Existing arrangements will, however, remain until they are reviewed by the Commission. Future applications for such shortfall concessions, and any cases involving extraordinary demands, will be considered for reference to the Commission. Any resulting concession of this kind will likewise be introduced as a by-law outside the new system.

This leads me to the second matter, the review of existing by-laws and the granting of tariff concessions. I have already mentioned the position in relation to end-use and shortfall by-laws. Other existing commercial by-laws will be reviewed and new concessions issued where the new criterion is satisfied .
