This will be done gradually over a two-year period to accord importing and manufacturing interests a reasonable time in which to consider the implications of any changes for their business and minimise any disruption likely to occur.

Decisions taken under the new tariff concession system will be reviewable by the existing internal review system within the Department of Industry and Commerce. The legislation makes provision for applicants who wish to make further requests for review to seek a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission. Also, operation of the new system will be subject to review under the provisions of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Subject to the passage of this legislation through the Parliament, an extensive program is proposed to acquaint fully importing and manufacturing interests with the new system. Consequential amendments have been made to the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975.

The Bill also includes two other matters which are quite separate from the tariff concession provisions. Clause 3 of the Bill provides that Papua New Guinea content is to be included in determining whether goods are to be regarded as the manufacture of a forum island country, a declared preference country or a developing country. This amendment is in accordance with an agreement reached with the Government of Papua New Guinea. Clause 4 removes the requirement that goods eligible for tender quota must be imported and entered for home consumption within the same quota period. The intention of the existing legislation was to prevent goods being held back from entry to take advantage of a lower rate of duty which might apply in a later quota period. Experience shows that this fear has little basis. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will, among other things, honour an important election commitment to abolish the declaration that pensioners and concessional beneficiaries must sign when they receive pharmaceutical benefits. As honouring this promise involves legislative change, the Government is taking one of the first opportunities in the new Parliament to honour its election pledge. Honourable members will recall that the previous Government introduced from 1 January of this year an arrangement under which a pharmaceutical chemist could not supply a benefit item to a pensioner free of charge or to a concessional beneficiary at the reduced contribution rate, unless the patient completed a complex declaration as to this entitlement. The declaration was printed on the reverse of the prescription form thereby requiring two signatures for each prescription, once on the declaration and once for the receipt of the benefit. In practice many patients, particularly the aged, the infirm, migrants and the disabled, were unable to complete the declaration form without help. There was widespread opposition to the arrangement. Its abolition will be welcomed generally.

I draw honourable members' attention to clause 6 of the Bill, which would establish a far simpler mechanism for pensioners and concessional beneficiaries to claim their entitlement. Under the proposed scheme a pharmacist would be authorised to supply the benefit if the prescription form contains certain basic information about the patient's entitlement. The information needed will be set out in regulations and will be easily available from the benefit cards issued to all persons entitled to free or concessional pharmaceutical benefits. A medical or dental practitioner, the patient or any person on behalf of the patient, or the pharmacist supplying the benefit, will all be allowed to enter the entitlement information on the front of the prescription form. There will no longer be a need for persons to sign twice in order to obtain supply of the benefit and the patient contribution concession. It is expected that the problems being experienced by patients and pharmacists with the present complex arrangements will disappear.

The new prescription form will simplify the present complex declaration form in four ways. First, all the required information will be provided on one side of the form. There will be no requirements on the reverse side of the form. Second, the information for beneficiary status will be simplified, making it easier for beneficiaries and pharmacists, yet still meeting the necessary demands for effective departmental monitoring. Third, a single signature will indicate both receipt of the prescription and claim to free or concessional entitlement. Fourth, doctors and, if need be, pharmacists will be encouraged to assist beneficiaries in completing the form. However, I would make it clear that responsibility for the accuracy of an entitlement claim rests, as it rightly should, with the beneficiary.

To discourage fraud, clause 9 of the Bill amends section 103 of the Act, the offence provision, expressly to cover the new procedure and my Department will continue to monitor closely the supply of benefits, and will examine improved monitoring devices to eradicate fraud in the pharmacy area.

The opportunity has also been taken in this Bill to amend the National Health Act to ensure effective continuation of established policies and practices in the Commonwealth control of nursing homes fees. I draw honourable members' attention to clause 3 of the Bill. The Federal Government's annual contribution to accommodation and home care programs for the aged can be expected to pass the $1,000m mark in the next budget. Of this amount, it is estimated that expenditure subsidising the provision of care in nursing homes will account for $865m. The recurrent funding of nursing home beds considerably overshadows all Federal capital expenditure on accommodation for the aged, recurrent funding for hostels and all expenditure on domiciliary care, and it is rising substantially.

While the expenditure on the nursing homes programs continues to escalate significantly there are growing criticisms of the present arrangements. The aged , their families and taxpayers are increasingly questioning the inadequacies, expense and the mismatch of services which comprise Australia's present arrangements for care of the aged. Care of the aged is now an important community and political concern.

The report released last year by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on expenditure entitled 'In a Home or at Home: Accommodation and Home Care for the Aged' is a significant document which identifies the strengths and weaknesses of the present arrangements. The report shows Australia as having a complex, fragmented and expensive system of aged care. A major emphasis of the report is on the preponderance of institutional care over domiciliary and community care and on the need to redress this imbalance. At the same time the report provides clear recommendations aimed at rationalising and improving the present arrangements.

The Government endorses the thrust of this report. As a nation we go on spending very considerable amounts on institutional care of the aged whilst severely restricting funding to those who would prefer to remain at home or in the community. The Government intends to develop a Community Care Program to provide support for the elderly who wish to remain in their own homes. Under this program there will be a comprehensive range of domiciliary and community services provided across Australia.

On the residential side our task will be to moderate growth in the nursing home sector, while continuing to pursue more equitable geographic distribution of nursing home beds, and to increase the availability of hostel accommodation. It is our view that neither per capita nursing home benefits funding nor deficit funding are ideal methods for securing the proper national development of nursing homes in the context of a total care policy for the aged.

Existing nursing home benefits and deficit funding arrangements will be replaced by program grants paid to nursing homes. These program grants will be based on standard costs for the services delivered less the income received by the homes through standard patient contributions. The program grant system will take some time to develop. In the meantime the existing funding arrangements for nursing homes will be maintained.

The principal purpose of clause 3 of the Bill is to ensure protection for patients against excessive fee increases and at the same time to ensure appropriate control of expenditure on benefits under the current nursing home benefits arrangements pending the introduction of the Government's Residential Care Program. Expenditure on the Nursing Homes Benefits Program is determined by the number of approved beds and the level of benefit. The benefit level in each State is related to the levels of nursing home fees in that State which in turn are determined by my Department having regard to costs necessarily incurred by nursing home proprietors.

The existing legislation on the control of fees simply provides that in determining fees the permanent head shall 'have regard to costs necessarily incurred in providing nursing home care in the nursing home'. Two recent Federal Court judgments have shown that this legislation is not able to support the policies and practices followed over many years in the administration of fees control-policies and practices which have been followed by both Labor and Liberal-National Party governments. These judgments have serious implications for the overall cost of the Nursing Homes Benefits Program.

The practical effect of the judgments is that the continued application of the policies and practices currently used in the determination of fees for nursing homes would result in many determinations being set aside, if challenged, as being made contrary to law. Costs which previously were not allowed for the purpose of setting fees now have to be given consideration possibly resulting in significant fee increases contrary to Government policy. This would lead to higher benefits and therefore increased Government expenditure.

Within the protected environment of the nursing home industry, there is very little incentive to constrain costs given the cost-based nature of fees determination and the high occupancy rates resulting from Government controls on new beds. Limited costs validations undertaken by my Department have revealed cases where costs have been artificially increased as a means of increasing profits. A recent consultancy survey undertaken with the co-operation of the industry revealed considerable variations in costs and profits between like homes.

Legal opinion has been given to the effect that, in the light of the recent Federal Court judgments, the legislation greatly circumscribes the use of policy guidelines. Consequently, very great burdens will be placed upon delegates of the permanent head whose task it is to determine fees. The judgments interpret the legislation as requiring the permanent head and his delegates to regard all costs necessarily incurred as fundamental matters for consideration, with each fee being determined on the basis of the merits of each individual case. The considerable difficulties involved in maintaining consistent administration Australia-wide will be much exacerbated. Successive governments have acted on the basis that Parliament, in passing the fees control legislation, did not intend to limit significantly central control and accountability, particularly given that the legislation makes detailed provision for appeals against, and reviews of, delegates' determinations.

There are indications that the effect of the Federal Court judgments could be an eventual increase in government expenditure on benefits of the possible order of $50m per annum. In a program which is expected to cost more than $600m for benefits alone in 1983-84, it is imperative that consistent and effective controls be exercised on costs which may have an inflationary effect on approved fees.

The effect of clause 3 will be to allow the effective continuation of established policies and practices pending the introduction of the Government's residential care program. The Bill provides that the Minister for Health may formulate principles in accordance with which the permanent head or his delegate is required to determine a scale of fees. It is intended that the principles will reflect established policy. The Bill provides for scrutiny of the principles by Parliament. In formulating these principles, regard is to be had to the factors set down in the proposed sub-section 40AA (7B). These factors will permit delegates to take account of the lack of normal market constraints on the nursing home industry.

Clause 4 of the Bill is designed to ensure that the Minister is not, of necessity, constrained by principles authorised by clause 3 which are intended to limit the discretion of a large number of delegates of the permanent head throughout the country. Thus, on appeal, the Minister may, in considering the merits of a case, decide that rigid application of the principle is inappropriate. This change puts beyond legal doubt a practice which has been followed by successive Ministers of governments of all complexions.

In summary, the proposed changes will ensure that the Government is able to continue the application of policies and practices in nursing homes fees control , established and supported by successive governments, pending the introduction of the present Government's residential care program.

I now turn to clause 5 of the Bill which relates to the domiciliary nursing care benefit. Honourable members will be aware that this benefit is paid to persons who care for persons, generally relatives, in their own homes rather than having them admitted to nursing homes. To attract this benefit, persons are medically assessed by their own doctor and by a Commonwealth medical officer as requiring continuing nursing care to an extent that admission requirements to a nursing home would be satisfied. Other eligibility criteria for the benefit include that the person providing care and the patient must be domiciled in the same residence and regular nursing attention must be provided by a registered nurse.

Where a person ceases to provide domiciliary nursing care to a patient, section 58J of the National Health Act provides that the permanent head of my Department or his delegate shall revoke approval of the benefit. At present, this provision restricts the delegation of the power of revocation to a departmental medical practitioner. This restriction results in unnecessary diversion of medical staff resources in that revocation of an approval often results from non-medical considerations such as a change in residential arrangement or, indeed, the death of a patient.

It is this unnecessary restriction in section 58J which is removed by the amendment in clause 5. Of course, a delegate would have available, if required in the process of exercising the delegation to revoke an approval, the advice of medical practitioners and other professional personnel. The amendment does not remove the inherent requirement in the domiciliary nursing care arrangements that a decision, requiring medical judgment, which may result in the revocation of an approval for the benefit, can be made only by a medical practitioner.
I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Carlton) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT (ELECTION BLACKOUT) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
The Governor-General, in his speech to the Parliament on 21 April 1983, stated that the Broadcasting and Television Act would be amended to:
remove the ban on political news and comment applying to radio and television stations in the three days before Federal and State elections.

I am pleased to introduce this Bill, which amends the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, and honours the Government's commitment to remove the election blackout. The only election matter which remains subject to restrictions is paid advertisements. The Bill also seeks to reduce the administrative burden on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

We are well aware of the controversy which is caused by the blackout each time an election is held. The momentum that has built up over the years for removal of this provision could not and should not be ignored, because the blackout is simply not supported by most Australians. Amongst members of parliament it is rejected not only by members of this side of the House, but also by a number of members opposite and by the Australian Democrats. It is opposed by the broadcasting industry; it is opposed by the print media; and it is opposed by most public interest groups associated with the media. Not to put too fine a point on it, the present provisions are an infringement of our civil liberties which should not be tolerated by a democratic society. In fact, the Human Rights Commission, prior to the last election, had already initiated an inquiry into section 116 of the Broadcasting and Television Act, the section which contains the blackout provisions, on the grounds that it violated internationally accepted political rights.

The Government believes that Australians are entitled to receive news and comment on the issues of the day at all times. They are certainly entitled to such news and comment in the process of an election when they are exercising their democratic right to choose a government. Even if it were possible to justify this abrogation of free speech-of the rights of free men and women to decide for themselves-there would be no logic in denying such information to the public via the electronic media, while simultaneously allowing the print media to report it in full. Radio and television broadcasters, who have been asking successive governments to lift the blackout year after year, are entitled to describe this as discrimination. The Government accepts their argument and has moved to end this discrimination.

The Bill provides that the blackout, from midnight of the Wednesday immediately preceding the election to the close of polls on the following Saturday, will apply in future to paid election advertisements only. All other election matter, including news, current affairs and political commentary, is a legitimate part of the public debate and should not be suppressed.

Of course all parties would oppose a broadcaster favouring one party over another, either in its news and current affairs or in its provision of free time . The right to broadcast carries with it a corresponding responsibility to act with impartiality in matters of public interest. The coverage of elections- indeed of all political matter-should be handled by broadcasters in the most sensitive manner, so that neither listeners and viewers, nor we politicians are prompted to cry 'foul' and seek to impose restrictions on all because of the sins of the few. The Bill therefore seeks to extend the existing obligation for broadcasters to afford reasonable opportunity for the broadcasting or televising of election matter to all political parties contesting the election which were represented in the last preceding parliament, so that it covers the whole election period, that is, in future this responsibility will exist from the issue of writs to the close of polls.

The Government also intends to examine the general question of fairness in the presentation of public issues by the electronic media. I am currently considering draft terms of reference for an inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which will allow a full and free public debate on this issue.

The Broadcasting and Television Act currently requires the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to notify any broadcaster who is exempted from the blackout on broadcasting election matter. When a Federal by-election is held, the Tribunal therefore is required to notify the majority of radio and television stations, that is, those not received in the electorate concerned. The blackout now will apply only to election advertisements, but it also seeks to assist the Tribunal by substituting a duty to advise only those stations which are subject to restrictions. In the example just mentioned, the Tribunal would need to notify only a few stations. The stations notified, of course, are required to comply with the notice. It should be noted that since the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Special Broadcasting Service are prohibited from playing any advertisements, they will no longer be subject to any election blackout.

The Bill defines election advertisements as advertisements which contain election matter and for which payment, whether by money or other consideration, is made directly or indirectly to the licensee of the radio or television station concerned; that is to say, advertisements broadcast on commercial stations and sponsorships broadcast on public broadcasting stations will not be able to contain election matter in the three days before an election.

The Bill before the House is slight in form but highly significant, because it introduces a reform which has been delayed for too long. There is a need for other laws reforming the way elections are conducted in Australia, but this reform is unarguably justified. The Government believes that Australia is a democratic society with a mature electorate and responsible broadcasters providing that electorate with the information it needs to make more balanced judgments on public issues. The electorate's need for accurate and informed comment is never more urgent than in the process leading up to the choice of governments. It is high time that we in the Parliament recognised this and repudiated the paternalism embodied in the present legislation. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Uren, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the winding up of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission, and the termination of the Christmas Island Agreement with New Zealand. As indicated in the Schedule to the Bill, both the Australian and New Zealand governments have agreed to these changes being made. Honourable members will recall that in June 1981 the Christmas Island Agreement Act was amended to enable an Australian government company-the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd-to replace the British Phosphate Commissioners as the managing agents of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission. As was indicated in the second reading speech on that legislation, those amendments were of an interim kind, and a completely new Christmas Island Agreement was to be negotiated with New Zealand.

The legislation now before the House takes that process further. Article I in the Schedule provides that the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission shall cease to function as soon as practicable, following which the Christmas Island Agreement will terminate, in accordance with Article IV. As to Article II, the intention is that the assets of the Commission on the island-the phosphate rock, buildings, plant et cetera-will pass to the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd, which will then mine the phosphate deposits in its own right rather than as managing agents.

Agreement is close to being reached with New Zealand on arrangements which will operate in future between the two countries in respect of island phosphate. This agreement will be embodied in an exchange of notes, which will begin to operate when the legislation before the House comes into force.

Just as the 1981 legislation affecting the Christmas Island Agreement paved the way for the British phosphate commissioners to be wound up, so does this legislation spell the end of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission. The Commission was established in 1949 by the Australian and New Zealand governments after they had on 31 December 1948 purchased the assets on the island of the Christmas Island Phosphate Co. Ltd. That company had been mining phosphate on the island since the 1890s. The purchase price at that time was #stg2,690,000. The original 1949 Agreement was revised in 1958 when Christmas Island became an Australian Territory.

The Commission has always been an unusual organisation. There are three part time commissioners, but no employees, the Commission having always had managing agents-for 32 years the British phosphate commissioners and since July 1981 the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the present commissioners-Mr M. C. Timbs, A.O., the Australian commissioner; Mr W. D. M. Bremner, C.M.G., the New Zealand commissioner; and Mr W. B. Marston, O.B.E., the joint commissioner.

It is a measure of the relationship between Australia and New Zealand that a body under the authority of both of them could for 25 years be responsible for conducting a mining operation on a Territory under the authority of one of them. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Braithwaite) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Appropriation Bill (No. 6) 1982-83 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1982-83, as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposals brought forward in the Appropriation Bills are purely for the funding of programs that were approved in the last Budget and , as such, I do not propose to comment on the great number of items that are raised in them. Rather, I thought that today I would spend a little time looking at the economic scene in Australia and would join the debate on the wages case.

SPEECH.PARA: The release yesterday of the balance of payments figures reflects very much the standard and situation of the economy. Indeed, the overall position that emerged from those figures certainly pointed out to me, and I am sure to those who take an interest in the economic debate, that while for the first time for some considerable period, an overall surplus was run on the balance of trade, the overall balance of payments showed a deficit of some size. As a consequence, one has to look at what contributed to that and reflect on what is happening in the Australian economy. There is no doubt that the level of exports was affected by such things as the drought and poor commodity prices. At the same time imports, which are vital in the composition of Australia's trade-ours is a small domestic market of 15 million, but imports represent a very significant item in the balance of payments-were down in some very sizable quantities. It is recorded that fuels fell by 21 per cent, textiles and fabrics by some 18 per cent, while metals and manufactures fell by some 16 per cent. This shows that the overall level of economic activity has fallen considerably.

In order to compensate for that downturn at this time, we need to look to the performance of the capital account. In the March quarter it showed that we have not attracted the level of funds which is necessary in terms of monetary policy and interest rates and which is also very material in the investment process of this nation. If we look further into that account we will see that off-shore investors have been most reluctant to come back to the Australian scene. I can understand that at the present moment because the Government simply has not given them the confidence that they look for. It has not attempted to allay the fears that were certainly around in the Whitlam years. It has not attempted to encourage the off-shore investors to come here with confidence. They still fear a confiscatory element that surrounds the socialist policy.

Although I can understand that the Government is certainly pressed in areas of finance and has problems with the Budget, I point to the fact that the current balance of payments figures clearly show that the amount of money that will be necessary in the next two to three years certainly will not be found. On top of that, a continuation of large deficits of the order of $10 billion will put increasing pressure on the capital market in Australia. This will force interest rates higher rather than bring about the lower rates to which we would all aspire. After 1 July 1983 the public debt requirement from Australian capital markets will be over $17,000m, a very sizable amount. These figures will not be achieved unless some confidence is brought back to foreign investors. Therefore, I think it is most important that we look to the question of the balance of payments.

I am today very indebted to the Australian Financial Review for its analysis of this matter and I recommend it to all honourable members. The newspaper, carrying a large one-page advertisement pointing out the virtues of the National Economic Summit Conference, also brought to my attention the fact that at the Summit the Government was told by business interests and people involved in unions and government that to lower unemployment and inflation and to get economic growth going will certainly require massive wage restraint. Mr Speaker, it might now be an appropriate time to adjourn the debate.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12 midday and in accordance with the Sessional Order , the debate is interrupted. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Government giving consideration to the call from the honourable member for Fraser for the abolition of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and its replacement with a different type of intelligence organisation?
—No.

—I ask the Prime Minister about claims by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and others that documents tabled at the National Economic Summit Conference show that Australia's employment prospects would be best served by a wages policy based on what was termed scenario C which entailed an extension of the wages pause until the end of the year. Would the overall economic interest of the country be best served by the adoption of scenario C as the basis of the Government's wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me refer again to the clear position that I put yesterday in this House as to the wages policy of this Government. The policy of this Government in respect of wages is clearly based upon the necessity to return to a system of centralised wage fixation, a position which, as I reminded the House yesterday, was overwhelmingly endorsed by the National Economic Summit Conference. Bearing that in mind, it is the clear position of this Government that at best only a minimal wage rise in the latter part of this year would be appropriate, that any such rise, if it is to eventuate, should be determined by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the context of a national wage case and that that should be the essential basis of any wage increase this year. I repeat the words that I used yesterday: This policy of the Government which has been endorsed so widely is a policy which is coherent, equitable and workable.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member referred to the question of scenario C which was in issue , to some extent, at the National Economic Summit Conference. Let me remind the House that scenario C would have entailed no wage increase until April of 1984. I suggest to the House that one does not need to be especially brilliant to appreciate that such a result is simply not achievable. If one really believes that it is achievable one only has to think about it to know that we would only move to a situation where there would be a complete collapse of any possibility of having any sort of rational wage fixation at all. Let me refer to what was said in respect of scenario C, in terms of its reality and realism, in an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday. In relation to scenario C which is touted about in some fashion by some members of the Opposition, the editorial stated:

And the sad fact is that Scenario C lacks credibility. The superior employment outcome it promises is based on the assumption that the wage freeze can be prolonged, all catch-up can be avoided, and a system of partial wage indexation can be held together until the end of 1985-86. With the clamour for 'sectional claims' and the talk of spurious 'special or extraordinary circumstances' already upon us, does anyone seriously imagine that such idyllic wage-fixing arrangements are possible? Scenario C purports to produce a profits share of national income greater than Australia has previously experienced. Does anyone seriously imagine that wage-earners could be induced to accept protracted partial indexation while profits rose to unknown heights? To embark on Scenario C would be to guarantee a wage explosion.
It concluded in this respect by saying:

The interests of the unemployed will best be served by a wages policy based on realism, not idealism. Employers will best contribute to the restoration of economic stability not by hankering after the impossible, but by uniting with the Government and union moderates to ensure that an achievable degree of wage restraint is actually achieved. This is a sufficiently daunting task.

That is a clear endorsement of the realism of the position adopted by the Government in this matter, as distinct from the policy advocated by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition which has been tried and which resulted in a massive wage explosion and an explosion in the level of unemployment in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether he agrees that, in the defence of liberty and reputation, an individual is entitled to know the details of any charge made against him. If so, will the Government make a specific charge against Mr David Combe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to my friend, the honourable member for Moreton, for his question and the spirit in which it is asked. I want to indicate to the House, and I am sure that the honourable member will appreciate and accept what I now have to say, that precisely in terms of our appreciation of the significance of the issue raised by the honourable member and because of the publicity which has emerged and which is not of our seeking in respect of the person concerned, I have people currently-right now, in that sense-working on this issue. I am not therefore in a position to give an answer to the honourable member now or at this stage in Question Time.

ANSWER.PARA: I say this to the honourable member and with respect through you, Mr Speaker, to the House: At the earliest possible time later this day I will be making a detailed statement in regard to this matter, which I am sure will meet the requirements of the honourable member.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the House?
—Yes, in the House.

—Can the Minister for Health advise the House whether in vitro fertilisation is currently covered under health benefit arrangements or will be covered under future health benefit arrangements envisaged for Medicare?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Stirling for his question. No, in vitro fertilisation is not covered under the present medical benefits schedule; nor in the first instance, I am afraid, will it be covered under the schedule covered by Medicare because it is our intention simply to apply the Medicare scheme to the existing range of medical benefits. I inform honourable members of that fact so that there may be no rumours on that topic. However, I do recognise the problems caused for individuals in relation to this exemption. The Government will be looking at those problems. Once Medicare is in place, this issue and a number of others will be examined.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr DAVID COMBE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In coming to his decision to bar a former friend and colleague from access to Ministers as a lobbyist, was the Prime Minister acting on information supplied by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation?

—I have made the assumption in the period I have been in this House that all members have the capacity to understand the Queen's English, put simply and straightforwardly. I would have thought that the answer I gave a moment ago to the honourable member for Moreton would have been capable of being understood by every member in the House, including the one who has just asked this question .

—I ask the Minister for Science and Technology whether it is a fact that science and technology will play a very critical role in this country's economic recovery. To this end, will he take steps to hold a conference of scientists, technologists and industrialists to evaluate their needs and to enable the Government to put in place policies that give both encouragement and support to all three groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for Hawker for his question. Science and technology is the greatest single factor in promoting high growth rates in modern economies. One of the major reasons for Australia's failure in the last seven years has been the sabotage by the people opposite of Australia's intellectual and research and development base. They failed to grasp the fundamental shift in the economy away from the resources based industries to high tech, brain based, high skilled industries. New high tech industries, such as microelectronics applications, are not just valuable in themselves; they provide essential forward and backward linkages with our existing industrial structures which must update and diversify if they are to meet murderous competition overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: To illustrate this point, I advise the House that a chart prepared by my Department-which I would be glad to table, or to incorporate in Hansard if you, Mr Speaker, would agree-indicates that, of 24 nations of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Australia ranks twenty-third, and a poor twenty-third at that, on two indices: The value of high technology exports, and the ratio of imports over exports. To maintain this position would be a recipe for disaster.

My Department and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation can be two powerful engines to assist national recovery, working closely with my colleague the Minister for Industry and Commerce and with other departments. I have instructed my Department and CSIRO to work closely in providing advice and assistance to existing industries and to assist in the development of new ones.

We are engaged in a continuous educational process, and the conference on sunrise industries at the Regent Hotel in Sydney on 31 May and 1 June is only one example of this. Another example is the meeting in Perth on 9 and 10 June of Commonwealth and State Ministers of industry and technology to discuss a range of related issues-the first such meeting. I shall also give serious consideration to holding a conference with representatives of industry, the professions, the universities and CSIRO to see how we can lift the national performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that the Minister has tabled the document. It is not in a form suitable for incorporation in Hansard.
—Yes, Mr Speaker.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Is the Government going to increase the number of sports at the Australian Institute of Sport by the inclusion of cycling and rowing, as announced by the previous Government? Also, is the Government going to decentralise hockey to Western Australia as part of the operations of the Australian Institute of Sport? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question because it gives me an opportunity to make a few observations on these comments. It is true that the previous Government, just prior to the election, made an announcement-I think it was made without too much knowledge aforethought, a sort of ad hoc announcement- about introducing two new sports to the Australian Institute of Sport and the decentralisation of hockey to Perth.

ANSWER.PARA: The incoming Government favours the movement of hockey to Perth, not the least of the reasons being that the new member for Perth, my colleague Dr Ric Charlesworth, is the captain of the Australian hockey team-I might say, the world champion Australian hockey team. Obviously we would be very delighted to have hockey stationed in Perth, where there is a facility available to cater properly for all the training and all the necessary side issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Provided by us.

—Provided by the taxpayers of Australia, as a contribution to Western Australia for its centenary. There is competition available in Perth, at world standard, for the Australian hockey experts who will be stationed there.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as extra sports for the AIS at present are concerned, we do not favour the movement into the AIS at present of cycling and rowing, for the very good reason that the AIS is in its infancy-I might say, a very buoyant and properous infancy-and we think the AIS should consolidate the sports that are already there.

There is need for accommodation to be provided at the AIS site for the athletes of varying ages who are now spread all around Canberra at campuses of universities and of colleges of advanced education, in private homes or in hostels. There is a need for them to be stationed on the campus. We think the better thing for the AIS to do at this stage is to consolidate what it has, to provide accommodation to make the system work more effectively and to look to the future for the inclusion of two new sports. We are in favour of expanding the number of sports at the AIS, and I would think cycling and rowing would be very high on our priority list.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. There have been reports that the Government is making efforts to reduce expenditure. Are these reports accurate? Why is this necessary now?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One can understand the discomfiture of people on the other side of the House when a penetrating question like that is addressed to me. During the election campaign the then Government led the people of Australia to believe that in the financial year 1983-84 we would be confronted as a nation with a deficit in the vincinity of $6 billion. I do not want to spend a great deal of time on the deception involved in that assertion at the time by our opponents because I think it is pretty indelibly etched on the minds of all Australians. But I do remind the House, in the context of the answer to this question, that as early as January there were indications publicly that the then Treasurer and the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition had reason to believe that the deficit for 1983-84 would be of the order of double the $4 billion that he knew it would be in 1982-83. Certain it is that on the Monday before the election he knew that the deficit would in fact be of the order of $9 billion and in discussions between him and the then Prime Minister the continued delusion was practised on the people of Australia in that election context.

ANSWER.PARA: We, when we came to office, were shocked to find that in fact what we were confronted with was a deficit in the order of $9.6 billion for 1983-84, not the $6 billion which quite deceptively and dishonestly the now Opposition had been touting around the country at that time. Of course, it was quite clear that that deception was part of a deliberate political tactic because, in the desperate attempt to retain office, what the previous Government had done in the Budget of 1982 was to make certain handouts and certain concessions, the full impact of which would in fact be hitting the Government in 1983-84. For example, the personal income tax cuts granted in the last Budget obviously will have their main effect in 1983-84. The accelerated depreciation for company purposes has a huge effect on the Budget for 1983-84.

In these circumstances we as a Government are not in any sense arguing that some of the concessions that were given at the time do not of themselves have some merit. We are not arguing that what was done at that time should simply be withdrawn because those things were part of a deliberate and massive deception, politically, upon the people of Australia. But the fact is that the vandalism of the previous Government on the finances of this country has imposed an obligation upon this Government. We will receive, in 1983-84, the impact of the vandalism and the dishonesty of the previous Government; but fortunately, intervening in that process, we also received, on 5 March, the mandate of the Australian people to direct our attention to that vandalism. In that sense, I have confidence in saying to this House that we will direct our attention to that vandalism and that deception that was practised on the people, and the actions which my Government will take, both in the May statement and in the Budget, will be directed to correcting that vandalism and setting this country on the path to sustainable economic recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the Prime Minister's answer to the question asked by the honourable member for Franklin, to which a blunt no was given and indicate to the Prime Minister that a similar question was asked of his Attorney-General in another place, to which that gentleman replied that the accountability of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation is a matter of active review and, to continue his words, will be the subject of an early review. Will the Prime Minister now outline the nature and timing of this review indicated by his Attorney-General?

—The Leader of the Opposition, in his desperation, should not allow his memory to stray so much as to forget what the question was that was addressed to me by the honourable member to whom he refers, the honourable member for Franklin. That question was put to me in terms of whether we had directed our attention to the suggestion that was made-as reported by the honourable member for Fry. I said no.
—You are going to fry him.

—I see; I mean the honourable member for Fraser. This is not a cook-up. Mr Speaker, I apologise to you and to the House for that slip-up. I wanted to indicate to the honourable member who asked the question and to the House that we had not directed our attention to that suggestion. Of course, in the context of our own election promise about the necessity for judicial audits of the security organisations-a commitment which I might say has been heightened by some recent events-at the appropriate time in the near future I will be making a detailed statement to the House as to our intention to ensure what has always been the intention of the Australian Labor Party and of this Government; that is , that the security of this country shall have the highest priority, and that in that context of ensuring that we take actions to maintain the security of this country we shall at the same time have the appropriate and necessary concern for the rights and civil liberties of Australian citizens.

—Can the Minister for Finance inform the House whether school parents and citizens associations and mothers clubs that are engaged primarily in raising funds for additional school equipment are exempt from the provisions of the bank account debits tax introduced by the Fraser Government which came into force on 1 April this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bank Account Debits Tax Bill was one of those pieces of Budget legislation which the former Government actually got around to putting through Parliament before the dissolution of the Parliament. It is for a very good reason that the tax has become known by its acronym. The Commissioner of Taxation informed me soon after the election that the administration of this tax was causing very substantial difficulties because of the drafting of the legislation. Whilst there are exemptions for benevolent institutions, religious institutions, schools and universities, some substantial problems arise. In the first instance, a religious institution which is primarily involved in commercial activities is, in the Commissioner's view, exempt from the provisions of this tax. However, a parents and citizens association which is primarily involved in raising money for a school is not exempt from the provisions of this tax. But if the tuck shop account run by a parents and citizens association is a school account then of course that account is exempt from the provisions of this law.

ANSWER.PARA: We are confronted with this administrative nightmare presented to us by our predecessors. We are in the process of trying to untangle the mess. At the time it was announced that this tax would proceed I indicated that there would be a review of the operation of the tax within six months to see whether the system of exemptions could be clarified. That review has already commenced and I indicate to parents and citizens bodies, which have been inundating the offices of honourable members, certainly those on this side of the House, that I am having examined ways in which exemptions might be provided for them. I indicate that under the provisions of the tax as introduced by the former Government, parents and citizens bodies are not exempted. That is causing considerable distress to organisations which are primarily involved in charitable purposes of a very honourable kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction: Is it a fact that a drastic shortage of housing exists in Australia? Is it further a fact that the Government has promised increased funding to assist in overcoming this shortage? Can the Minister say when government funds will be made available which will considerably assist housing and the employment situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I want to say how privileged I am to receive a question from one of that exclusive group, the back bench of the coalition parties. Even with the honourable member for Higgins and the honourable member for Murray having removed themselves from the front bench to the back bench, it is still much more exclusive to be on the back bench. It is a great privilege for me to receive a Dorothy Dix question from the honourable member for Paterson. Yes, it is true that there is an enormous shortage of housing in this country because of the terrible situation left to this Government by its predecessor. There is a shortage of something like 80,000 dwellings in comparision with the needs in this country. That does not take into consideration the increase that is required each year for new people coming into the category of those wanting homes, or indeed, the increase that is required because of the phasing out of old homes. It is an indictment of the seven years of monetarism that the situation has deteriorated to such a terrible extent.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member asked me what this Government is doing about it. One would not need to be an obsessive reader of the newspapers to know that this Government is getting on with its program to fulfil its promises in that area. I draw the attention of the honourable member not only to what took place at the National Economic Summit Conference but also to the answer I gave in this House as to what took place in a mini-housing summit on 28 April arising out of the Economic Summit.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —All these interjections and noises do not make up for the fact that it is an indictment of those sitting on the Opposition benches that they left this country in such a situation. I ask the honourable member to be patient another week or so until the May statement. An enormous amount of work is going on to make sure that that will comprise a comprehensive package which not only will ensure that there is an increase in housing commencements in this country- which have fallen to the abysmally low figure in the current year of 106,000, or 107,000 if we are lucky-but also will show that we are in the business of creating jobs through housing construction.
—Will the Prime Minister inform the House of the Government's view of the most recent developments in the Lebanon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate and recall the fact that, where I have previously had cause to direct the attention of the House to the position of the Government in this matter, it was obvious that what I had to say received the support of the Leader of the Opposition and I believe of the Opposition as a whole. I take this opportunity of recording again our appreciation of that. In the brief comments that I will make in respect of the honourable member for Kingston's question I believe that that same position will exist. The Government welcomes the indications that have now been made public of the agreement between Israel and Lebanon in respect of the possible withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon. As a government we give credit to the obvious hard and effective work that has been done in this respect by Secretary of State George Schultz. Obviously, we have some concern at the apparent rejection by the Government of Syria of the draft agreement and we hope that continuing work in that area will bring about a change in that attitude. The basic point of concern which we must repeat is that the continuing division of the country of Lebanon is something which is tragic and which all nations of good will should work towards bringing to an end.

ANSWER.PARA: That capacity to eliminate the tragedy which is Lebanon can be achieved only in circumstances where all foreign forces-the forces of Israel, Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organisation-are withdrawn from Lebanon. In this context, we are concerned at the indications of some growth in tension between Syria and Israel. We hope that the good offices of those concerned in working in this area will be directed towards lessening such tension which could, if it grows, have such tragic consequences. I complete my observations to the honourable member and the House by saying that these matters of which we speak are further proof of the fact that we can have peace in this area and an ending to the tragedy in Lebanon in particular only when arrangements are arrived at which guarantee the integrity and the security of all states in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. It relates to the answer which he has just given concerning the withdrawal of all foreign forces from the Lebanon. Given the fact that Kampuchea is occupied by a foreign force, namely, Vietnam, and that in this country and in this capital right now is a representative of a group and a leader and former Prime Minister of Kampuchea, namely, Mr Son Sann, and that under any reading of public international law on the question of recognition there can be discussion between individuals, regimes and states without recognition being connoted if a government indicates that there is no recognition, why will the Government not discuss matters with Mr Son Sann?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I deplore the attempt by the Leader of the Opposition regarding a matter about which I know he is deeply concerned-that is, the achievement of peace in the region of Indo-China-to make some capital out of a suggestion that we are not acting in a way calculated to help to achieve that objective by not meeting with Mr Son Sann. Let me make it quite clear what the position of the Government is in this regard. It is a position which I might say has been very effectively conveyed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, who has, in his brief occupancy of that position, displayed a determination to work as hard as he possibly can on behalf of this Government to achieve positive results in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me quickly say to the Leader of the Opposition what our position is. Our position is that the occupation of Kampuchea by the troops of Vietnam is not something which can continue. We will be using all our best endeavours to try to secure a position where that is brought to an end. Clearly, the twin conditions of achieving a proper resolution of the problem in this area are that there be a withdrawal of the forces of Vietnam from Kampuchea and, associated with that, that there be the creation of a condition where the forces of Pol Pot are not able, in a condition of the withdrawal of the forces of Vietnam, to impose by force upon the people of Kampuchea a situation in which the people of Kampuchea are not able, in a free act of will, to determine what sort of government they want.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.

—I am glad to see the indication from both the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs of their agreement with that. In an acceptance of our belief that the achievement of those twin conditions is necessary for what I perceive to be the common objectives of both sides of this Parliament, I, the Foreign Minister and this Government will be, with the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, China and the United States of America and later in discussions that we will be having with the Government of Vietnam, attempting to use what power and capacities we have, with a due recognition of our place in the world and the limits to what we can do, and will be seeking to do what we can, to achieve those results. I conclude, having stated the Government's general position on this, by informing the Leader of the Opposition that the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Lionel Bowen, will be seeing Mr Son Sann this afternoon.

—I ask the Minister for Transport: Given the serious impact of the current economic recession upon the interstate trucking industry, as demonstrated by the increasing number of bankruptcies and the rate of involvement of heavy vehicles in road crashes, will the Minister inform the House of the current position with respect to its promised inquiry into the road freight industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue referred to by the honourable member in his question is a serious one. It is a fact that an increasing number of heavy road vehicles are involved in fatal road crashes. That is not to say that this is the responsibility of the road transport industry. It is also a fact that economic pressures on the industry have increased significantly, particularly as a result of the incompetence and the mismanagement over the last seven years of those opposite, who sought to represent small businessmen. A vast number of small businessmen in the road transport industry have suffered and have gone into bankruptcy because of the ignorance of those who now sit opposite.
—What about retreading?

—That was the previous Government's proposal, not ours. The fact is that the national road freight inquiry that we proposed during the election campaign will provide for the first time on a national basis a comprehensive examination of the road transport industry. The States have indicated that, despite their partial inquiries on occasions, they do not have the capacity to look at all the problems involved.

ANSWER.PARA: What we propose to do through the inquiry is to examine the economy and the efficiency of the industry, the impact of regulation on the industry, the effect of existing truck financing practices, the effect of competition from rail on the industry and the need for a national research program relating to the road freight sector.

It is our expectation that the inquiry will invite submissions from all interested groups within the industry so that everybody who has a concern will have an opportunity to put a point of view. The matter has been actively pursued by the Government since it came to office. The Prime Minister has recently written to each of the Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory inviting their co-operation and support in the inquiry. We hope that that co- operation and support will be forthcoming.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aviation. Are airlines using Sydney Airport incurring losses caused by traffic congestion and traffic delays at the airport? If so: Firstly, what is the current annual rate of those losses? Secondly, what decisions has his Government made-I emphasise the words ' decisions' and 'his Government'-to eliminate the causes of those losses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should preface my answer to the honourable member's question by pointing out one or two things about the parallel runway to which he indirectly alluded. Any losses that are being suffered by airlines at the moment at Sydney Airport and which may have been removed by the construction of that runway-and that would be a debatable point-would not be removed for a period of at least eight to 10 years. We have a problem here and now that we happen to be dealing with, and that problem has several solutions. I will provide to the honourable gentleman a little later information in respect of those losses. I do not have the information immediately to hand, but I do concede that there are losses involved.

ANSWER.PARA: The previous Government set in train a process of ground movement procedures which I think were excellent ones and which we are pursuing. They will require construction work during this year, both in terms of taxiways and in terms of the implementation of a ground-surveillance radar system. We will be pursuing those matters. We estimate that with the new procedures set in train by the previous Government there will be an improvement in the realm of 8 per cent in air traffic movements.

In addition, the Government is considering what additional fast taxiways might be provided, what additional air traffic control procedures might well be implemented and what other developments might take place at the airport, designed specifically to achieve savings to the airlines and to deal with the problem to which the honourable member makes reference.

But, overall, it is my belief that there will be no real solution of the problem at Sydney that will be of a decent, long term character, that will meet the needs of Sydney as the preferred entry point to Australia of most international travellers, that will meet the needs of New South Wales country regions for people to get into the city on a regular and reasonable basis, and that will meet the operational requirements of the major domestic airlines of Australia, until a second airport is constructed, and properly operating, at a reasonable distance from the city.

I do not believe that the previous Government came to any other conclusion. I note that in a letter which the honourable member wrote recently to the Sydney Morning Herald he expressed support for the view that a second airport site should be acquired, and I agree wholeheartedly. I assume that he arrived at that judgment for the reasons I have outlined in answering him today. I notice that my predecessor as Minister for Aviation also came to the same conclusion. That is evidenced by the material he put down when he announced his intention to proceed with a closely spaced parallel runway. It is very necessary that we arrive at that decision as soon as we possibly can. It is one that will be fraught with considerable political difficulties. Nevertheless I believe that overall, in the interests of the country and of the people of New South Wales--

TALK.START.PARA: —Boring!
—I am dedicating this answer to the memory of Reg Swartz and the honourable member ought to look upon it with respect--
—Order! The House has been doing very well in regard to the number of questions asked and answered and I request the Minister to co-operate.

—There will be no solution of the problems of the people of New South Wales and in regard to the very important services that Sydney performs as the major entry point to Australia until we have a second airport. In achieving that objective, the Government will be grateful for all the support it can get from the Opposition.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Science and Technology, relates to an answer given by him earlier this day in which he stated that Australia's rate of technological advance had fallen during the period of office of the previous Government. I ask: Was this related to declining levels of Government support for research and development during that period? What other policies of the previous Government contributed to the decline? What new areas could be explored by Australian industry to give Australia a chance to recover the lost ground?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The level of government investment in research and development neither rose nor fell dramatically, at a time when the rest of the technologically advanced world was moving forward very rapidly. For example, Canada has doubled its investment in research and development over a five-year period. It is President Mitterrand's intention to double France's investment over a seven-year period. Therefore, to stand still amounts to regression compared with the rest of the world. The Government hopes to promote the 16 ' sunrise' industries that we identified during the election campaign. We believe that this is an area, in conjunction and association with existing industries, with both forward and backward linkages, which can help move Australian industry in the right direction.

ANSWER.PARA: By a strange coincidence, not having anticipated the question, I happen to have with me a piece of an extraordinarily interesting substance called partially stabilised zirconium, or PSZ, produced by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. It will bring about a revolution in the automotive industry. Engines that are constructed of PSZ rather than metal alloys have an increase in fuel efficiency of from 38 per cent to 56 per cent. That order of magnitude of increase in fuel efficiency is so great that it cannot be resisted, I would think, by any future motor manufacturing enterprise throughout the world. The CSIRO estimates that the value of this product may well be, by the year 1990, of the order of $2 billion per annum. This is an example of one of the 16 'sunrise' industries that are so essential for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 19 of the Weights and Measures (National Standards) Act 1960, I present the National Standards Commission annual report 1981-82.
—For the information of honourable members, I present the Science and Industry Endowment Fund statement of income and expenditure and balance sheet for 1981-82.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—Yesterday in the House the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), in referring to me, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I can tell him that no one was subsidised more than he was with 70,000 bucks for a car to run around in for eight months--

Then he corrected it to '$70,000 for Commonwealth cars'. Outside the House, I told the Minister that I rejected his allegation. I am now reliably informed that the Minister's statement that no one was subsidised more than I was is untrue. I am further informed that it is believed that the former Leader of the Opposition for one had a much higher account for Commonwealth cars than I ever had. I reject the smear made upon me by the Special Minister of State and suggest that he was not merely attacking me but also was attacking the former Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The Minister may proceed.

—Yesterday, as a result of an interjection made while I was speaking, I told the honourable member for Denison that he should not complain too much about Government subsidies, seeing that the taxpayers of Australia had to fork out $70,000 for his car transport costs over a period of eight months. I did not take it any further and I did not intend to. I was just drawing his attention to the fact when he was talking about government subsidies. He asked me outside the chamber to give him details because he did not accept what I had said. I now have the details if the honourable member would like them. If he asks me a question in the House tomorrow, I will give him every line of the details of his car costs from 1 July last year until the date of the election this year, where the cars were, how they were costed against him and how much he cost the Australian taxpayer.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the House of the result of my investigations into reports of improper behaviour at the Royal Military College, Duntroon. Honourable members will be aware that following newspaper articles in April, I called for a report from the Commandant of RMC and for other relevant information. I subsequently made the Commandant's report public, noting that inquiries into allegations of improper conduct had been made and were continuing. The Chief of the General Staff has now passed on to me a further report by the Commandant. As a result of the Commandant's more recent investigations, a number of steps have been taken to improve behaviour, with particular emphasis on supervision of mess procedures, non-interruption to study and sleeping time, and on the principle that assimilation and induction training at RMC are to reflect approved practices throughout the Army. Also as a result of the Commandant's investigations, a number of charges were made and a number of cadets were subjected to disciplinary action. Among these, five cadets were recommended for expulsion from the college.

SPEECH.PARA: In the light of all the evidence available to me, I have decided not to endorse the recommendations for expulsion but have asked the Commandant to substitute a lesser punishment. I have done this because I believe that the number of substantiated incidents of improper behaviour have not been isolated cases but rather have been reflections of a wider pattern of conduct which has apparently become accepted as customary. I do not in any way condone such behaviour. In these circumstances it is not appropriate that the severe punishment of expulsion should apply to a limited number of cadets.

Let me emphasise that in no way am I suggesting that the Commandent has acted unreasonably in recommending expulsions. I am quite satisfied that he is determined to ensure that this type of behaviour does not continue, that he has examined all the allegations thoroughly, and that where hard evidence has been available he has taken vigorous action to punish the offenders. I note that the Commandant has taken speedy action to improve some procedures and I have asked the Chief of the General Staff to prepare a comprehensive report for me on the detailed steps that have been and will be taken to ensure that policies on behaviour are not only clearly understood but also vigorously implemented. To this end, I have asked that he give particular attention to the degree of supervision given to the cadets by the college staff. The Chief of the General Staff Advisory Committee is meeting today on this matter. I table for the information of honourable members a copy of the Commandant's final report, other than sections which reveal names of individuals, and a copy of my minute to the Chief of the General Staff which I personally gave to the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There is no doubt that all of us are concerned about the maintenance of proper standards of behaviour at the Royal Military College, Duntroon and, indeed, in every other training establishment around Australia whether it is the Australian Army, any of the other Services or , any other area. The question mark that has hung over the head of Duntroon since the assertions were first made in the Age is to be regretted. I think it is particularly regrettable that we now have a comment from the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) which, in paragraph 11 of his minute of 10 May 1983 to the Chief of the General Staff, states:

SPEECH.PARA: As you know, I asked the Age for further detailed information of specific allegations, and I note that such allegations as have been given to me orally cannot be substantiated by factual evidence.

I do not believe it is satisfactory for anybody if assertions are made which cannot then be backed up. I think we all should regret that a newspaper like the Age should see fit to sensationalise allegations in what are very serious matters for the cadets concerned. There is certainly an obligation on senior cadets and junior cadets to maintain the standards of discipline set for the college. One hopes that, as a result of the changes in procedures which Major- General Coates, the Commandant of the College, has advised the Chief of the General Staff, these past practices will be obviated.

I commend the Minister too for not expelling the five cadets concerned. Honourable members on this side of the House were most concerned that it seemed for a while that these boys might well be the scapegoats for events that should not have taken place but apparently were alleged to have taken place within the college. The fact that they had already passed their initial year's training and some of them were more advanced in the college course meant that they had obviously passed through that early and rigorous selection process. They had passed their exams and now their whole future was to have been blighted, because of allegations made apparently by youngsters who had not met the same standards and who apparently had left the college. I think it is important that individuals not be selected in such a way as to prejudice their careers, and I believe the Minister has acted quite properly in this instance.

As I mentioned a while ago, the Minister has identified the steps that are to be taken by the College Commandant. They are set down in one of the documents that he has tabled in the House; that is, in the final report of the College Commandant of the CGS, dated 22 April 1983. On reading through those steps, I think there are a number of important elements in them which do seem to accommodate the difficulties that have previously taken place at Duntroon. I think it is important that these standards also be taken in mind by the preliminary council of the Australian Defence Force Academy, ADFA. As honourable members will know, the future training of officer cadets in Australia will go through significant changes when the Australian Defence Force Academy is established. One would hope that the same allegations about discipline at Duntroon will not be made there. I hope that each of the military colleges will take note of the experience in this case and take note also of the advice of the Minister and similarly conform with the procedures and practices that have been laid down. In his statement, the Minister comments:

. . . the Chief of the General Staff to prepare a comprehensive report . . . on the detailed steps that have been and will be taken to ensure that policies on behaviour are not only clearly understood but are also vigorously implemented.

When the Minister receives that report, I ask that he table it also in the Parliament so that honourable members in this place may observe those changes that have taken place: The matter of the status of Duntroon can thereby be maintained. However, I think it is important that the community at large recognises that Duntroon over the years has established a very high reputation both for itself and for its graduates. It is a very excellent military training college whose standing is high not only this country but also in those Asian and other countries whose students participate in its courses and also with those people who have come to exchange points of view in their particular professional discipline with those graduates of Duntroon. It is important that those standards be maintained. The Opposition certainly supports any efforts by the Minister and the Government which will ensure that that will be so.
Sitting suspended from 12.58 to 2.15 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, the Appropriation Bill (No. 6) 1982-83 and the Appropriation (Parliament Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1982-83.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Question Time I was referring to the balance of payments figures that were released yesterday, which continue to show a deteriorating position within the competitive structure of Australia and the deterioriation that has taken place, in a very real way, in our export performance and indeed, in particular, in terms of the capital flow of this country. I particularly wanted to highlight that, to bring us back to one of the basic problems facing Australia-the question of wages and the payments beyond wages. It is quite clear that the rapid increase in wages costs in 1981 was at the expense of the competitiveness of Australian industry. Because of that, we are seeing today that large areas are simply just not competitive.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate of recent weeks has been a call by the Government for wage restraint . At the same time, there have been people working away at the edges, the on site allowances, little give-ups here and give-ups there, which are eroding the confidence of the business community in the Government's ability to maintain a restraint in this area. But it is not only that to which I draw the attention of the House but also to the true cost of labour, which is a very important ingredient. The concentration of the debate upon direct wage costs would not have been significantly misleading if total labour costs had been growing in a fixed proportion to direct wage costs.
