But as the details of the survey by the Australian Industries Development Association show, it has not been the case, and in fact wage cost movements are a biased underestimate of the actual movements or the total cost of employing labour in Australia. The survey produced by AIDA goes on to show that the add-on costs grew from 33 per cent in 1974 to 39 per cent in 1981, and in the one dramatic year, 1982, they grew to 43 per cent. It is not hard to extend those figures and to assume that by the late 1980s the add-on cost to labour in terms of these other items will certainly be 50 per cent.

For the direct interest of the House, it is worth detailing the percentage increases that have occurred, because while wage, as a direct cost, has increased from 1974 to 1981 by a factor of $3.60 an hour to $8.80 an hour, the add-on costs have increased from $1 to just short of $4 an hour. These additional costs come in the form of annual leave, annual leave loading, public holidays, long service leave, sick leave, compassionate leave, other paid work absences and benefits, allowances, non-productive paid time, superannuation, workers' compensation, insurance, payroll tax, employee amenities, employee health, uniforms, safety and other add-on costs. Many of those costs are, of course, recognised by industry as being important to the job. But in discussions on labour costs, I find that far too often no concern is given to this huge area of add-on to the overall cost structure of business.

This has been particularly so, in the last few years, of the rapid growth in superannuation, which is one of the high growth areas in this add-on cost. In addition to that, there has been considerable growth in the cover of employees for health costs. On top of that, there has been a considerable increase, according to these figures, in the area of payroll tax which, of course, is the area that State governments took over from the Federal Government some years ago and they have consistently used it as a very substantial income earner for the State government treasuries.

In drawing the attention of the House to this matter, I think it is quite evident that the debate that has so far been taking place on the wages question has been misinterpreted to the extent of these additional costs. When statistics are produced in future, I hope that they will relate not just to the direct cost but to the add-ons that occur. Unless we are prepared to accept these points, not only in terms of the loading for holiday pay and for the discrimination in terms of employment such as weekend penalty rates and the like, it is not likely that many of the service industries in Australia will be able to get out and match the competition from overseas and the requirements that will be made by visitors to this land. With those comments, I indicate that the Opposition will not be opposing the Appropriation Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bills (No. 5) and (No. 6), which we are debating, provide for Additional Estimates arising out of cost and price increases since the August 1982 Budget. Additional appropriation is necessary to cover these increases. Insofar as the original appropriations were initiated and sanctioned by the present Opposition, I feel that it is, therefore, appropriate that Opposition speakers should support the thrust of the Bills, given that the cost increases in many cases have been a result of the previous Government's disastrous anti-inflation policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet how much support for national recovery have we seen from the Opposition to date? I am afraid that in sum total it really results in obstructionism, which was seen at the Constitutional Convention in Adelaide, when conservative governments stacked that meeting to turn what should have been an objective forum into another party political hothouse of mud slinging and intrigue, and it has been carried on in this House as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has attacked the constructive things that this Government has been trying to do. I am concerned-but I hope that it is not so-that the Opposition may not want recovery, because recovery would show that this Government is a competent economic manager and can deliver the goods, while the previous Government could not or would not do so.

To return to the Bill, as I previously mentioned, a significant proportion of the appropriations required arises out of cost increases experienced in Commonwealth Government departments. In turn, many of these cost increases have arisen out of increases in staff ceilings. One of the major increases in this area has been in the Department of Social Security, to allow the Department better to cope with the flood of unemployed people over the last 12 months. This has been a direct result of the previous Government's economic policies, and the horrendous effect of those policies can now be seen queuing up outside welfare agencies around Australia.

Amazingly, the Opposition now says that we, as a government, should be doing something about unemployment. As the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) , the Treasurer, so cogently put it this week, it is a pity that Opposition members have not been crying those crocodile tears for the unemployed over the past seven years. In February 1976, 5.4 per cent of the work force was unemployed. By February 1983 the figure had grown to 10.7 per cent. The National Economic Summit Conference was the first attempt by a government to come to grips with the communication problem between governments and the people for whom they are legislating. As such, it should be applauded not only by the business and consumer community but also by the Opposition, which after all is part of the Parliament which has been elected to represent the people. As the representatives of the housing industry pointed out, the recently convened meeting of the industry attended by the Minister for Housing and Construction ( Mr Hurford), the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) was another example of reporting to the people affected by legislation before that legislation is enacted.

The labour intensive construction of houses forms an integral part of the reconstruction of human lives which we are undertaking in Australia. While we in the Australian Labor Party have certainly worn the tag of the compassionate and sometimes do-gooders who wear our hearts on our sleeves, it is a fact, not widely recognised but nonetheless true, that we who have come to office from the ranks of the less privileged have a strong streak of practicality born of experience. This practicality is reflected in policies and attitudes towards social problems.

Nowhere is this more apparent than in policies to combat unemployment. In vivid contrast to the non-policies of the Liberal and National parties, which parties point-blank refused to consider job creation schemes in the face of unemployment of dimensions unknown since the Depression of the 1930s, Labor thinking suggests that while long term policies dealing with the impact of a new technology are essential it is not only compassionate but also good sense to ensure that in the short term jobs are created. In similar practical fashion, we as a government will base our job creation on construction projects which will also go a long way towards alleviating the accommodation problem of thousands of unlucky Australians, given that we will have to phase in the programs which we wish to pursue, owing to the size of the deficit which we inherited.

We will meet this priority and this will not only meet the prime objective of any healthy society, and that is that every last person in the society should have a decent standard of living, but will also give added spending power and stimulate, and inject hope into, a depressed business and consumer community. Our Government has opened the lines of communication with that community. It is the only reasonable way to run a country. The only surprising aspect is that such meetings and communication between governments and business and community groups have not taken place before. It does not surprise me that a green-eyed Opposition Leader subjects us to a tantrum on the success of the Government's operation in public relations, but it saddens me and I ask, in the name of the people who elected both the Government and the Opposition to represent them, that he exercise a little restraint. I now look forward to a further outreach into the community by a government committed to meeting the needs of that community.

The previous Government's reaction was to suppress publication of figures on unemployment. I hark back to the actions of the previous Government, because it is so important to the success of our policies that the community realise just what has been done in the name of party politics by the Opposition. As the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) pointed out yesterday, one of his first steps upon reaching office was to order a collection of the figures on the unemployed on a regional basis. The collection on 17 March showed a total of 822,000 Australians officially without a job. The Government will reinstate the collection and publication of these figures. We do so in the belief that before a problem can be rectified it must first be recognised.

This is a major reason for the failure of the previous Government to come to grips with the burgeoning economic and therefore social problems in Australia. It typifies the vast gap separating the Liberal-National Party and Labor policy. It is the reason why Australians turned to the Labor Party and it is the reason why Australia now, under new leadership, is turning its face in a new direction, away from the frightening sterile landscape of recession to the hope of revival born of long-sighted planning and compassionate administration.

I turn now to one facet of the appropriations now under discussion which is a statistical reflection of the human face of poverty which is now, regrettably, a part of Australia. A sum of $2m is sought to supplement grants administered by the Department of Social Security for community welfare agencies. This supplementation is necessary because of the great burden on welfare agencies due to an unprecedented influx in the number of people seeking relief from poverty. Who are these people who are forced to go to charity for the first time in their lives in order to feed their families? They are the three million people who, according to the Australian Council of Social Service figures, are now living below the poverty line. In 1978 a joint government study with ACOSS regarding emergency relief proved that up to 90 per cent of those people on relief were social security beneficiaries. Many of those people are on the unemployment benefit.

But let us not get emotional about the situation. We will talk of facts and figures. Over the past 12 months, welfare agencies such as Life Line, the St Vincent de Paul Society and the Salvation Army have been unable to meet the requirements of thousands of people who have never gone to charity before but who are now going not just for clothing and shelter, but for food, for the very necessities of life. A typical picture is a family whose income earner has been retrenched. Whether he is paying rent, which could be $50 to $100 per week in Brisbane, or whether he is meeting large payments on his house, housing takes such a lump out of the amount he gets in unemployment benefit that it is not surprising that he cannot make ends meet. This is a reality. In Brisbane alone over 200,000 people live below the poverty line.

The way in which this has affected welfare agencies has become obvious. Twelve months ago Life Line was distributing food parcels worth $65 for emergency cases . Because of the number of people who are now coming for relief, it has had to cut the value of those parcels back to $25. It gives out food parcels worth $10, $15 and $25 at a time when the dollar does not go as far. St Vincent de Paul in Brisbane alone is expending $2,000 a day on food. These people do not come for the secondary necessities of clothing and shelter but for the urgent requirement of food. A profile of people in Brisbane and across Australia who now do not have enough money to buy food for their families is instanced in an article from the Brisbane Telegraph of last night. The article, headed 'Baked beans on the dole' states:

Putting the car up for sale because you cannot afford to register it, coming home to share baked beans on toast with your pregnant wife and three children- this is the life of the unemployed family man in Brisbane.
Ian last enjoyed a full-time job 10 months ago. He is a professional fisherman, jack-of-all-trades, and had 'people knocking on the door' with offers of work.
His wife, Sandra, who is expecting their fourth child in October, said: 'You really take that pay-packet for granted, when it comes in regularly.'
They will never take it for granted again.
Their fortnightly $297.60 dole cheque is usually accounted for before it arrives. Sometimes, bills account for two cheques at a time.
It was this which brought Ian and Sandra and their children, aged 6 years, 3, and seven months, to Life Line.
For the first time, they had to ask for outside help.
'We're able to get clothes from second-hand shops, but even their prices are going up. So is milk and electricity,' said Sandra.
'It was Ian's birthday last week and there wasn't enough petrol in the car to take it for a drive. It was a quiet birthday.'

That picture is not something out of a Victorian novel. That is what is happening in Australia today. It is all very well to have an influx of facts and figures-and they are necessary-but until this House comes to grips with the problem that gives rise to the facts and figures it will be impossible to get Australia back on the road to recovery. That is the difference between the last Government and this one. Before a problem can be cured it must be recognised and its dimensions must be recognised. We sat here for seven years and saw those dimensions go unrecognised. It was very bad to hear then Government members say that there were no huge unemployment figures. They did not recognise the fact of unemployment, and that is on record.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense. That is absolute rubbish.

—That is on the record. Is it rubbish that the Budget figures announced last year were shonky? Is it just in my imagination that the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), said at the time of the Budget being announced that less than 400,000 people, in total, would be unemployed by June of 1983 and that at the time he said it the figure had already gone over the 400,000 mark? What about the deficit? Is it in my imagination that the deficit was known before the election and that it was deceitfully hidden? Do I imagine that the problem was met by stopping the publication of figures on the number of unemployed? These are the facts and to giggle inanely does not help those people who are paying a packet for us to be here in this House to put forward policies for them. I am now part of a Government that is taking up that challenge and which will have to run right across the stupid party politicking which is thrown up in an effort to stop us carrying out the policies which we promised and which we will put into practice.

SPEECH.PARA: Poverty is the bitter harvest of Fraser policies. After the 1977 election the Fraser Government froze pensions, cutting out indexation for the May quarter. It cut funeral benefits in the same way. There was one story before the election and another after. That Government knew what the deficit would be; it ran up the deficit, which in plain words is just a debt which we will have to meet, in order to carry out election promises. In 1983 it made election promises that it knew it would have to break, being aware of the amount involved. This Government will phase in social reform which will render emergency relief a thing of the past as need is relieved. We are aware that these appropriations are filling needs in a band-aid way. We would rather that every Australian was on a decent income and did not have to resort to emergency relief. No family wants to live on charity; it is the intention of this Government that in Australia families will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before addressing some remarks to an item in Appropriation Bill (No. 6), by way of a short reply to what has been said by the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), I say this: When it comes to playing partisan politics, the Australian Labor Party has always been streets ahead of the Liberal Party or the National Party. It is that partisan and ideologically committed attitude that members of the Labor Party bring to all questions which gets them into the kinds of holes that they are presently digging for themselves .

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me directly to the question of the funding which has been announced of $175m for Qantas Airways Ltd and Trans Australia Airlines. In the two months since the Labor Government has been in power it has made three major decisions in the field of aviation. First of all, it cancelled the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. That was an irresponsible decision made solely in the interests of Labor's electoral prospects. I will be glad if the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) will table any advisings or minutes he has on the subject so that we can see what his Department's views on that question are. The decision had nothing to do with long term planning, the interests or convenience of the travelling public, with Sydney or Sydney's future as the gateway to Australia, or with the efficient operation of airlines. If we were to remain under Labor, which we will not, Sydney would be committed to stumbling along past the year 2000 with two increasingly overburdened runways.

The second decision made by the Government was that TAA was to remain a government-owned company. I stress the words 'government-owned' because it is nonsense to speak of the public owning TAA. Of course that decision was no more than a knee-jerk reaction to Labor's blind adherence to a nineteenth century ideology. Thirdly, we have the injection by Appropriation Bill (No. 6) when it becomes an Act of $175m into Qantas and TAA-$115m into TAA, the previous Minister having authorised $25m, and $60m into Qantas. These are huge capital injections which have been made, on what has been stated by the Minister-we have to judge these matters on what the Minister says-without any sense of purpose or direction. It is the spend now and think later school of government.

In order to understand the implications of those decisions it is necessary to look at the financial background and some of the figures relating to those two companies. Let me start with Qantas. In doing so, I acknowledge that Qantas has experienced real difficulties by reason of the competition in international airlines and by reason of the well-known depressed world trading conditions. What do the figures say? During the 1980-81 and 1981-82 financial years Qantas lost a total of $75m in airline operations. The Minister's recent Press statement indicates that preliminary figures for 1982-83 show an operating loss for that year of $45m. This totals a loss over four years of $140m. Qantas, understandably enough, paid no dividend over the 1980, 1981 and 1982 financial years and its results have been made worse by exchange losses in those years amounting to $17m. It is well known that it has been forced to take action to cut costs and to realise assets. It sold the Wentworth Hotel and realised a profit on the sale of that asset of around $62m. However, Qantas's malaise is not due solely to international conditions, to harsh competition or to the world recession. In Qantas's 1981-82 annual report, the Chairman says:

Our competitive position continues to be placed under extreme pressure from demands in Australia for higher wages and lower productivity-demands which do not occur to the same degree in countries of competing airlines.

It is the old story: We are living beyond our means and Qantas has suffered as a result of that. Will this kind of financial trend in Qantas's profitability continue? It seems almost inevitable on what we know thus far. The recent devaluation of the Australian dollar can, it would seem, only make things worse. Let me once again quote from what the Chairman had to say in his report to the Minister:

The relationship between the Australian dollar and Qantas' foreign trading currencies has a major effect on the Company's results. The recent depreciation of the Australian dollar against the US dollar has resulted in increased costs, expressed in Australian dollars, for fuel and materials-

One can only assume that those increased costs will continue. To sum up, the reasons why it would seem Qantas will continue to lose money and why this ominous financial trend will continue are these: The figures for operating losses which the Minister has indicated will be very high for this financial year; fuel costs; probable industrial unrest; exchange losses caused by devaluation; and, presumably, continued exchange losses as a result of commitments made by Qantas in the past. So unless there is a dramatic turnabout in Qantas's fortunes, it will need more money.

What about Trans Australia Airlines? We do not have the 1981-82 results for that company and the Minister in his statement of 3 May referred to a small operating loss. We do not really know how it is doing although reportedly it is running at a heavy loss. We know that it has a guaranteed share of the Australian market, unlike Qantas which must compete internationally. We do know from the Australian Financial Review of 4 May that two of its five airbuses are on the market, which is hardly a sign of confidence or of ready cash. We can only suspect that TAA is running at a very heavy loss. These matters will be known to the Minister. It would be good to hear from him what is the position of TAA. Thus far he has not bothered to inform the public of that position.

Where does this leave us? This leaves us with some questions and some issues of fundamental importance. First, have management decisions, particularly management decisions in TAA, contributed to the need for the major injection of funds-that is the injection of $175m of which only $25m had been authorised by the previous Minister? Secondly, when the Government made the decision to inject these vast sums into Qantas and TAA, did it call for forecasts or cash flow statements from Qantas and TAA? Surely it must have. What did those forecasts show about profitability? The Minister seems to have some confidence about Qantas returning to profitability. In a recent interview on PM on 3 May he expressed confidence, or the hope, that these organisations would return to profitable trading. He must have had some basis for expressing that hope or for that expression of confidence, and it is about time he took the Australian people into his confidence so that we know on what basis the decision was made, so that we know what the forecasts are and so that we know the good news if there is any good news or, more probably, the bad news.

The next question that we would like answered is: What projections does TAA make for its getting a larger share of the Australian market? That would be highly relevant whether or not it is to become profitable. Is there such a projection? If so, the Minister should tell us. Next, what benefits will the fare paying public get from this vast injection of capital which runs at about $ 11 to $12 per man, woman and child in this country? Will we have cheaper fares? If so, will the Minister tell us when and how? The ministerial news release refers to reduction of the costs of these airlines. Surely the reduction in the cost of these airlines should be reflected in some way which will benefit the Australian public. What are the initiatives which had not been possible under the previous Government and which the Minister referred to in his media release of 3 May? What are the details of these initiatives? When will they be put into effect? Is this just a vague, general pious statement made in hope of future improvements in the operation of TAA?

What return on investment does the Minister expect? This is a question of fundamental importance. The Minister has spoken learnedly about debt equity ratio, no doubt keeping very clearly in mind the difference between long term debt and short term debt. He criticised the former Minister, who certainly knew a great deal more about the industry than this Government demonstrates that it knows. The Minister must know what return on the injected funds the Government expects. The Minister would have us believe that it was a commercial decision. He is quoted in the Australian Financial Review as saying that this was the shareholders' response. He said on PM that it was a shareholders commercial injection of funds. If that is so, the fundamental point is that one expects a return on the injected funds. Whether it is provided by way of lent working capital or by way of paid up capital, one looks for a return. What return does the Minister look for? Is it one per cent, 2 per cent, 3 per cent or 4 per cent? What projections have been given? What do we know about these companies?

The handling of these decisions by the Government and by the Minister, and what they said about the reasons for the decisions, demonstrates that the Government does not know why it made the decisions in the first place to inject $175m into these two companies. I quote from the news release of the Minister of 3 May in which he said:

This is not in any way a handout to cover losses or projected losses that the airlines have incurred or might incur. It is an essential measure designed to make the airlines more competitive, to reduce their costs and to help keep air fares down.

Does he seriously make that statement in view of the Qantas figures? Does he seriously suggest that the $60m which is to be injected into Qantas would have been needed but for the losses which have been incurred by that company over the last four years? If he did believe that on 3 May he appears to have forgotten within 24 hours what he said on that day, because in the Australian Financial Review of the following day he is reported as saying that he had granted the $ 60m to Qantas as a salve for immediate problems. It cannot be both a salve for immediate problems and an essential measure designed to make the airlines more competitive. It is either a handout or it is a commercial injection of funds, the shareholders' response.

On the subject of the shareholders' response the Minister is reported in the Australian Financial Review of 4 May as saying that the funds were injected as a shareholders' response to an extraordinarily difficult market. That is apparently not a handout. In making that statement, he seems to have misunderstood the role that shareholders play. Shareholders in private companies have the right to quit their investments and to sell up. They have the right not to inject capital into ailing companies. In short, they make a business a commercial decision. Who consulted the shareholders? What purposes do the shareholders, the great Australian taxpaying public, serve? They serve one purpose and one purpose alone, and that is to provide money.

What cost cutting measures has the Minister examined? What cost cutting measures have these companies put to him? What specific initiatives are proposed to increase the efficiency of these companies? All these questions are left un- answered. All we know is that Qantas and TAA-Qantas most certainly-are faring badly. We do know that $175m has been injected into these companies. We do know that Qantas's present position is bad and its position in the future is likely to be equally as bad for some time, recalling that it is losing about $45m in this financial year. We are left, therefore, with some bland and empty generalisations about the reasons for the injection of funds. In the case of Qantas, we are left with a contradiction between a salve for immediate problems- if the Minister was correctly reported-and, on the other hand, a shareholder's response. It is most certainly a salve and it is most certainly not a shareholder's response.

When one comes to the end of the day, the major kinds of questions that the Australian public needs to have answered are these: Firstly, what kind of structure is proposed for these companies in the future? Secondly, what are the Government's policy objectives for TAA and Qantas? Thirdly, are they to be free to manage their affairs on sound commercial principles? Fourthly, if they are to be free to manage their affairs on sound commercial principles, are they to face the sanctions of failure in the market-place or is the Australian taxpayer, that shareholder who cannot quit, to be called on again in the future? If one looks to the answer to that question under this Government, it would appear to be almost too clear that the answer will be that this Government will prove to be incapable of making or understanding commercial decisions, just as it is incapable of making hard decisions on the future of government-owned enterprises . When these or any other government-owned organisations need assistance, the Australian public needs to know that it will be called on to provide the funds and it will have no alternative but to provide the funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills which are under discussion at the present time provide for the appropriation of funds to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to those appropriations which were made in the last Parliament for the current financial year. The additional funds apply to both capital works and wage and salary increases. Cost and price increases which have occurred since the Budget was prepared are principal factors underlying the Additional Estimates. Although the Budget figures contained allowances for prospective wage and salary increases, those amounts were not then appropriated and funds are now required to meet the cost of awards and determinations made before the introduction of the wages pause in December 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of other factors such as staff increases, the appropriations now sought , together with those made in Appropriation Act (No. 3) 1982-83 and Appropriation Act (No. 4) of 1982-83, and after allowing for prospective savings , represent a net increase of $1,286.5m in expenditures financed from annual appropriations. This increase represents approximately 2.5 per cent of aggregate Budget outlays for the fiscal year. The Government considers this increase is unavoidable in view of the need to maintain essential services, to continue at existing levels programs of the previous Government, pending their review, where appropriate, and to fund certain requirements that have to be met by the Government since the election.

I will outline some of the main areas in respect of which the Government has found it necessary to seek additional provisions in these Appropriation Bills. In Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1982-83, an estimated $275m is for wages and salaries-being $208m for non-defence and $67m for defence purposes-to meet increases in award wages and other wage and salary costs, including the costs in respect of increased staff ceilings approved by the previous Government. An amount of $17.5m is included under the Department of Communications for the Australian Broacasting Commission, primarily to meet salary and rent increases and thus enable the Commission to maintain its domestic services.

Under the Department of Defence, provisions totalling some $129.1m are to meet prices and exchange rate effects on the costs of new and replacement equipment. A further $11.9m is included under the Department for the repair and overhaul of equipment and stores. An amount of $10.4m is sought for the Department of Defence Support for production assistance in respect of the Nomad aircraft and covers increased subsidy and development costs caused by price increases, production over-runs and cancellation costs. A further $4.3m is sought by way of additional working capital advances to various Government defence factories. An amount of $10m is sought under the Department of Foreign Affairs for the provision of the special grant to Papua New Guinea announced recently by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden).

Supplementation has been sought also for a number of welfare related programs funded from annual appropriations, including: The sum of $2m in respect of grants administered by the Department of Social Security for community welfare agencies; the sum of $3.3m for payments in respect of accommodation for migrants and refugees, and support for employment-related schemes administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, including $3m for special training for Aboriginals, $2m in respect of the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training, $1.5m for community-based youth support schemes and $1.5m for youth training.

Some of the major capital funding items include an amount of $175m for additional capital injections to Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd , reflecting the deterioration profitability and liquidity positions of the airlines due to the downturn in the airline industry. Part of the increase for TAA was approved by the previous Government in December 1982. Since that time, it has become necessary to approve an additional $90m injection of capital for TAA and $60m for Qantas. The sum of $25.5m is included under the Department of Communications, representing a further payment on the 75 million part-paid shares in Aussat Pty Ltd which are now held by the Commonwealth. An amount of $3 .2m is provided to the Australian Taxation Office for the purchase of facilities for a national integrated computer system, a second computer site and equipment to assist the Taxation Office in the implementation and administration of the proposed labour and services withholding tax legislation.

Included under the Department of Primary Industry for payment to South Australia is $11m in respect of concessional loans for the reconstruction of the forestry industry in the wake of the recent bushfires in that State. An amount of $4.1m is sought for payment to New South Wales as a concessional loan to assist the Letona Co-op Ltd. An amount of $7.4m is provided under the Department of Resources and Energy in respect of an advance to the Pipeline Authority. An amount of $90m is included under the Department of Transport to meet an urgent need to increase the capital of the Australian Shipping Commission resulting from liquidity difficulties. The amount comprises a direct capital injection of $30m as well as $60m to enable the immediate conversion of that amount of outstanding government loans to equity capital. The provision of additional equity to the Commission is subject to satisfactory arrangements being agreed with the unions on reductions in manning levels across the Australian National Line fleet.

It can be seen from the Bills presently before us that cost and price increases are the principal factors which necessitate the provision of additional funds. These increases are a direct result of the policies which were pursued by the previous conservative Government-policies which had such a devastating effect on the economy of this country. The major element of the Fraser Government's approach was its 'fight inflation first' strategy. It was this strategy that exacerbated rather than assisted our economic problems. The previous Government' s tight monetary approach did not reduce inflation but it did squeeze out of the system any chance of real economic growth.

In August 1982 the former conservative Government brought down a Budget which by understating expenditure and overstating income estimated the deficit for the current financial year as being $1,674m. We all know that it was no time at all before the deceptive and rubbery nature of the Budget was outlined for all to see. In fact, within days of the Budget being presented, the funds provided for unemployment and welfare payments were shown to be downright inaccurate and misleading. The Budget blowout continued throughout the former Government's term of office and is still continuing because of the effects of that Government's decisions on the Australian economy. We know now that the anticipated deficit for the current financial year will be in the order of $4,300m-a far cry from the original estimate.

The fragile nature of our economy was outlined in great detail at the recent National Economic Summit Conference, a conference historic in its formation and in the manner in which community and union leaders were apprised by the Government of the state of the nation. Never before has a government been willing to apprise the people of Australia of the true nature of the parlous position that this Labor Government has inherited from the conservatives sitting opposite. The Australian economy is in deep recession. Economic activity and the level of employment are continuing to fall and the level of unemployment is rising. Profits are depressed and inflation and interest rates remain high. One cannot deny that the country's decline into recession has been as a result of many factors, including the international recession. It is also an undeniable fact that the previous Government did nothing to stimulate the economy or provide additional job opportunities for those 700,000 people unfortunate enough to find themselves on the dole.

The Labor Government has now set in train a number of measures to get Australia moving again and legislation to give effect to this will be placed before this House in the very near future. I do not intend to canvass these recovery measures during this debate, but suffice to say that this Government of which I am proud to be a member will do something about increasing demand, creating work and providing assistance to those in need in our community. As I mentioned earlier in this debate, the additional funds now required are as a result of cost increases. The schedules outlining the various costs show that increases in wages and salaries are a dominant factor. It is for this reason that adherence to the prices and incomes accord between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions is paramount if a real growth in the economy which will be beneficial to all Australians can be achieved.

Let me now turn to some of the major capital funding aspects of this legislation which affect Australian Government travel and transport carriers and outline in greater detail the reasons for such increased funding which is designed to ensure that our national carriers are allowed to continue in that important role, free from the threats of sale or downgrading of activities imposed or proposed by the former conservative Government. The Government seeks to provide $115m to Trans Australia Airlines and $60m to Qantas to assist both airlines during a period of a severe downturn in the demand for international and national air travel.

The problems faced by our national carriers are similar to those faced by the major airlines of most other countries, namely increasing costs and a downturn in demand. In the late 1970s Qantas committed itself to the acquisition of bigger and more expensive aircraft as a result of the boom in passenger travel which unfortunately declined rather rapidly over a short period as a result of an increasing international recessional process. At this stage I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the weekly average passenger traffic carried by Qantas in and out of Australia and the weekly average seat capacity of that airline.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. That table shows that from 1979 to 1983 weekly average passenger traffic in and out of Australia increased by 24.9 per cent, whereas weekly average seat capacity increased by 31.6 per cent. The Qantas expansion occurred during a period of tight monetary control when interest rates and costs were rapidly increasing. The effect of the increase in interest rates during recent years, for instance, shows that the interest burden on Qantas of $ 53m in 1982 increased to $69m in 1983. The crux of the problem goes back to the boom period of travel in the late 1970s.

SPEECH.PARA: To cash in on this boom market, Qantas, as did many other airlines in the world , placed orders for new equipment. The trouble with buying huge and expensive aircraft such as the $60m Boeing 747 is that orders have to be placed for these aircraft years before they are ready for delivery and progress payments have to be made. Qantas reached the final committal point for ordering a new series of Boeings in 1979 and months after that, when there was no turning back, the world air traffic market collapsed. The initial Qantas strategy was a 'roll over'. The newer 747s are more efficient than the older ones, so like other airlines Qantas decided to buy new and sell off the old. But the 'roll-over' strategy depends on a good resale market. Airlines have to be matched to aircraft and the price for both has to be right. But what happened in the 1980-81 period was that, with the collapse of the air traffic market, the second-hand market for wide bodies also collapsed.

If there were such a thing as a normal market, the three 747s Qantas had for sale would be worth something like $20m to $25m each. So if they had been sold at a fair price, the cash result might have made it unnecessary for Qantas to sell off some properties. But the problem went far beyond merely having capital locked up. Overhead charges such as interest payments, depreciation and care and maintenance on each aircraft would add up to about $8,000 an aircraft a day, or more than $150,000 a week. This is before attributing a figure of up to $250,000 a week to represent the forgone opportunities of using the capital tied up in these aircraft. So, irrespective of what was happening in the market place, Qantas was flying into a built-in headwind-the high interest payments caused by the low equity component of its capital and the overhead of having three expensive aircraft pushed up against the fence. In order to finance these initiatives Qantas had to borrow quite heavily, having been denied adequate capital by the previous conservative Government.

The most important cost factor for airlines today is the price of fuel. Qantas' s fuel bills make up 30 per cent of its airline expenditure. Again I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a further table showing the airline unit fuel costs from 1979 to 1983.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
AIRLINE UNIT FUEL COSTS 1979-83(a)
(a) Average unit price paid throughout the world for that year-1979 set at 100 base units.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The table shows that the increase in fuel costs between 1979 and 1983 was 191 per cent. This, of course, has become part of the world-wide problem which occurred in the 1970s. However, the position has also been exacerbated by the previous Government's oil parity pricing and the decline in the value of the Australian dollar. The need of the new Government to devalue the Australian dollar recently was a result of the irresponsible behaviour of the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in talking up depreciation which accelerated an outflow of capital from Australia just prior to the 5 March election. Labour costs constitute one-third of Qantas's total outlay, even though the number of employees over recent years has declined. In April 1983 the approximate staff numbers were 11,500. But while staff levels have remained fairly constant over the past 10 years the total employee costs have soared by 241 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, of course, other problems facing Qantas. The competition from overseas and the number of gimmicks which have been put forward by a number of overseas airlines have made it very difficult for Qantas to compete on the international market. The same applies to TAA. That Australian Government owned airline is facing similar problems to those of Qantas-inadequate capital, the need to borrow heavily, high interest rates, fuel increases and high labour costs. The injection of $115m that I mentioned previously, which is covered by the legislation, will permit the revitalisation of the airline and enable it to take initiatives which had not been possible under the previous Government.

In conclusion, I emphasise the injection of capital funds into Qantas, TAA and the Australian National Line is very necessary. It will enable all three national carriers, in the air and on the sea, to compete better against overseas competition. It will enable them to fulfil this Government's wish that they remain in Australian Government ownership thus ensuring long term service to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin by acknowledging the victory of the Australian Labor Party on 5 March. It was certainly convincing and decisive. What needs to be understood on both sides of the chamber, as well as in Australia generally, is that the Opposition need recover only 2.6 per cent of the national vote to put the Government out of office. That is not a particularly comfortable margin. I believe that 13 to 20 members on the Government back benches would realise that their positions in this place are not necessarily all that secure. I believe that will keep the Government on its mettle and will ensure that the sorts of things that were canvassed by it during the election campaign will be implemented. If they are not, I rather suspect that next time around there could easily be a change of government. During the election campaign, and prior to it, the Labor Party created enormous expectations in the Australian community. It now has the task of delivering on those expectations. If it fails to do so I believe that it will suffer at the hands of the Australian electorate the next time around.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Economic Summit Conference, which was undoubtedly an enormous political success for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government, has added to the expectations in the community and will increase the pressure on the Government to perform. It is obvious at this early stage that the Government will continue to blame the former Government for all sorts of things; we have seen that going on. I guess it is the approach that all incoming governments take but I do not think that it will necessarily wash all that much. The reality is that a Labor Government is now in office. It is the Government that is making the decisions. It is the Government that will introduce the Budget in August. It will not be our Budget; it will not be our deficit. That needs to be understood. The decisions about which policies are to be continued and which are to be cut will be made by the Cabinet of this Labor Government. They will not be made on this side of the House. Whatever level of deficit the Government comes up with, whatever economic strategy it determines in relation to the Budget and for the period that follows will be decided by Labor's priorities. That needs to be understood. It will not be good enough for the Prime Minister and his Ministers to continue, into the indefinite future, to blame everything on the former Government.

It should be acknowledged that the Australian Labor Party has deserted its platform. That platform was hammered out in great detail last year at the ALP Conference. It was built upon in forming the strategy for the elections of 5 March but, in reality, it bears no relationship to the policies that the Prime Minister and his Government have followed since they achieved office. It is very interesting to go through the documents that were made available prior to, and during, the National Economic Summit Conference and look at some of the acknowledgments made therein by the Government, on economic matters in particular. Perhaps the most significant is that the Government acknowledges that unemployment will continue at levels of around 10 per cent for the next three or four years and perhaps even longer.

Of all the things that the Prime Minister and his Ministry have done since they achieved office the greatest indictment must be that they have walked away from the unemployment problem on which they placed so much emphasis during the election campaign and when in Opposition. They have obviously realised the sorts of difficulties that the Australian economy is facing. They are acknowledging that the policy thrust of the previous Government was not too far off the mark. For a Labor government, only a couple of weeks after it has been elected, to capitulate to that reality and acknowledge that unemployment will continue at a level of about 10 per cent for the next three or four years represents an enormous indictment of that Government. I say to all Government supporters and to Australia generally that it is a pretty grim prospect that we are being offered when the Prime Minister of Australia tells us that under his newly elected Government, which was to bring all Australians together, we will have 10 per cent unemployment in 1983-84, in 1984-85 and in 1985-86. If that is the best that the Government can offer to Australia a harsh judgment may be made concerning it in two or three years when it faces the people again.

We ought also to look at the Government's foreign policy, because it is apparent that under this Government Australia's foreign policy has collapsed. One has only to consider a couple of areas of concern, especially those of East Timor, Kampuchea and the Multinational Force and Observers in the Sinai. If anything was clear about the policy of these aspirants for government during the pre-election period it was in relation to those matters. Labor said that it would overturn the policy of the previous Government on East Timor. It said it would derecognise the incorporation in Indonesia of East Timor; that it would reintroduce aid to Vietnam even though that country was occupying Kampuchea; moreover, that it would withdraw the Australian force from the Sinai. It is apparent to everybody that, despite the footwork of the Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden), as he has gone from country to country since the elections, the Government has had to capitulate, to accept the propriety of the former Government's policy in relation to those matters. Despite the pressure being exerted on it from within its party and by back benchers, the reality is that the Government can do nothing about East Timor. It will have to withdraw its assertion in that regard. It will have to change its attitude concerning the offering of aid to Vietnam. Moreover, it will have to continue to maintain the force in the Sinai.

One could give all sorts of other examples of the way in which this Labor Government has walked away from its platform, its commitments and its election promises. Perhaps closest to the hip pockets of most Australians is the matter of tax cuts. I do not believe that the average Australian will be all that much impressed by what the Economic Summit may have produced. The reality is that the Prime Minister made it clear that tax cuts would be put in place when his party came to government. His policy speech, of which I have a copy with me, even has on the back tabulations showing what a taxpayer with dependent spouse and children would get, what a taxpayer without such dependants would get; it is all there. It could not be clearer, yet the Australian Labor Party came into government and promptly walked away from that promise. That should be understood .

I find it interesting that the Prime Minister has demonstrated that all he is concerned about is being there. He did exactly what he had to do to get there and he is doing what he perceives he must do to stay there. Whatever that might mean in terms of capitulation and change of heart and policy does not matter. The fact of the matter is that he is there; he sees himself as being in his rightful place in government in this country. Being there is what he is all about. I go so far as to say that the Prime Minister is the Chauncey Gardener of Australian politics; he is just concerned about being there. I wonder how long the Labor Party-this great party with an enormous ideological commitment built up over 60 years or 80 years in this country-will accept this 'being there' approach offered by the Prime Minister of the day.

I do not in any sense want to regard myself as a twentieth century Nostradamus, but I predict that ALP supporters will start to expect and demand implementation of the Party's platform and policy. I do not think that the great Labor Party will go on for too long just feeding the ego of the Prime Minister and allowing him the fruits of office when all the people who have supported him and done so much work over so many years to achieve the success of a Labor Government at the polls expect him to do more than just be there. They expect him to implement the policies and the platforms for which they all stand. It will be interesting to see how this Government reacts when the pressure really comes on. What will it do about its foreign affairs, wages and unemployment policies? Dare I ask also what it will do about the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation? We might hear a word or two about that this afternoon when the Prime Minister comes in to the House to talk about these matters.

In my view, the ALP faces two major difficulties. The first is that it has created an expectation that it will deliver the goods for its supporters and the people who voted for it. As I have indicated, it has already walked away from so many of those promises, policies and, indeed, its own platform. It has to learn to live with that and it is my view that it will not be allowed to do so because the people who supported it will not accept that. If they had wanted the sorts of policies this Government is implementing, they would have voted for Malcolm Fraser, Doug Anthony and the Liberal-National Party team. It is as simple as that. They voted for a Hawke Government because they perceived that they would get different policies. They are not getting different policies and I think they will probably come back to the Liberal-National Party coalition at the next election. I predict also that the Government will have enormous difficulty containing the ideologues within the party. It will be very interesting for honourable members on this side of the House to watch that over the period ahead of us.

I do not believe that overseas recovery, even if it does come and there is some doubt about whether it will come, will be enough to save this Government. The signs of recovery in the United States of America are still very tenuous and the Prime Minister and his Government are hanging an awful lot on that overseas recovery. If it does not come, there will be some enormous difficulties facing the Government.

I now turn to the area of transport for which I have responsibility as shadow Minister. I am very pleased that the Minister for Transport (Mr Morris) is in the House for this debate. I think it goes without question that transport is an area which is of major significance to the Australian economy. These days, the portfolio is structured to cover three broad policy areas: Roads, rail, to the extent that the railways are a Commonwealth responsibility, and shipping and shipping policy. When I was preparing this speech and giving thought to the things I would say, I determined that I would consider the mandate that the ALP has, because I do not want to cause any problems for the Minister in relation to those things for which it is clear that the Government has a mandate from the people. I refer to those things that the Government put before the electorate during the election campaign. The Australian Labor Party has now come into Government with the expectation of implementing those measures without any great difficulties from the Opposition. But one of the interesting things about the policy speech that was delivered at the Sydney Opera House on 16 February is that transport does not get a mention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all?

—No, not at all. I do not quite understand why that is because I know that the Minister, when in Opposition, was a very vigourous shadow Minister. He and I shared a lot of interests in a committee sense and our offices were on the same floor of the building. I saw his staff beavering away day and night. There was obviously a great deal of work done by the Minister for Transport in his period in Opposition, but for some reason he failed to get anything up at all in the ALP policy speech which was delivered by the Prime Minister. Even in the back-up documentation that was not delivered by the Prime Minister at the Opera House there was no mention of transport-even though all sorts of other areas that were not even departmental areas got a mention. The only place that I could find it mentioned was in the commitment to spend $70m on the Jobs on Roads Program. This came under the section headed 'Community Works Program'. It was not under a section headed 'Transport'. I think that is interesting, because I had difficulty trying to find out what was the policy of the Labor Party that was put before the people during the election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: The next thing that transpired in this history was that the Governor-General came to the Parliament on 21 April 1983 and delivered a speech on the occasion of the opening of the Thirty-third Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good speech too.

—It was an interesting speech; I will say that to the honourable member for Bowman. The Governor-General covered a broad range of areas. I here pay a tribute to my friend, the Minister for Transport. I am pleased to say that transport got a mention in the Governor-General's Speech. In that Speech it was laid down that an Inter-State Commission would be established. That was legislated for and passed by both Houses of the Parliament in the life of the previous Labor Government. The Bill was never given royal assent. It was not given royal assent by our Government and it remains to be seen whether the present Government asks for royal assent to be given. There is nothing very new about that proposal. There will be a blue about it when it comes up because a lot of people were concerned about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The second proposal was for a national inquiry into the road freight industry. That, I think, is new; I do not recognise it as having come from elsewhere. I acknowledge that the Minister actually got that one into the Governor-General's Speech. In that Speech there was also mention made of the fact that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program would continue. I think that is a tribute to the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), the former Minister for Transport, who legislated for that. I think that is terrific. The next proposal was for improvement in the efficiency of national rail services and the upgrading of designated railway routes of national importance, including port and rail facilities for exports. Again, I think that is a tribute to the former Minister for Transpot and an acknowledgement of the policy that he was implementing and pursuing in that area. It was also mentioned in the Speech that the Government would put the Australian Shipping Commission and the Australian National Railways Commission on an improved commercial basis. The legislation to do that had already been introduced into the Parliament by the former Minister. Again, we acknowledge the contribution made by the former Minister in that regard.

The last matter mentioned in the section on transport in the Governor-General's Speech was that the Government would pick up the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships. The Minister has introduced the legislation into the Parliament; it is in terms indentical to those which had been introduced by the former Minister for Transport under the former Government and which had lapsed upon the prorogation of Parliament. If we consider the transport section of the Governor-General's Speech and look at the sorts of things this Government will be doing in the life of this Parliament, we will be looking at a pretty dynamic area. I hope that the Minister for Transport will be able to keep himself busy over the period ahead. I certainly hope that I do not get bored with trying to keep up with him as he goes about the process of administering this Department and implementing what policies the Australian Labor Party may have.

There are other issues. I mention shipping and, in particular, the need for a major inquiry into coastal shipping. The question of regulations, the Navigation Act and things of that nature are particularly important to me. I will give them a lot of scrutiny in the period ahead. I am concerned about the Australian National Railways Commission. I believe it is a disaster area. It is a statutory authority that has a corporate plan to which it has never stuck and has no hope of sticking. It is supposed to break even by 1988; it has about as much chance of that happening as-well, honourable members can put it in their own words.

The Australian National Line is another disaster area. The Government has had to allocate $30m in cash and write off $60m worth of loans to try to improve the situation of the Australian National Line. Over the course of this Parliament I want justification from the Minister for Transport as to why ANL should continue in government ownership if in fact it will continue to guzzle the dollars in the way that it is. I will obviously be scrutinising the administration of the Bicentennial Roads Development Program in the period ahead. I look forward to co -operating with the Minister for Transport over the period of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the package of appropriation Bills before the House. In the atmosphere of this afternoon's debate, at the outset I wish to express my appreciation to the former Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), for the courtesies and the assistance that he provided to me in my capacity as shadow Minister for Transport. I welcome the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) in his new role as the shadow Minister for Transport in his rightful place on the other side of the chamber. I want to convey to him and to the Parliament my intention to provide the shadow Minister for Transport with the same kind of courtesy, treatment and reciprocal approach as was provided to me by my predecessor. I appreciate the remarks made by the honourable member for Hume at the end of his speech just a few moments ago. It is interesting to listen to the comments of former Government supporters when they complain about what they see as broken promises. No really honourable gentleman on the other side of the chamber could make such a claim. In seven years in office honourable members opposite created the greatest record of unbroken promises, unfulfilled obligations and reversals of policy.
—There is no reason for you to go down the same track.

—But I am saying it very gently to honourable members opposite. I appreciate the concern of the honourable member for Hume about the welfare of the new Labor Government. I hope that it is honestly and genuinely intended.
—What about your own retreaded promises?

—I ask the honourable member for Dawson to be patient. It is interesting to listen to those comments because the previous Government's abysmal record of incompetence and mismanagement has brought this country to its knees. It is for those reasons that honourable members opposite were hurled from office on 5 March at a date of their own choosing without policies and without representation of what they were about or what they intended for the future. I am very touched by the concern of honourable members opposite about what is going to happen to this Government because they did not have a policy to present . Their only reaction had been one of negativism. At the same time, I am concerned at the lighthearted comment of the honourable member for Hume, the shadow Minister for Transport, that transport did not get a mention in the Australian Labor Party policy speech. Had I known of his concern I would have ensured that at least half a page of items had been included for his benefit.
—It would have been very enlightening.

—It would have been enlightening. I think the best thing to do, given the amiable manner in which the shadow Minister for Transport and I are going to work together, is for him to pop around to my office. I will ensure that he has a copy of the full document which was distributed before the election. It spells it all out there for him. I will explain it.
—It came out after the election.

—Do not worry, I will explain it. I also remind the House that the platform policy of my party which was released in July of last year-this policy was formulated at the 1982 biennial conference of the Australian Labor Party-set out the principal objectives of my party. For the benefit of those honourable members opposite who did not have time during the election campaign to read it I point out that in this document--
—It came out after the election.
—No, it did not.
—Order! The Minister will ignore the interjections and address his comments through the Chair.

—I am sorry. I will have all that information ready for the honourable member for Hume. If any other members of the Opposition would like to have a briefing they should let me know and I will arrange for a committee room to be set aside and I will go through the document for them, sentence by sentence. I would like to correct the shadow Minister for Transport on one point . He referred to the Inter-State Commission Bill. Certainly that Bill did have bipartisan support in its amended form in 1975. That Bill received royal assent in 1975. But the previous Government of which the honourable member for Hume was a member for seven years refused to proclaim the legislation. That is what happened.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Hume said that an inquiry should be held into coastal shipping. His party had seven years in which to set up such an inquiry. Previous Liberal-National Party governments were in office for 23 years before that. In all, Liberal-National Country Party governments had 30 years in which to set up a coastal shipping inquiry. The previous Government did nought about it. It is a matter about which regular allegations are made sometimes by people in the community with vested interests. If allegations concerning interstate coastal transport are backed by some form of evidence the inter-State commission, after it is established, could examine them. In view of allegations which are made from time to time by various groups that is certainly an area that could well be the subject of activity by the proposed Inter-State commission.

The honourable member for Hume said that railways are a disaster area. My same comments apply. For more than 90 per cent of the period since World War II conservative administrations have been responsible for national railways. If they are in a disaster situation now then it is the responsibility of those honourable members who sit opposite. We are looking at the problems of the Australian National Railways Commission. In doing so we will operate on the basis of consultation. We will try to get a proper information base to the work force and develop a better relationship among the Commission, management and the work force. We will look at ways of inproving the provision of national mainline rail services. Our policy document provided for that in the form of a national railways council. We will not be resting to ensure that the Commission is made more efficient and that its productivity is increased. The shadow Minister for Transport and I share some common interest from our service on the Expenditure Committee. It is an area of positive endeavour on our part.

The honourable member for Hume also referred to the Australian National Line as a disaster area. He asked why it should continue in Government ownership. The question that beggars is this: If that is his view now why was it not his view some 61 days ago, prior to the election of 5 March?

TALK.START.PARA: —Passenger trains back in Tasmania would be a good idea.

—In the seven years of the previous Government the honourable member for Franklin was one of the members who went along with the cancellation of the last passenger service in Tasmania, the Tasman Limited. The honourable member for Franklin endorsed that cancellation and approved it. The honourable member for Franklin was party to that mischief. In its seven years in office the previous Government endorsed the removal of passenger trains in Tasmania. Let me turn to the more important areas. I want to mention--
—No, I did not endorse it. Check the records.

—Honourable members opposite will have plenty of time to talk to me privately. I will make available a committee room. Do not worry. We will deal with those things then. The other matter to which I wanted to refer is the amount of $750,000 that was to have been provided by the previous Government to publicise the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. It was a paid media advertising program. The former Government intended to spend $750,000. A lot of kerbing and guttering, road drainage and the sealing of roads could be done for $750,000 in those areas of Australia which do not have those services. We have removed $700,000 from that sum. Instead of the amount in the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) being $750,000 it is now $50,000. Most of that was expended by the previous Government prior to 5 March.
—You transferred the rest to the--
—Order! The honourable member for Hume has had his opportunity to speak.

—The other matter to which I wanted to refer is the amount of $ 75,000 which is to be provided to the Bureau of Transport Economics for the expansion of computer facilities which will enable the BTE to save on costs that it pays out now and would have to pay to data processing bureau in future years and to use the latest computing and information processing techniques in its important research work. Another matter concerns the provision of $2.5m. I am sure that all honourable members from Tasmania are concerned about this item. It relates to the construction of the second Hobart or Bowen bridge in Tasmania. That amount is necessary because it is an ongoing commitment from the previous Government to meet contractual commitments arising from accelerated programs and site developments.
—Thanks for letting me open it. That is terrific.

—I am sure that is another matter on which you will be strongly supportive of the Government. That is being done on a bipartisan basis. However, the most important significant item is the payment of equity capital to the Australian Shipping Commission which was touched upon briefly by the shadow Minister for Transport. The Government has agreed to make available to the Australian National Line the sum of $30m as a cash injection for immediate working capital and to maintain the liquidity of the Commission. We have agreed to convert $60m in government loans to equity capital. That will place the Line on a much sounder commercial footing. It will substantially reduce its indebtedness and its debt servicing costs and interest payments.
—It will just cover the loss too.
—It is not a capital loss my friend, because--
—I said it will just cover the loss.
—It will not cover the loss.
—Order! The Minister will address his remarks through the Chair and not respond to the interjections. I advise the honourable member for Hume once again that he has had his opportunity to speak.

—Very good advice, Mr Deputy Speaker. I accept it. The conversion of loans to equity capital will reduce interest payments and debt servicing and at the same time will give a much more secure base upon which the Commission can develop in the future. We need to remember that, when the Commission was established in 1956, it had a capital injection of $32.85m. In the first year, its revenue almost equalled its capital of $32m. In 1964, there was a further injection of $3m and, even though there had been a vast expansion in revenue, the capital remained at that figure until the recent decision of the Government. In the 1970s, ANL expanded into overseas bulk and liner trades. This expansion was financed by recourse to loans and lease back financing that left the Commission with a huge interest bill to be met from its operations, which left it without reserves to cushion it against the troubles and difficulties it would face in a period of recession, as has developed over recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, the Commission operates over 33 ships' across a diversity of trades. It employs almost 4,000 people and it provides a significant and essential service in the domestic and international trades. Its assets are worth in excess of $ 400m. Its turnover is in excess of $500m a year. Like any other enterprise in a period of recession and depression, much of which was inflicted upon it by the previous Government, as Australia is experiencing now, it is certain that the Commission would suffer some difficulty in trading conditions and performance. Across the globe, something like 100 million tonnes of shipping is laid up because there are no cargoes to be transported. Many operators-less efficient national and private ones-have been driven into insolvency because of the state of the industry. The fact that the Australian Shipping Commission has survived to date is very much due to the people who manage and work in the operation. It does no credit to those now opposite that the Commission finds itself in a desperate financial situation. That information was available to the previous Government at least as early as February last year but it declined to do anything about it. Since then, the Commission's difficulties have been exacerbated, firstly, by poor leadership from those who now sit opposite, secondly, by the high interest burden, thirdly, by chronic undercapitalisation and, fourthly and most importantly, by a serious lack of morale that arose from attacks within the former Government upon ANL and Trans Australia Airlines.

When we came to Government the position was very clear. If we expected that enterprise, which is owned by the Australian people, to perform effectively and efficiently in the way the public expects it to, there needed to be a concerted effort by all involved-by seafarers, management and government. It was in that tenor that we approached the problem of arranging meetings between employees, the Commission, its management, myself and the Department of Transport to try to bring together the common objectives. I commend the representatives of the seagoing unions and the Commission for the very positive and constructive attitude they exhibited during those discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't go too far on them, for goodness sake.
—I beg the honourable member's pardon?
—Order! the honourable member for Franklin will remain silent.

—The former Government tried its way and it just about destroyed the enterprise. We are trying to put it on a proper basis now. We expect the support of the Opposition on this matter. The agreement that has been reached between the Government and the representatives of the seagoing unions and the Commission is designed to increase productivity and efficiency to make the Line more competitive. It will result in a rationalisation of crew sizes, part of which is to be achieved in the fairly immediate future and part of which is to be achieved by the the end of the year. In addition agreement has been reached on what we call the ANL Shipboard Practices Committee. That Committee has the very positive objectives of reviewing and examining shipboard practices and productivity, the sharing of tasks on board, the organisation of duties, shipboard organisation and proposals, from whatever source, for improving the efficiency and operation of those vessels and of the Commission generally. In going about it in that positive and consultative way, sponsored by Government, but involving the employees of the Commission and the Commission itself, we hope that it will develop and provide the kind of shipping service that the Australian people expect its Commission to provide. I am confident that it can.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, I again commend the officials of the seagoing unions for this very enlightened and courageous approach they have made to what is a very serious problem. The result of this will be to provide a secure and developing future for the ANL. It will be a line that will be more competitive and more efficient. The $30m cash injection we are providing will help it to get over its immediate problems. The $60m conversion of loans will ease the debt servicing problem I mentioned earlier. But that can only be done in the spirit of consensus, which is something that I am sure those opposite have found is out there in the community. People are sick of the division of Fraserism. They are sick of that confrontation and division. They want Australians to pull together and work together to get this country back on its feet again. We are reflecting that hope in the action that we have taken in respect of the Australian National Line. In a few short weeks, we have managed to achieve more for the Australian National Line than seven years of Liberal Party and National Party confrontation , rhetoric and union bashing have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—The honourable member for Braddon says: 'Rubbish'. He will hang by his own words. With a proper financial structure and positive union involvement, ANL will be a viable commercial operation, able to maintain its position in world trading. In due course, it will be able to grasp opportunities to expand operations and provide greater employment opportunities for seafarers. Most of all, as a great maritime nation, we need a maritime presence in the shipping trades of the world. We have not had that under conservative governments but we can do it. It will provide jobs and careers for Australians and a better balance of payments picture. I am very heartened by the approach that has been taken by the unions and the Australian Shipping Commission and all the parties involved. I support the Bills before the House and I commend the honourable member for Hume for the expression of attitude that he has made to this date. I assure him that I will be reciprocating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now sitting as the Thirty-third Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. As I said in my speech last week when we spoke on the South West Tasmania dam issue, this is an historic Parliament because there are Tasmanian members of parliament only on this side of the House-in Opposition . There are no members from Tasmania on the Government side.
