I believe that is a very significant factor and it is one which I hope the Government, especially the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), will give a great deal of thought to. I emphasise this point again by asking: Why is it that the people of Tasmania have totally and absolutely rejected the policies of the Australian Labor Party and why have they returned to this Parliament five members of the Liberal Party who sit in opposition on this occasion?
—It was just an accident.

—Just an accident, yes! The reason was, of course, that the people of Tasmania were afraid of the actions that the Australian Labor Party might undertake in taking away from Tasmania our own State's rights and our responsibilities. I do not want to get back on to that dam issue or speak too long on that point. This certainly should have been a Parliament of hope. There has been a lot of talk about consensus, of harmony and of bringing the nation together. Part of the policy enunciated by the Prime Minister before the election was that he would reduce unemployment. But the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) made a very salient point when he said that we now have an admission by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister that unemployment will remain at about 10 per cent for at least the next three years.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have it that the people of Australia were told that if the Labor Party gained office, the present Government would reduce unemployment. Now we have the admission, within a matter of weeks of Labor's gaining office, that there will be no significant reduction in unemployment. I would hope, as I believe every fair minded Australian would hope, that we could reduce unemployment. It is a tragedy that so many young people are unemployed. Somehow we must get these people back into jobs. If the Labor Party has the answers, so be it; we say congratulations. On this side of the House, we shall be happy, because our job is not to do the right thing by ourselves and by the party that we represent but to do the right thing by Australia. We would hope, therefore, that we could reduce unemployment.

There has been much talk about the deficit. This is an old trick. It was used by Mr Cain when he gained office in Victoria and by Mr Bannon when he gained office in South Australia. The idea is that when one gains office one says: 'We did not realise that the economy was in such a disastrous state and therefore we cannot keep our promises'. It is an old record that we hear being played day in and day out in this place.

It is interesting when we hear talk about a mandate. It is a very interesting concept. What is a mandate? On the one hand, the Prime Minister says: 'I have a very clear mandate to stop the dam in Tasmania, and despite the fact that it will cost hundreds of millions of dollars and despite the deficit situation, that is a promise we have made to the people. We have this mandate; we shall go ahead and stop the dam. We are not concerned about the deficit as far as the dam is concerned. It will cost hundred of millions of dollars, no doubt, in compensation for Tasmania. Regardless of the deficit, we shall implement that policy and spend hundreds of milions of dollars of mainlanders money to stop the dam. We do not care about the deficit'.

On the other hand, what about income tax? In the policy speech the present Prime Minister said: 'We will reduce personal income tax'. I do not have the details in front of me, but there were a number of different areas in which he was going to reduce personal income tax for Australian taxpayers, and he would do that immediately. He quoted the cost of doing that. In his policy speech there are scales and schedules which indicate all the details of the promises. Now, of course, the Prime Minister says: 'We cannot do this because of the deficit situation.' So we have this duplicity: 'We shall implement this policy to stop the Tasmanian dam regardless of the deficit. We do not give a damn about the deficit. But we will not implement this mandate and this promise concerning personal income tax because of the deficit'. Where is the honesty in those two positions taken by the Prime Minister?

We are now talking about appropriations. The Government of the day is asking this Parliament to approve large amounts in appropriations. This is a very important factor. Here we are sitting as a parliament. It is tragic that we have so few members in this chamber at present, and certainly so few on the Government side. But we are being asked to approve a huge sum to be spent by the Government under these Appropriation Bills. So we are now fulfilling a very important role, and we should look carefully at the appropriations. I want to refer briefly to three particular areas of appropriation contained in these Bills. If my arithmetic is correct, we have $54,691,000 to be appropriated to the Department of Defence, $18,007,000 to be appropriated to the Australian Broadcasting Commission, and $288,000 for the departments of the Parliament. I want to focus attention on those areas of appropriation.

The first appropriation is for defence. If we are to appropriate funds, as a parliament, for the Department of Defence, it is important that that money is actually spent for proper defence purposes. This, of course, highlights the spy planes episode that occurred recently when an F111 and a Mirage jet flew over South West Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful!

—As the honourable member for Denison says, it was a most shameful incident. It is one which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in the other place tries to laugh off when he talks about the streaker's defence-it seemed like a good idea at the time. That is not a very good defence when we are talking about matters as important as this. It might be all right for a streaker appearing in a magistrate's court charged with running on to the Melbourne Cricket Ground, but we are dealing here with major issues of concern to Australia. It is vitally important that those who are charged with the grave responsibility of administering the defence of this nation realise how important that responsibility is, and they must do the right thing by the people of all of Australia, including our State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: We notice that the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes), who is not in the chamber at present, has not admitted that what he did was wrong on that occasion. He answered questions in the House last week-not very well, but he endeavoured to answer questions put to him by me and by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) on this issue. Eventually, the Minister came clean and admitted that there had been additional flights over South West Tasmania, despite the fact he initially said that there were only two flights over South West Tasmania. But he has continued to suggest to this chamber that it really was not an unlawful act, that it was not a wrong thing to do and that what he did was proper on that occasion.

There are two important issues which honourable members should take on board. The first is that here we have a case in which the defence forces of Australia were used for a partisan purpose. It was not to help people in a bushfire or where there were floods. It was a partisan purpose because at that moment a legal battle was going on before the High Court of Australia, in which the Commonwealth and the State of Tasmania were locked in dispute. Here, the Attorney-General, who, I believe, is the principal offender in this matter, conspired with the Minister for Defence for the F111 to go across our State, Tasmania, to take film of the South West, the dam site and what is happening in the South West and to place that evidence before the High Court. It is quite incredible-this is the second point-that an F111 was tasked to undertake this mission on the basis of a telephone call between a Mr Glare, of the Attorney- General's Department--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a glaring mistake.

—It was a glaring mistake, as the honourable member for Franklin mentions-and Group Captain Waterfield of the Royal Australian Air Force. Group Captain Waterfield authorised the mission without consulting officers and without any written confirmation that the mission had been approved by the Minister for Defence. I suggest that honourable members should look at the papers that have been tabled on this issue, in which one sees a glaring conflict between the reports that were presented to senior officers and to Ministers by Mr Glare and a report by Group Captain Waterfield. Group Captain Waterfield said in his minute of 11 April:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Glare confirmed that the Minister for Defence had approved the task about 15 minutes ago.
Mr Glare, in his report of 11 April, the same day, said:
I then contacted the Director of Air Force Operations, Group Captain Waterfield , at about 3 p.m., informed him of the events, and suggested that he confirm the approval with his Minister's office.
So, there are two quite different versions of those conversations, what happened and what was undertaken by those officers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Governor-General know?
—The member for Franklin says: 'Did the Governor-General know?'
—That is important.

—That is an important issue, because we must ask who is in ultimate command of the nation's defence forces. Who makes the final decisions in these matters? When this matter first came to my notice, I think on 11 April, or maybe 12 April-I would not be certain; I would have to check my records-I sent two telegrams. I sent one to the Chief of the Air Staff and I sent one to the Governor-General, who is mentioned in the Australian Constitution as being the commander-in-chief of our defence forces. I received two interesting replies. I do not have them before me at this time to table but I would be pleased to do so if that were requested by any honourable member. The Chief of the Air Staff said that this was not a matter for apology. I had requested an apology on behalf of my constituents for the fact that a Royal Australian Air Force plane had flown over Tasmania in the circumstances that prevailed. I am not quoting exactly from his telegram, but he said: 'We are subject to the civil power'. He said it is a matter for the civil power to make these decisions; it is not for the Air Force to make these decisions. In other words, the chiefs of our defence forces are not in ultimate command of those forces.

SPEECH.PARA: I received a reply from the Governor-General's official secretary in similar terms, saying that although the Governor-General was mentioned in the Constitution as the commander-in-chief of the defence forces, in effect it was a matter for the Ministers. An important question we should ask is: Who is responsible for these decisions? Who decides when our defence forces should be used? What are the criteria for using our defence forces? I believe that it would be appropriate for the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) to come into this chamber as soon as possible and detail when the defence forces can be used to aid the civil power. I believe it would also be appropriate, and this is a point that has been made by the honourable member for Denison, that the Minister for Defence should come into this chamber and admit that he was in error in authorising this particular mission. He should also apologise to the people of Tasmania for what to them was a most offensive incident. Perhaps that is not understood by the Minister, but it is certainly understood by the people of the State of Tasmania. They were most upset that the defence forces, in which they have always had confidence, were being used against them in this way, and one could not deny the fact that the defence forces were being used against them. The evidence they collected was to be used for the Commonwealth case against the State of Tasmania. It was obviously a secret and hostile mission because those concerned were told to make sure that the plane was not obvious-in other words, that the people did not see the plane when it flew over the dam site.

I want briefly to mention one other matter. I referred earlier to the appropriations to the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Department of Communications. Over the last few days one episode has caused so much concern in Australia. I refer to the battle between the ABC and the present Government. One must ask initially who is the Minister responsible for the ABC. Is it Senator Button in the other place or is it the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) in this place? Who is the Minister responsible for the ABC? I thought that the honourable member for Holt was the Minister for Communications and, therefore, the Minister immediately responsible, at the political level, for the operations of the ABC. But apparently it would seem that, despite the fact that Senator Button is the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications, he in fact is the superior Minister and he is the one who directs the Minister in these matters.

If we are concerned about accuracy, and I believe that we should be concerned about truth and accuracy, we should look at the letter that Senator Button wrote to Professor Kramer, the present Chairman of the ABC, the Chairman whom the present Government, by its pressure, obviously wants to sack. But there are some glaring mistakes of fact in the letter written by Senator Button. This was an important letter because this was a major political issue at the time that letter was prepared. It was a letter which was seen, apparently, by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

TALK.START.PARA: —How does this fit into the Appropriation Bills?
—Because, as I have indicated, we are dealing here with appropriations, including the appropriation to the ABC. If the honourable member had been listening earlier she would have noted what I said.

SPEECH.PARA: The basis of Senator Button's concern was an interview by Helen O'Neil of Prime Minister Fraser during the election campaign. Senator Button in his letter said that this incident happened during a Press conference. He said this in his letter. It was published in the Age of 7 May. People can read it. They should read it carefully. There was no Press conference. The incident did not happen at a Press conference. That is mistake No. 1. He said that a question was put to the Prime Minister by Helen O'Neil. If we look at the facts, no question was put . So that is another mistake made. There was an aside-obviously an aside, if we look at the facts-by Helen O'Neil. No question was put. I will quote her words. She said:
I must ask President Reagan that.

That was the only comment she made. That was not a question, that was a comment that she made. Then in his letter Senator Button said the former Prime Minister had trouble anwering the question. He said:
I am informed by journalists who were present at the Press conference that the then Prime Minister seemed to have some difficulty in answering that question . . .

I have quoted directly from his letter. As I said before, there was no Press conference. Is Senator Button misleading the community of Australia, and in particular Professor Kramer, to whom he wrote the letter? He talks about journalists who were present at the Press conference. But there was no Press conference, so who were these journalists? It was an interview conducted by telephone. This may not have been such an important issue had a letter not been written by a senior Minister of this Government concerning a major national political issue. It contains assertions which are clearly inaccurate, which are untruthful and grossly misleading. The whole basis of his letter was wrong in fact. That is something that that particular Minister should be ashamed of and he should admit to the community of Australia that he made mistakes in that letter.

As I said before, there was an allocation also to the Parliamentary departments . I hope that the Prime Minister will pursue the thoughts that he had when he was not a member of the Parliament, when he said that the Parliament should be reformed. Here we have the national Parliament sitting. People are watching us. How many members are here at the moment? What is this debate all about? How worthwhile is this debate? Are we not wasting our time? Where are the Ministers? There is one Minister at the table; no other Ministers are here. We are really wasting our time. Is the Parliament worthwhile? What we need are reforms of the Parliament so that we can question effectively Ministers such as the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris). I think we should have a special committee room , we should have television, we should have effective committees where we can question the Minister for Transport or the Prime Minister-any of the Ministers, including Senator Button-about some of the mistakes that they are now making. The fact is that the balloon has burst already. The Parliament has been sitting for less than two weeks now--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honeymoon is over.

—The honeymoon is over. There have been glaring mistakes by this Government. I am sure that the people of Australia are most disappointed with what has happened so far and we want the opportunity to ask these people some questions about these matters.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills provide, among other expenditure, $2m for the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training; $1.5m for community based youth support schemes and $1.5m for youth training. We did not hear very much about any of those three expenditures from the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom). In fact, all he had to say had very little relevance to the Bills and showed very little concern for the disastrous unemployment among Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: No one in this House will resile from expenditure that will in any way bring forward some coherent policy for youth employment and youth training. The existing short term preparation and work experience schemes do little to improve the employability and job skills of the hundreds of thousands of long term young unemployed. Everyone here is well aware of the current economic difficulties we are all facing. Every Australian family is affected by them. But, as is usual, within our system the heaviest burdens fall on those least able to bear them. The recent National Economic Summit Conference recognised that Australia must improve its standards of education, training and retraining. We need to base our economic recovery on a more productive national effort. Recovery will be temporary if we do not take full advantage of the potential of our work force. We must have the will and the courage to encourage projects to get our unemployed people off the dole and back to work. Hundreds of thousands of Australians of all ages are living in poverty on unemployment benefits.

This Government has provided a welcome increase of $4.25 in the unemployment benefit but I do not think anyone on the other side of the House can congratulate himself on having done much for the unemployed over recent years. With the cost of living as high as it is today, an increase of $4.25 paid from 1 May simply recognises the justice of indexing the unemployment benefit as we have already indexed pensions. The unemployment benefit of $68.65 is still totally inadequate. The fact that so many people are unemployed is totally unacceptable to this Government. I am sure the level of benefit also causes deep concern to honourable members on both sides of the House.

In 1974, when seconding the motion that the Address-in-Reply to the Governor- General's Speech be agreed to, I reiterated his words when I said that there were three main principles we should all take as the basis for living, and they are as relevant today as they were in 1974. They are: Protection of the weaker sections of society, equity in sharing sacrifice as well as in sharing prosperity, and the need to ensure that any deferment of expectations would not be made at the expense of those for whom deferment could mean a lifetime of deprivation. Into these three categories come the poor, the old, the sick, the handicapped and the disadvantaged including women, migrants and Aborigines and all those recipients of social security benefits. Heading that list would be the great army of unemployed who face a lifetime of deprivation.

We live in an age in which the poor are not easily distinguished from other members of society. They are not integrated into their occupational or neighbourhood communities as they were in earlier decades. A report from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development entitled 'Are the Poor Always With Us?' suggests that we would have more effect on reducing the level of poverty if we scrapped all our pensions, grants and subsidies and spent one per cent of our gross national product on a redistributive plan. However, redistribution of wealth alone will not eradicate poverty. There is a notion about that rising affluence will sooner or later reduce or eliminate poverty. Without fundamental structural change in our economic and social institutions affluence may not be a cure for poverty but may well turn out to be its siamese twin.

It is useless in 1983 to blame the unemployed for not having jobs. This attitude focuses attention on the disabilities of the unemployed rather than on the disabilities of society. It focuses attention away from the need for social change, from job creation schemes, from the absolute necessity to get people back to work and from the desperate needs of the unemployed who want jobs. Divisions have occurred in our society and will multiply without government- backed job creation policies. We will concentrate on job creation schemes, as Appropriation Bill (No. 5) indicates. Without comprehensive policies for youth, more and more young people will end up on the dole. The implications of a generation of unemployed young people has horrific overtones for the future. The social implications of unemployment will engulf us all, and to a large extent they already have. The former Government must carry the burden of guilt for all it failed to do to ensure that young Australians had a future and a place in our society.

The longer the period of unemployment, the more difficult the problems. Long term unemployment sets up psychological trends that are hard to reverse. The social cost of unemployment lies at the door of seven years of Liberal government. It is an enormous problem that this Government has inherited. I pointed out in the House in February 1982 that we must work together, Opposition and Government, to give back to the unemployed in this country their self- respect and we as a Government will now do so. The Government recognises the severity of the task. It has already moved in the job recreation area. In New South Wales technical colleges further full time pre-apprentice course places are being made available under a Federal Government offer to all the States and Territories to create 2,000 additional trade-based course places in 1983. Further community based and council sponsored schemes to rehabilitate and train long term unemployed young people are also under consideration.

It has to be recognised that many long term unemployed young people have never worked since leaving school. It would be quite useless to create short term dead end jobs that do not in any way train people for future rewarding employment. Many of those seeking work have limited educational qualifications and are so further limited in their opportunities. What small opportunities are open to them demand few skills, give little satisfaction, are repetitive, tedious and generally temporary. Such schemes offer too little too late, after young people have already been alienated from both the education system and the system itself . The greater emphasis given by this Government to youth affairs reflects our intention to develop a consistent and coherent set of policies designed to meet the needs of Australia's youth. All of us in this House represent the aspirations of the people of Australia. Working together with a will we can solve the unemployment problem that is our national tragedy and is doing so give hope to the hundreds of thousands of Australian families who in this so-called affluent country live in poverty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will, as did my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), make some comments on the funding to be appropriated for Australia's two Government-owned airlines. The Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) justifies grants totalling $175m of taxpayers' funds into the coffers of Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd by claiming to inject those Government-owned trading enterprises with additional capital. It is an injection all right, and the sting is being put on the vast majority of Australians who have little hope of ever recovering their investment either in the form of reduced air fares or returns on their investment by way of commercial dividends payable into Consolidated Revenue. By ignoring one commercial measure-that is, an adequate return on capital for, one hopes, maximised profits arising from reduced interest payments-this Government is committed to a deception which no commercial enterprise could get away with. If the Minister's Press release were part of a prospectus for capital raising by an Australian company, the authors would be subjected to the extreme rigours of Australian company law. The National Companies and Securities Commission would be in, boots and all.

SPEECH.PARA: The measures proposed will have the effect of increasing trading profit-or, more likely, minimising trading losses-over the years immediately ahead. Concurrently, the return on funds will be worse than at present. This is from a Government which, in seeking to justify the establishment of a prices surveillance authority, promises to take into account an adequate return on capital. This decision may give those to be subjected to the will of the PSA some hope because the criteria used by the Minister for Aviation confirm that his Government has a convoluted idea of what constitutes an adequate return. It may also explain why the Government could not seriously consider structuring TAA as a public company. At least it has the sense to realise that no prudent private investor would contribute capital to TAA under the conditions in which this Government is prepared to commit taxpayers' money. This commercially inept decision increases the former Government's grant of $25m to TAA to a staggering $115m. The equivalent of paid up capital is to rise, therefore, by 360 per cent in one hit. I suggest that that is enough to make the Broken Hill Proprietary Co . Ltd, CRA Ltd and other corporate giants either green with envy at the Government's generosity or blanch with fear at its profligacy. Those companies may hold similar views about the 65 per cent increase in Qantas's capital.

Trading losses of the dimensions being incurred by both TAA and Qantas would not normally be conducive to vast capital raising but it seems that under this Government commercial sanity is not to be a hallmark-shades, I might add, of Bourkes stores and ACTU-Solo. Mr Deputy President, the Minister has the audacity to assert that these measures are 'not in any way a handout to cover losses or projected losses' by the airlines. Whatever the degree of sincerity in making that claim, that is precisely their effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not wish to stop the honourable member but he is in the House of Representatives now and he just referred to me as Deputy President.
—I do apologise, sir. Thank you.
—They never learn.

—He is right; old habits die hard. While one hopes otherwise, these grants may offer neither the prospect of adequate profits nor adequate returns. In a burst of realism, uncharacteristic of the Government in this connection, it at least has had the good grace not to promise reduced air fares either with TAA or Qantas.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to another matter I wish to raise. Western Australians, even Liberal Party supporters, could have been excused in the aftermath of the March 5 election for thinking that some good may have come out of the change in government because a Western Australian was appointed Minister for Aviation. In particular, air travellers to and from Western Australia on domestic flights may have felt that they had good reason to believe that they could expect a better deal in future under the new Minister. When he was in Opposition on the back bench as merely the honourable member for Swan, the Minister had a great deal to say on the subject. Much of what he said then is recorded in Hansard. Amongst other things on 3 March 1981 he said:
With the current air fare structure, Western Australians are had both ways. We subsidise eastern States jet routes and we subsidise eastern States F27 routes.

It may be fairly concluded that nothing has changed from the time when he spoke on those matters prior to his appointment as Minister for Aviation. It is sad to say that nothing has changed since then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which State is he from?
—He is a Western Australian. During debate on the Airlines Agreement Bill the Minister, then merely the honourable member for Swan, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australians cannot, I believe, look forward with the degree of confidence they ought, to a rapid gaining of access to Qantas flights on the east-west trip.
He went on to remind the House that:
various estimates made of the value to the Western Australian travelling public of the use of Qantas seats have put the reduction of fares as high as 50 per cent.

Western Australians, and indeed others, might well have anticipated an early announcement from the Minister for Aviation permitting, to use his words, 'a rapid gaining of access to Qantas flights on the east-west trip' as he had previously advocated. The reason Western Australians may have expected access to Qantas flights may be best expressed in the Minister's words when he said:
We are paying $500 for a trip to Sydney when all we need to pay is $250 if we use Qantas.

That is still a pretty straightforward proposition as it was when he made it and one which, I might add, attracted my attention at the time. While I will not pretend that I voted against my Government's legislation when it was put to the test in this place in June 1981 because of his powers of persuasion, much of what the honourable member for Swan said accorded with my thoughts. In his speech of 5 March 1981 the Minister referred to a revelation in the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares which he termed 'a $23m per annum rip-off of the Western Australian traveller'.

Again, on April Fool's Day 1981 he said that the Holcroft inquiry pointed to the 'systematic ripping off of some $20m per annum from the Western Australian public over a very lengthy period'. While I do not suppose a difference of $3m in the short space of less than a month bears dwelling upon, the Minister is now in a unique position to rectify the wrongs that he identified so eloquently in the four or five speeches he made in this place between March and June 1981. All this begs the question: Will he secure a remedy for the $20m rip-off as he called it and which I assume would be more now if it were indexed. He may even care to make that corrective action retrospective; I notice he has never displayed any aversion to retrospective legislation in this place.

My Western Australian colleagues on this side of the House and, I suspect you, Mr Deputy Speaker, look forward with eager anticipation to an early announcement by the Minister for Aviation, on behalf of the Government, that the things he argued for and spoused when in Opposition will be put into practice under his stewardship. His powers of persuasion are undoubted so he should have no trouble with his Prime Minister and Cabinet. After all, he will have the virtue of practising what he preached in the past. If he needs any reinforcement, I will quote also from the April Fool's Day 1981 speech of the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) who said:

Qantas has an attractive proposition to offer to us, yet it is prevented from offering seats to the travelling public because, in the first instance, of the existence of the two-airline policy and, in the second instance, of a reluctance by the Government to make a change based on a fear about what Ansett Transport Industries Ltd would think about it.
In the same speech he said:
I first raised this question publicly in 1978.

Those are the words of the honourable member for Fremantle before he became a Minister of the Crown. They might be said to give a commendable perception of the problem. They might even have given an impression that the honourable member for Fremantle and Minister for Finance would work with the Minister for Aviation -both Western Australians-to ensure access to employ Qantas seats to the benefit of Western Australian air travellers. The words of the Minister for Finance should give the Minister for Aviation the necessary incentive to persevere and win over Cabinet, particularly as a Cabinet Minister also hails from Western Australia. I urge the Minister to get on with it and to make an early statement confirming that past injustices suffered by air travellers in relation to access to Qantas flights to and from Western Australia will be remedied. Many Western Australians will join with me when I ask that the appropriate announcement be made within the next few days.

I wish now to go on to another matter. It is something of an understatement to say that there is widespread disappointment amongst business entities with the capacity to maintain and ultimately to increase employment over the Government's abandonment of group taxation proposals announced in the former Government's Budget. The proposal to allow company groups to offset a loss suffered by one company in a group against the taxable income of another company in the same group, provided there was 100 per cent common ownership, was one way in which the present Government could have expressed its new found support for the business sector in a practical way and with flow-on benefits for employment.

Despite its proud boast that it will continue the previous Government's spending programs this Government is not prepared to enact legislaton to put into effect an important initiative which also formed part of the former Government's Budget package. Both the reports of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee and of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System recommended the grouping of companies as proposed by the then Treasurer at the time he brought down his Budget in 1982. There were good reasons, and those good reasons remain, for such a measure to become part of our tax laws. Amongst those reasons I cite by way of an illustrative example a case of one company in a group finding itself in a loss position for tax purposes while a sister company has earned taxable income-taxable income as it was and will now remain. In this case and in others like it it might be said that the problem can be minimised with careful planning although, of course, it is not always possible for a group of companies to so order its affairs. It should be patently obvious that each year that goes by a loss unable to be recouped within a group reduces the effective benefit of the tax loss to the group due to the impact of inflation.

It is common for a parent company to incur expenditure on behalf of a group of companies-sometimes, but not always, even the bulk of the overhead expenditure of its subsidiaries. Out of this, difficulties frequently arise for the parent company in substantiating with the Commissioner of Taxation a deduction; there are also difficulties for a subsidiary company also being required to substantiate management fees which may be charged by its parent company. Complications also arise where management fees are raised on the basis of time spent by personnel of the parent company, as well as by inclusion of charges for general overheads.

Another set of problems which will continue to arise because of the Government' s failure to honour its predecessor's Budget commitment surrounds investment allowances. Often the reason that groups of companies are established is to foster a range of specialised activities within the overall business objectives and managerial capacity of the group. It is, in fact, a sort of departmentalisation formalised in accordance with company law. The assets of one in the group may be suitable and utilised to service one or more of the other companies which comprise the group. In its professed support for private enterprise, the Australian Labor Party might have been lauded for encouraging profitability and the subsequent benefits for revenues and for the economy as a whole; but its actions, or lack of them, confirm what most of us suspected was merely election and pre-National Economic Summit Conference rhetoric. If it was more sincere, this Government would know of problems with the investment allowance and its application and allocation to separate entities within a group of companies. It would know that by simply addressing itself to the decision in 1981 arising out of the W. A. Hughes Pty Ltd v. Australian Commissioner of Taxation case.

This Government could and should have been aware of the contribution towards both survivability in business and tax equity if it had addressed its collective mind to the precarious position of private company groups. Private company groups also suffer from an inability to offset the losses of one or more of their number against the profits of others in the group. They also have to pay taxes on profits even though, at worst, the group may be in an overall loss situation or, at best, even though losses exist and payment of tax on the profitable entities eats into any overall profit. By virtue of Division 7 provisions, private company groups also are faced with the burden of paying compulsory dividends on top of taxes even though trading results would not warrant either if the total operation and accounts were consolidated as a single corporation. Corporate taxes were never intended or designed to penalise businesses where those businesses are so structured that they become another form of departmentalised operation only distinguished and distinguishable by incorporation in accordance with company law. The ineptitude of the Government in this connection gives the lie to any popular notion that it may be a sound economic manager.

The manufacturing industry in Australia does not need the additional burden which the Government's selective back-tracking on previously announced measures occasions. The adverse effect of the Government's decision is not confined to the manufacturing industry. An earlier suggestion by the Minister for Finance that only large companies would have benefited only underlines his lack of knowledge and experience. He, as the Minister responsible, deserves the opprobrium of not just those directly affected but also the entire business community. In its selective approach to acceptance of the previous Government's Budget measures and inconsistencies in its pre-election and post-election treatment of air travellers to and from Western Australia, this Government stands condemned. I hope the Australian public understands its shortcomings. I hope the Australian public will remember them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keogh Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only real part of the speech by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) that was worth listening to was when he concentrated on quoting my colleagues the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). Towards the end of his speech, he referred to the bottom of the harbour, which is the best place for it! This afternoon I want to confine my remarks in this cognate debate to Appropriation Bill (No. 6) and specifically to the proposed appropriation of $90m for the Australian National Line. This $90m, comprising $30m as a direct capital injection and $60m to enable the immediate conversion of outstanding Government loans to equity capital for the ANL, is something for which the Minister responsible and indeed the Government are to be congratulated.

SPEECH.PARA: These funds will enable the ANL to keep afloat in more ways than one. They will allow our Australian flag carrier to survive and our Australian crews to face a reasonably promising future rather than the bleak prospect of financial ruin by the chronic undercapitalisation that the previous Government seemed quite content to force upon it. Clearly, the ANL has been saved by the election of a Labor Government. It has been given a new lease of life by this Government, but it is appropriate that, as the Government requires, the ANL must take on some responsibility in the future for its survival. There is no doubt that the previous Government was fully aware of the critical situation that existed as far as the ANL was concerned, but it refused to act. In fact, that Government allowed this important public enterprise to become run down. Obviously it suited the previous Government's free enterprise philosophy for the ANL to appear inefficient and unable to compete satisfactorily with its competitors. In contrast with the attitude of the previous Government, this Labor Government is committed to the survival and to the future viable operations of the ANL.

Earlier this afternoon, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), who led for the Opposition in this debate, suggested that transport and transport policy were not really given any attention in the Australian Labor Party policy prior to the last election. Because of the way in which the election was thrust upon us by the former Prime Minister, we had very little time to put completely before the Australian people all the very important and attractive parts of our policy. I do not want it to be assumed for one moment that I am complaining about the fact that the former Prime Minister brought the election on early. As a matter of fact, I am sure that, during the seven years that he was the Prime Minister of this country, that is the only thing for which the Australian people can be grateful to him. This afternoon I want to draw to the attention of the Opposition, and particularly the honourable gentleman who led for it, the fact that that was the reason why there might not have been very much attention given to transport policy in the Labor Party campaign in those few short weeks before the election date.

The former shadow Minister who is now the Minister for Transport (Mr Morris) and is responsible for this section of Government policy has been very vocal and has covered Labor Party transport policy quite fully in the past. I inform the House that the Labor Party is very solidly committed to the survival of the ANL. That is the reason for this injection of capital into the Australian National Line. The Labor Party believes in expanding the operations of the Australian Shipping Commission to ensure that an equitable share of our overseas trade is carried in vessels that are Australian owned or controlled and Australian manned and to provide financial incentives for the expansion of Australia's international shipping fleet. We are deeply concerned that, although Australia is recognised as a major trading nation, our flag vessels carry less than 4 per cent of our annual overseas trade.

At present, annual revenue forgone in carrying export minerals alone is about $ 1.6 billion and is expected to rise to about $3.3 billion annually in 1995 on the basis of current prices. Madam Deputy Speaker, I am sure you know that the Labor Party believes that a planned and reasonable approach to the expansion of the fleet is essential if Australia is to reduce its dependence on the world shipping market. Whilst freight rates are now at an all time low, when the world depression eases and shipowners seek to recover heavy losses freight rates will almost certainly jump. Australian industry will be severely handicapped in its access to overseas markets if this dependency is maintained. The solution to the problems confronting the ANL is not simply more money any more than it is more strictures on the Line. The solution lies in a concerted and planned effort by the Government and by all sections of the maritime industry to increase productivity, to raise efficiency and minimise costs to make the Line more competitive.

The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) is to be congratulated for the fact that he has already initiated consultations which have resulted in a significant agreement by the ANL to improve its efficiency and by the maritime unions to reduce manning levels and improve their productivity. I believe that conditions of employment and pay rates for Australian workers should be second to those of no other country. Likewise, I believe that Australian workers should not, except in the most exceptional circumstances, be required to forgo any of their hard won conditions. However, I have reason to believe that such exceptional circumstances now exist, particularly in respect of the future operations of the ANL. The agreement to reduce manning levels, reached following consultations between the Australian maritime unions and the Senior Vice- Chairman of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Charlie Fitzgibbon, must be regarded as a starting point only if the appropriations in this Bill are to have the desired effect and the ANL is to become competitive again in the long term.

Manning levels, shipboard practices and hours of work must be thoroughly examined, realistically reviewed and changed if necessary. Several examples of what could be described only as excessive luxuries and featherbedding have been brought to my attention. Whilst it is appropriate, as the Minister indicated to the House this afternoon, that a committee be established to look at all aspects of the day-to-day operations of the ANL, I believe that it would be more appropriate if this examination were conducted by an independent expert authority. Nevertheless, any examination of the working conditions and the day- to-day operations such as that proposed must be very worth while and must be very welcome both to the management and the seagoing unions which participate in the operations of the ANL-and which would be looking forward to the successful operation of the Line in the future.

As I said, many examples of inefficiencies and practices that have crept into the operations of ANL ships over the years have been brought to my attention. I would like to take up the time of the House this afternoon for a few moments to refer to a practice which was brought to my attention recently. A person who sought my support in respect of representations he wanted to make outlined in some detail the serious effects that the excessive availability and use of intoxicating drink can have on the personnel and shipboard life in general of Australian National Line ships. I will quote from the representations that were put to me, to illustrate to the House perhaps what a serious problem this is. It appears that this problem generally has been overlooked in respect of the cost efficiency of the operation of ANL ships. The representation stated:

Bars appeared on ANL ships about 12 years ago . . . since that time the performance of ANL ships has dropped year by year. They are occupied at all breaks by some of the crew during the day and continuously from 3 p.m. onwards the overall efficiency of all is affected and in some cases the loading of stores becomes hazardous as beer is distributed to those handling stores and store cranes.
The view of the person who put the matter before me is:

. . . to control hours or quantities will not work and will bring about more trouble. The ships should be without alcohol in any form and that means for everybody. It means that the Master will have no liquor for entertainment, likewise the Chief Engineer . . . American ships are dry and run well without liquor. The navy has alcohol but it has regulations and discipline to manage it and we do not in the merchant service.

It is suggested that the big plus if all ANL ships were to be run dry would be that the people who were not prepared to serve would not remain with the Line and the number of accidents would be cut down. It is also suggested that time off for sickness due to excessive alcohol consumption would be reduced and the result would be an overall benefit to the cost of operation of these ships. I am not suggesting that this is a matter of major consideration. I merely bring this matter to the attention of the House as I have been asked to do. But I suggest to the Minister and to the House that this is one contributing factor. It is one of a whole range of factors which have crept into the operations of the ANL in recent years and which must seriously have affected the efficiency of the Line. The Line must benefit if this matter and other matters that affect efficient operation are examined by the committee the Minister has proposed to the House.

The difference between the attitude of this Government and the previous Government to the ANL of course is indicated by the very swift move that was made by this Government soon after assuming office to inject funds into the ANL to ensure its immediate and continued operation. The previous Government did not believe in the survival of the ANL; this Government does. The Government, in a rather responsible way, will demonstrate that belief by its support for the Line . The ANL will be given every available opportunity to get over its current problems. As a result of certain necessary changes which have been foreshadowed to date and which I am sure will come from the review that is to be conducted, I am sure that we will be able to show the world that the Australian National Line can operate as a successful and competitive fleet in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Chairman, may I congratulate you on your election as a Deputy Chairman of Committees. I regret that you are in the Chair at the moment. I have a few words to say about a speech that you made this afternoon and I would prefer to see you sitting on the other side of the House. However, I would like to pick up a couple of points that you made in your speech . I was annoyed that you seemed to take upon yourself and your party the view that you were the only ones that had a monopoly on compassion for those on lower incomes. I would think that the objective of all of us in this House is to get jobs for Australians. The position is not, as you seem to indicate, that the Australian Labor Party is the only party that is worried about that objective.
—If the honourable member--

—The honourable member will get a chance to speak if he wants to. One of the reasons I wish to enter this debate is to say a few words about guidelines for foreign investment in Australia. We are all concerned about the need to get foreign investment into this country to provide jobs for Australians who are unemployed. The Government tells us that the foreign investment guidelines are to be reviewed in the very near future, and I welcome that. What most of us are concerned about is that the guidelines will be toughened rather than, as I believe they should be, loosened-which would encourage more foreign investment in this country. Australia does not generate enough savings to provide the capital required for the development of the country. The only way in which to create jobs is to expand the private sector and get employers to put people on instead of off.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to quote from an insert placed by the Government in the last few weeks in Australia's Foreign Investment Policy, a publication of the previous Government. It states:

The Australian Labor Government recognises that foreign capital has a significant role to play in the development of the Australian economy and is in general agreement with the broad thrust of the policy outlined herein.

The insert contains one or two other paragraphs which I will not quote. The Opposition is pleased to see that the Government recognises that foreign capital has a significant role to play. I wish to raise, in the course of a few minutes this afternoon, the requirement of 50 per cent Australian equity that is contained in these guidelines. Generally speaking, development projects will not be approved by the Government, as they were not by the previous government, unless Australian equity amounts to at least 50 per cent. Two examples of the application of that policy have been provided recently in my own electorate of McPherson. Yesterday approval was given to a proposal by a company called Tanzora Pty Ltd to build units on the Gold Coast because 51 per cent of its equity was Australian. However, a few weeks ago a company called Sanko Shoji was refused approval to proceed with the building of certain units on the basis that it did not have enough Australian equity and, I might add, that there were already too many units on the Gold Coast.

Let me deal with the latter point first. I hope that we shall never again see any government reject the building of units, or some commercial activity in this country, because of Government reasoning that there are too many or too few of whatever it is planned to build. That would be a disastrous course for this country if it were ever carried through. The Government should be the last body in the country to make commercial judgments on whether there are too many or too few of something. The units envisaged by the Sanko Shoji company would not have been completed for two or three years. Even if the Government were a good judge of commercial matters, who could say how many units would be required by that time? That aside, governments should never make decisions on the basis of what is good commercially. Let us leave that to the market-place.

To return to the matter of the 50 per cent Australian equity requirement, I say that many foreign developers have great difficulty in attracting Australian capital for some of their projects, particularly the higher risk ventures. I fail to see why we should select an arbitrary figure of 50 per cent Australian equity as the basis for a project proceeding or not. Surely the criterion should simply be whether it is in the national interest. If we are talking about creating jobs in Australia, that is what serves the national interest. If foreign developers or development companies submit a proposal but can only raise , or only wish to raise, 20 per cent of capital from Australians, and the proposal is in the national interest in that it is creating development and jobs , why should any government refuse it permission on the basis that the project has not 50 per cent or 51 per cent Australian equity?

I put it to the Government that in the coming weeks, when these policy guidelines are reviewed, we should get away from the 50 per cent figure, which was arrived at God knows how or why, and consider the matter rationally. If a proposal is in the national interest and will create work for Australians, if it will be good for Australian development, let us not stick to the 50 per cent requirement. Whatever development takes place, cannot be taken away. If a developer gets half way through a project, something happens and he cannot finish it, he cannot take the project away. It is not as though he can take away the land or the building. What we are seeking in Australia is jobs. At the moment that is the main thing. That is the kind of development that we should be encouraging.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not worry about it too much when you were in government, did you?

—If the honourable member had been here earlier when I was speaking he would have known that I am not particularly apportioning blame in this matter between this Government and the former Government. I would urge any government to display more flexibility in this matter. The guidelines are to be reviewed and now is the time to have a good look at them and ensure that they are in the national interest, that they will create jobs for Australians. If the honourable member does not want to see development projects go ahead, and thus create jobs for the Australians that week after week he is complaining are out of jobs we will make sure that that fact is farily well publicised as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that it would be a bad thing if, during the review, serious consideration was given to a proposal to remove all foreign exchange controls for a period and just see what happens in regard to foreign investment. If at the end of that period the policy proves not to be in the national interest controls could be reimposed. I hear some inane laughter from the other side of the chamber. I would be delighted if honourable members would get up during this debate-they have a chance to do so-and tell us what would be wrong with such a proposal. If some emotional argument is to be put that foreigners should not invest in land in Australia, let us hear the reasons. I would be very interested to hear them, as would most honourable members on this side.

I hope that the Government will note the few remarks that I have made because the time is ripe, now that the guidelines for foreign investment in Australia are to be reviewed, to make those guidelines more meaningful and get away from the rigidity that has been applied to these sorts of proposals in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 6) provides for the appropriation of $115m for Trans Australia Airlines and $60m for Qantas Airways Ltd. Before outlining some of the issues involved and the reasoning behind our recommendations that these funds be provided, I should comment on a number of technical points.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, as to the funds to be provided for TAA, towards the end of calender year 1982 the previous Administration made available to TAA additional capital funds amounting to $25m. On that occasion the funds were drawn from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The $115m referred to in the Bill includes a sum of $25m to recoup that advance. We have proposed that an additional $90m capital be provided to TAA during the current financial year. In summary, the total funding to be paid to TAA during 1982-83 will amount to $115m, the $25m having already been paid. The sum of $115m will be made available as equity capital, that is, shareholders' funds. These funds will not attract interest. The Australian National Airlines Commission will be expected to manage its affairs with the aim eventually of providing a dividend to its shareholders, in other words, the Australian public.

We have also decided to recommend to the Parliament a capital injection of $60m for Qantas. These funds are also included in the appropriations before the House . As is the case with TAA, it is proposed to provide the funds as equity capital . Similarly, interest will not be charged and it will be up to the management of the company to aim for the payment of dividends. The proposals will significantly improve the gearing ratios of both the Commission and Qantas. As a result of them the Australian public will have provided equity funds totalling $ 130m in the case of TAA and $149.4m in the case of Qantas. The amounts involved are substantial. Therefore, I think it appropriate to offer some comment on the recommendations and the prospects we see facing TAA and Qantas in the immediate future.

As I have indicated, the funds are not provided as a subsidy to the airlines. I want to make that quite clear. I make that point not so much for the benefit of the members of this House because most of them, I am sure, are in complete agreement with what we have done. I make the point more for the benefit of the members of the public who may have been misled, or at least very puzzled, by the sensational sub-editing evident in recent reports speculating on our consideration of this issue. These are not handouts. The airlines are not failing. We are moving to fix the problems faced by both the Commission and the company as a result of inadequate working capital. In that sense, it is an action precisely comparable with the situation in the private sector when shareholders provide additional funds. As with any industry, the aim is to arrange the affairs of the business in a manner which allows management the flexibility it needs to compete effectively and to return dividends to its owners. The fact that TAA and Qantas are publicly owned-I emphasise that they will stay that way-does not alter the basic objective of performing effectively.

I have commented in some detail on that particular aspect, because I think the contrast between our decision and the approach adopted by the previous Administration offers a very instructive lesson. I except from my comments in that regard the performance of the specific Ministers with responsibility for aviation who did try reasonably hard on behalf of both TAA and Qantas during their periods of office. They were subjected to the most vile campaign of vilification in respect of both airlines by people who are now, fortunately, absent from this Parliament. Despite the rhetoric over many years, the simple fact is that the previous Administration allowed both organisations to depend far too heavily on borrowings to finance their operations. Both the commission and the company ultimately faced crippling interest problems. As a result, both were left without the flexibility which is essential for proper management in any organisation, be it government or private. Both have in recent years faced extremely difficult trading conditions which compounded the problems arising from inadequate working capital. The inattention to the question of the gearing ratio was perhaps understandable in circumstances when there was a constant increase in usage of the airways well beyond the rate of improvement of the economy as a whole. But the full impact of the economic contraction was not felt until we had moved down to the sorts of levels we have actually experienced. There has been a substantial contraction in the airways industry since that period and the gearing ratios in those circumstances began to be completely inadequate and the indebtedness positively crippling.

It would also be appropriate to note at this point that the policies of previous administrations were not limited to restriction on capitalisation. For example, TAA paid something like 90 per cent of its net profits to the Government between 1975 and 1981. It was not permitted to build up its reserves. In addition, it has been obliged to operate, on behalf of government, uneconomical services. In the case of Qantas, there are requirements for it to maintain services for social and political reasons. The list in both cases has been quite extensive. As I have said, there is a marked contrast between the private sector rhetoric and the public sector penny pinching which characterised the previous Administration and the decision we have taken to face up to the commercial and management issues involved.

I note that the decision that we have made meets the commitment outlined in the Governor-General's Speech. In that Speech it was stated that we would give consideration to the capital needs of both TAA and Qantas. It also happens to have been a promise made, an undertaking given, prior to the last election campaign by my predecessor, as spokesman on aviation matters for the Australian Labor Party, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). I am happy to be able to advise the House that we have carried out what I consider to be an absolutely vital and important election undertaking associated with the Governor -General's Speech. Overall, that Speech indicated our intentions to put this economy, and business in this community right. We are starting in this instance with two government businesses very important to the Australian nation.

I turn now to a number of more detailed comments with regard to both TAA and Qantas. As I have indicated, both companies have been working hard within the constraints imposed to improve their own situation. Qantas has sold a number of major properties to improve its cash position. It has been progressively reducing its work force over a number of years in line with the competitive staffing requirements which obtained in the markets in which it has to operate. I point out that this voluntary staff reduction program has reduced staffing levels world-wide by about 2,000. The company has also cut back services and rationalised remaining services on routes such as those to Europe where traffic has shown a major decline.

Similarly, TAA has undertaken a number of significant steps to improve market performance and efficiency. Staff numbers have been reduced through voluntary and early retirement from a peak of some 9,000 in 1980-81 to about 8,000 at present. It has rationalised services, in particular, F27 services. Strict controls have been introduced over capital expenditure and cargo operations have been reorganised. It has also taken a number of initiatives to stimulate demand through innovative fares with the object of improving its market share and from recent advice given to me it has done so with some considerable success.

The management problems of TAA were undoubtedly made worse by uncertainty over the future ownership and the nature of the airline. There is no doubt in my mind that this uncertainty damaged staff morale. We have now resolved that uncertainty and we are confident that further improvements in competitiveness will follow. I say in passing that the Joint Chairman and Managing Director of Ansett, Sir Peter Abeles, has welcomed our decision to put TAA on a proper commercial basis. I am sure that the travelling public can only benefit if competition between TAA and Ansett is conducted on a more equal footing.

As I have said, in both cases airline operations have been conducted in very adverse trading conditions. Domestically, the downturn in the economy over the last two or three years has had a very direct and serious impact on passenger traffic carried by both major domestic airlines. The international airline industry as a whole has been experiencing the most severe financial and trading difficulties in its history-again, largely as a result of the world-wide economic recession. By way of illustration, I note that the International Air Transport Association has estimated total losses by its member airlines at about $US2 billion in 1983. Despite this, Qantas's losses on airline operations have been relatively less than those of many other airlines.

I understand that one or two honourable members on the other side of the House have sought to indicate that the injection of funds we are giving Qantas is somehow unprecedented, somehow strange by comparison with what may have been done elsewhere-that is, for the competitors with which Qantas has to deal. I will point out one or two things about that. A number of other airlines, major competitors of Qantas, have received more support from their governments than the previous Government gave Qantas; indeed, they received more support than is the case with even this particular injection of funds to Qantas by our own Government. Singapore Airlines received a capital injection of $200m from its Government in 1982. Air New Zealand received $68m in 1982. The British Government, during the period 1975-82, increased the capital base of its national carrier, British Airways, by $265m. During the same period, the capital injection provided to Qantas by the previous Government was $25m. The Opposition spokesman on aviation has referred to the cost per head of the recent capital injection to Qantas. He may wish to note that the total paid up capital of Air New Zealand is $120m which is $38 per head of the New Zealand population. Singapore Airlines has a capital base of $261m, which is equivalent to $107 per head of population. In contrast, the capital base of Qantas is now $149.4m which is $10 per head of the Australian population. I have specifically cited those airlines because they are equivalent to Qantas in size and in the areas in which they operate.

I would not like to leave the House under any misapprehension that both airlines are still facing, and will continue to face, very difficult conditions. I hope to be able to table the TAA report for the financial year ending June 1982 in the very near future. I expect this report to show a small operating loss. I do not anticipate other than a substantial loss for 1982-83. However, we are looking for improved conditions and results during 1983-84. The outlook for Qantas remains very difficult to forecast and is very heavily dependent on a recovery in world economic conditions generally. Again, I think that substantial losses are likely to occur during the current financial year, after taking into account interest and other items. By providing these funds, the Government has signalled its support for and firm belief in the prospects of both these Australian-owned airlines. Both have a national importance, and not simply from the point of view of aviation. We have moved to place both airlines in a position where they can plan confidently to meet competition efficiently with a better cost structure and a sound commercial basis.

In the time remaining to me I would like to take up just one or two of the issues that were raised in the debate. I apologise to the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) who is the Opposition spokesman on aviation for not being in the chamber to hear his speech. I had certain Cabinet committee requirements at the time. I regard my failure to be present as an act of discourtesy. I apologise for it. I will attempt to be in the House in the future when he is speaking on a matter directly of concern to me.

I did hear the speech made by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). He asked what might be anticipated for Western Australia taking into account my expressions of view in the past about the need for Qantas to operate across the continent. This matter has been raised frequently by honourable members representing Western Australia on both sides of the House. The point I would like to make is that in the speech of the honourable member for Curtin there was a vast historical gulf extending from early 1981 until the present day; it was as though nothing had happened since the point of time when those speeches were made and the point of time when we came into government. In fact, a great deal happened. Principally what happened in relation to that issue was that the Airlines Agreements Bill was passed through this House. Included in that Bill was provision which meant that Qantas could not operate domestically without the express permission and agreement of the other two airlines. That was written into the two-airlines agreement not by the Australian Labor Party, not by Western Australian Labor members, but by the previous Government in revising the previous airlines agreement.

Also included in the two-airlines agreement, which in fact controls effectively the domestic operations, is a provision whereby it could not be scrapped or in any way substantially altered before 1986. We are going to commence a review of that process but it cannot begin until late 1984 in order to bring it into a reasonable time scale for conclusion at a point when we can do something about it.

I do not want to hear, at any stage in an aviation debate in this House, any honourable member on the other side of the House criticise this Government's operation of the airways systems based on a restriction imposed by the two airlines agreement. Honourable members opposite are responsible for that agreement. They are responsible for its timing and its conclusion. If that agreement is having the adverse impact on airways honourable members opposite indicate only one group of people in this country is to blame. By that, I do not mean to imply that I am in favour of the total deregulation of the Australian airways system. I think that proposition could have a very serious and deleterious effect on the profitability of the airlines, the employees of the airlines and the safety of our airways operations.

I think there is often far too much shoddy thinking on this matter in the Australian community. We do not have a market like the United States. We are not talking about a situation where there are 30 million people on one side of the country, 100 million people on the other side and 70 million or 80 million people in between. We have one and a half million people on one side of the continent, 10 million to 12 million people on the other side and a couple of million people in between. That obviously creates a very different and very difficult marketing environment in which the airlines have to operate.

Nor do I indicate by anything that I have said that I think it is entirely inappropriate that TAA, for example, ought not in some circumstances to operate effectively social service routes. That has been required of it in the past and it will probably be required in the future. There will be no interjections from National Party members from Queensland on that particular subject because I imagine that if TAA did anything else they would have a lot to say about it. The fact of the matter is that we have obliged TAA over the years to bear the brunt of government decisions both in relation to its dividends and the operations that we have expected it to undertake. Those decisions have placed TAA in an extraordinarily difficult position competitively. We have been invited by people like the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and others in the past to preside over the winding down of the commission because of the difficulties in which TAA has found itself. That situation is largely a result of the trading conditions for airways that apply not only domestically in Australia but also internally overseas and internationally. According to the honourable member we are obliged to look at TAA's situation as though there has been no history and as though the performance of the airlines between 1981 and 1983 has been preceded by an equivalent performance prior to that date. This is of course ludicrous.

As I said before, this legislation is aimed at rendering commercially viable two great national institutions. In the process of becoming commercially viable I believe that their managements will be able to operate innovative policies in a way that, because they have been living from hand to mouth, they simply found impossible. They are now going to be presented with that opportunity to be innovatory. I expect that as they become innovatory they will look at broadening the market and at broadening the opportunities to travel for the Australian public both on a regular basis and as tourists. This will not be possible without capital injection but will be possible as a result of capital injection. I think that is a development that all Australians, Western Australians and everyone else, ought to welcome. It has taken this Government to end the dithering, the inefficiency and the incompetence that has reflected the past Government's policy towards TAA and Qantas in, as the honourable member for Mackellar said, such a decisive fashion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in addition to the Leader of the House or his nominee and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or his nominee, Mr Campbell, Mr Cross, Mr Griffiths, Mr Gorman, Mr Hall, Mr Hodgman, Mr Miller, Mr Simmons and Mr Spender be members of the Committee of Privileges, five to form a quorum.

The Government sees the setting up of the Committee of Privileges as an extremely important measure. Honourable members will recall that in the last Parliament there were some difficulties with matters that were raised in relation to the operation of privileges and what it meant in the responsibility of honourable members. The members of the then Committee applied themselves in this area and did an excellent job in bringing some sanity to this area of privileges of members of Parliament and also brought great credit on the institution of Parliament and how it is used.

We have a good mixture of members who are prepared to accept the responsibility of being on the Committee. I understand that the exercise that they are undertaking is to be completed in a very short period. I hope that, at the completion of their work on this matter, we will have a clearer insight as to the way Parliament is to proceed in relation to future problems of members or of the House itself. I think all honourable members who were members of the last Parliament will agree that that Parliament did not bring great credit on itself or on the members of the Parliament in relation to their behaviour on certain episodes. When the then Privileges Committee was asked to produce a report in relation to one matter, it left greater dissatisfaction in the ranks of members of parliament than if answers had been given to the problem without it going to that Committee.

I hope that this Parliament and future parliaments will not be confronted with these types of problems. We have a clearer view of how the privileges of Parliament ought to be used. There is great cynicism among people outside the Parliament that on occasion parliamentarians do use the Parliament for too much in respect of their privilege and that perhaps there ought to be some curtailment of that power. Of course, there has been discussion of using organisations outside the Parliament to apply their judgments on what ought or ought not to be the privileges of members of Parliament. But I think ultimately you, Mr Speaker, would agree, as a person who has spent a considerable amount of time applying himself to these problems, that the Parliament itself should be the sole arbiter of the way in which it will be used. I do not think we can seek greater wisdom from outside the Parliament than that which we can apply ourselves because we are the people who must suffer from an incorrect decision in relation to the use of privilege or any misuse of privilege. By and large, I do not think that, although problems are presented to the Parliament on occasions, there are many misuses of the privilege of Parliament. But when it is misused, privilege brings great problems and traumas to the institution. I hope that we can overcome those problems in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
