Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Events of the last few weeks relating to the expulsion of the Soviet KGB officer Ivanov involve fundamental issues of national security and individual civil liberties. My Government's approach to this matter has involved placing these issues above all other considerations, including political party or personal associations. For my part I have sought to ensure that because the issues of national security extend beyond which political party holds office the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was fully briefed. He expressed complete support for the Government's proposed course of action. I am appalled that the endorsement by the Leader of the Opposition of the Government's approach was of insufficient influence to prevent members of the Opposition making efforts to exploit for political purposes a matter in which issues of national security and individual civil liberties are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision relating to the expulsion of Ivanov had the unanimous support of all members of the Cabinet Sub-committee on National and International Security, comprising myself, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes ). The subsequent decision regarding Mr David Combe's association with the Government had the full support of both my Cabinet and my full Ministry. The basis for the expulsion of Ivanov is not in question, and remains as set out in the Foreign Minister's statement of 22 April. As regards the action relating to Mr Combe, the Government has never been in any doubt about the validity of its decision. At the same time it was concerned that he should not become the object of public censure without some opportunity to defend himself. From the time that the Opposition used his name in the House yesterday, it was essential that he be given this opportunity.

Mr Combe's association with Ivanov, and the subsequent decision made by my Government in regard to his contact with it, have been the subject of several hours of discussions today between Mr Combe and the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, during part of which time the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, Mr Harvey Barnett, was present. During these discussions Mr Combe gave his detailed account of his professional activities as a public affairs consultant and his past relationship with the Soviet Union and the Soviet Embassy, and the Attorney-General set out, in the terms summarised in the following paragraphs, the considerations which have determined the Government's course of action. Following those discussions Mr Combe has now advised the Government that, having regard to all the circumstances as they stood at the time the Government made its decision, he 'understands and accepts' the Government's decision that Ministers not deal with him in his capacity as a consultant lobbyist.

The Government's decision, which was made in the first instance by Cabinet in Adelaide on 26 April and endorsed by the full Ministry in Canberra on 2 May, followed a recommendation made by me explicitly based on the following considerations:

Ministers' doors should be, and be seen to be, open without the need for leverage by a party insider; and it was not appropriate that a former party official, by virtue of that status, have special advantages or access to government denied to others.

The Ministry, at its meeting on 2 May, agreed that the Special Minister of State should bring forward a submission canvassing a possible scheme for the registration of Government lobbyists generally, not just those with Labor Party connections.

I now make it clear that there was a further consideration underlying my recommendation to the Cabinet and Ministry which was not explicitly raised with either body at the time, but which had been the subject of prior discussion and agreement by the Cabinet Sub-committee on National and International Security. The information and advice then available to the Government suggested that Mr Combe's relationship with Ivanov had developed to the point that it gave rise to serious security concern. The view of the National and International Security Sub-committee was that, as events had developed, Mr Combe either had been, or appeared to have been, compromised by Ivanov to the extent that it was no longer appropriate for Government Ministers to deal with him. The deliberate cultivation by Ivanov of the relationship with Mr Combe, and the stage that process had reached on Labor's assumption to office, was one of the reasons-but by no means the only reason-which led to the Government's decision to expel Mr Ivanov from Australia on 22 April.

It is the view of the Attorney-General and his Department that, on all the information available to them, no criminal offence has been committed by Mr Combe. There is certainly, in the Government's belief, no foundation for any allegation or imputation that Mr Combe is, or ever was, in any sense a Soviet spy. I repeat that the Leader of the Opposition has been fully briefed on all aspects of the Ivanov matter-including the position of Mr Combe and the advice of the Attorney-General and his Department-both on 21 April, the day the decision to expel Mr Ivanov was taken, and subsequently. He has expressed complete support for the Government's actions in this matter.

Let me stress what I said to the House at the outset of this statement. When issues of national security are at stake, whether they be manifested in terms of foreign espionage activities or by such means as the articles published in the National Times last week, which are prejudicial to the national interest, this Government will not be deterred from resolutely defending that interest, whatever attempt may be made no misrepresent this principled position. Nor shall we attempt to exploit such issues for our own political gains. We will remain committed at the same time to ensuring that in defence of the national interest, there are no transgressions of individual civil liberties.

It is perhaps inevitable that there will always be elements of doubt and suspicion in the minds of all Australians in circumstances where there can be less than full disclosure of information. That is a responsibility which a government must accept, and for my part I accept it. But I trust this statement will put to rest the uncertainty of the last few days, and convince all Australians, of whatever political persuasion, of the correctness and fairness of our handling of the matter. A climate of innuendo and deceit, which some have attempted to introduce into this matter, is not one which my Government will be guilty of creating or permitting to flourish. Finally, I am sure that our actions in respect of this matter, and of the National Times articles, will have made it clear to all other governments that in no way will my Government be compromised when matters of our national security are at stake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The matter to which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has drawn the attention of the Parliament has come before me, in its typewritten form, only in the last half-hour or so. The Government may have had an extensive period of time to consider it; I simply make the point that on a matter as important as this, despite undertakings to the contrary, I received only 35 minutes notice of this statement. The first point I want to make is that all members of the Opposition, so far as I am aware , and certainly all members of the shadow Cabinet and shadow Ministry, endorse the Government's action in expelling Ivanov. I made that clear publicly, and I have not moved one dint from that. It has not at any time been called into question by the Opposition at all. No question has been raised regarding the expulsion of that Soviet agent. Injecting, as the Prime Minister has, in this statement, allegations and elements of political exploitation is, frankly speaking, mendacious.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) asked why Ministers were instructed to have no dealings with Mr Combe. The Prime Minister responded in terms that have now been well publicised. The Prime Minister himself earlier had indicated that he would not depart from the normal process of not walking down the path of disclosures in areas of national security; and yet it was the Prime Minister who called into question, by dint of his answer, the role of Mr Combe in this matter. The Prime Minister is responsible for the way in which this matter has blown over the last 24 hours, for it was his answer , and his answer alone, which not merely linked Mr Combe to this affair but denied him, prima facie, even a basic element of civil liberty.

Mr Speaker, do remember that this was, by yesterday, a matter of public notoriety, before the Deputy Leader of the National Party rose to ask his question. The problem, of course, was not the question; the problem was created by the answer that was given. The Sunday Telegraph contained an article which, by implication, led to certain conclusions. The Sydney Morning Herald yesterday, on its front page, all but named the person. We learnt during Question Time, by dint of an Australian Associated Press release, that the Caucus had discussed the matter without the person being named. All these transpired before the Deputy Leader of the National Party raised the matter. Prior to that, Liberal Party and National Party members had not been involved.

The fundamental error was made by the Prime Minister, who should at all times adhere to the constant practice, as he said himself in the Parliament yesterday, practised by parties on both sides of the political fence, of not walking down the path of disclosure of matters that go to elements of national security. One can neither confirm nor deny; one can neither say that it was someone nor say that it was not someone. That is the practice that has been qualified so severely by the Prime Minister's answer yesterday. In fact, the Prime Minister compromised this Government by the nature of his answer to the Deputy Leader of the National Party yesterday. That was in answer, not to a question fundamentally of national security but, if honourable members will recall, it was a question relating to ministerial dealings with Mr Combe. And yet the Prime Minister walked right down the track of smearing without detail. These matters should never have been brought into the open. These matters do go to the heart of national security and all of these things have been brought about by the Prime Minister's inadequate handling of the matter.

The actions of the Opposition have been entirely proper. The questions flowed from Press reports and, indeed, from reports of Caucus discussions and the Prime Minister is straying from the rules. Let me turn--
Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! So far the statements have been listened to in relative silence. I suggest that that continue.

—The Prime Minister has indicated that I have been fully briefed on this matter. That is correct. I have also fully supported, as I indicated, the expulsion of Mr Ivanov, the Soviet KGB officer which, by dint of the briefings to me, clearly pointed to fundamental issues of national security being raised. I have-and I think it has been accepted by the Prime Minister-been entirely proper in my conduct in this matter. But the matter goes to the heart of the proper handling of matters of national security and matters of civil liberties and the rights of individuals. At page 4 of the distributed statement read to the Parliament by the Prime Minister, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that the Leader of the Opposition has been fully briefed on all aspects of the Ivanov matter-including the position of Mr Combe and the advice of the Attorney-General and his Department, both on 21 April, the day the decision to expel Mr Ivanov was taken, and subsequently. He has expressed complete support for the Government's actions in this matter.

That support was complete in relation to the actions which had remained secret. That support did not go to the matters made public by the Prime Minister, nor did it go to the substance of the question by the Deputy Leader of the National Party regarding, allegedly, no ministerial contact with Mr Combe as a lobbyist, a fact that I knew nothing of and had never been informed of by the Prime Minister at all. I had no notion that Ministers had been so informed. I had been briefed on matters of national security and the matters relating to Mr Combe. I had not been informed, nor need I have been informed, I assume, of whatever directive had been given to Ministers. But do not say to me that by dint of the Prime Minister's response I have therefore given subsequent endorsement to what has transpired.

I feel very grave disquiet at what has been in the last few days-which was the time element referred to at the conclusion of the Prime Minister's address-the cavalier manner in which this matter has been handled, not merely in the Parliament but also in the Caucus. There should never have been any straying from the fundamental point that these matters are not commented upon publicly or in the Caucus at all. Once the Prime Minister moves away from that position, he walks down a mine field which he has himself exploded. A judicious Prime Minister would not have spoken in the manner in which he did in this Parliament or in the Caucus. A judicious Prime Minister would not have moved beyond the normal precedent in areas of national security of neither confirming nor denying the allegations. A judicious Prime Minister would not have swept aside normal concepts of civil liberties as he did in this House yesterday and we are, therefore, forced to conclude that the current occupant of the Prime Ministership is not a judicious man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Bill because it gives effect to a decision of the former Government. The Bill follows an announcement that was made in the last Budget Speech that the penalties for late payment of taxation would be increased from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. That announcement was made because of a decision by the former Government that the old interest rate of 10 per cent had become increasingly irrelevant. It was an interest rate which had been set in 1922 at a time, incidentally, when the long term bond rate was 5 or 6 per cent. As honourable members will be aware, the long term bond rate is now in the order of three times that figure. On that basis alone, a very strong case clearly existed for an increase in the interest rate on unpaid taxation amounts. But over and above the need for that to occur, very considerable evidence had been presented to the former Government, with which the then Opposition agreed, that the relatively low amount of interest charged on unpaid taxation had been exploited, along with the then prevailing fifty-fifty arrangement, as it was known in the accounting profession, by a number of people who had been involved in very large and sophisticated tax avoidance arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: As a consequence of that evidence, the former Government came to the conclusion that the most appropriate action was, firstly, to increase the rate of interest from 10 per cent to 20 per cent to reflect more adequately monetary values and interest rates which prevailed at the time and which still, generally speaking, prevail; secondly, to abolish the fifty-fifty rule, which in combination with the low rate of interest had really acted in many cases as an incentive for people indefinitely to dispute and contest the payment of outstanding taxation liabilities; and, thirdly, as it was only fair and reasonable, to give effect to a request that had frequently been put to the Government, not only by the accounting and legal professions but also by members of the public generally, that if taxation amounts are in dispute and as result of the dispute the taxpayer and not the Commissioner of Taxation is victorious it is only proper that the taxpayer, being victorious, should receive some kind of payment of interest on the amount of tax which is refunded, just as that taxpayer is under an obligation to pay interest on the amount which is unpaid if, in fact, the Commissioner is successful. At the time this Bill was announced we had the support of the Opposition. As a consequence of that, we are only too glad to express our support for this measure and indicate that it will receive a very speedy passage through the House of Representatives and no doubt through the other place.

I take this opportunity not only to express support for some of the announcements of the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) in relation to a continuation of measures in the taxation area announced by the former Government but also to express as I have on a number of occasions my disappointment that the new Government has seen fit not to implement the decision contained in the last Budget to offer a group taxation facility to many Australian companies. This was a recommendation of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. It was a recommendation which, if implemented, would have been of particular value to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and its associated companies. At a time when the Government has been expressing very great concern about the employment situation in the steel industry in Australia and has been talking at length about the need to take additional measures to help the steel industry in Australia, it has passed almost without notice, except by the Opposition, that by deciding not to go ahead with this measure the Government is striking a serious blow at the viability of the BHP steel industry . The withdrawal of this tax provsion, which was widely welcomed by many Australian companies and their affiliates, including BHP, sits very strangely at odds with the professed concern of the Government and particularly of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) about the viability of the Australian steel industry.

I put it again to the Minister for Finance and through him to the Government that if the Government is really concerned about the viability of the Australian steel industry why is it that one of the Government's first decisions in the taxation area after assuming office was not to implement the group taxation decision that was contained in the last Budget? It was a sensible measure; it was a measure which had been sought by many Australian companies over a long time. It is a facility that is available in the taxation laws of many other countries. It was recommended in the Campbell report and I believe also in the report of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee. It can be brought in with adequate safeguards and adequate protection against abuse. It involves nothing other than a deferral of tax payments and taxation liabilities and, really, it is beyond explanation why a government that is professedly interested in the viability of the Australian steel industry should almost by stealth, as one of its first announcements, deny something which if brought in would be of enormous help to BHP. I hope that I can be given in the course of this debate some explanation by the Minister for Finance as to why this decision was taken. That matter relates to the generality of the taxation policies of the Government. So far as this particular measure is concerned, which deals with interest on overpayments, as I indicated earlier the Government will have the Opposition's total support for a speedy passage of this measure through the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The House is considering at the moment the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Bill 1983. This legislation was introduced by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) last Wednesday and he explained the nature and particular purposes of it. The former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), referred to the fact that, of all those items of legislation of which notice had been given by the previous Government, one of the three with which the present Government had decided not to persist was that which involved the transfer of losses within company groups. As the former Treasurer indicated, the chief beneficiary in Australia of that particular proposition would have been the BHP group of companies. The honourable member for Bennelong also asked for an explanation as to why the present Government has decided not to persist with that proposition. The simple reason is that this proposal would have allowed company groups to offset a loss suffered by one company in the group against the taxable income of another company in that same group. The Government is taking advantage of the opportunity to investigate further the revenue and other implications of this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the honourable member for Bennelong's request for some indication of the Government's concern and actions in relation to the problems that the BHP group of companies is experiencing at present, I think he and everyone else is fully aware of the fact that very significant and important discussions are taking place in the Steel Industry Advisory Council. That Council includes steel industry representatives as well as the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button. Those discussions are continuing. The simple fact remains that a government has two hands. It is not necessary for us to assume, as a result of this Government being concerned about the implications of that measure and deciding at this time not to proceed with it, that that necessarily indicates any dereliction of responsibility or awareness of the particular problems that BHP is experiencing. It was estimated that the cost of that proposal would vary in the first year alone from something like $100m to $200m. It is not possible to be more specific about the possible cost but when amounts of that kind are involved it would be a serious deficiency on the part of the Government simply to accept without further investigation, without further inquiry, the proposition that the previous Government was putting forward and to be perfectly satisfied that in the light of that type of cost the measure was appropriate and one which was most likely to achieve the sorts of objectives desired.

I have some personal regard for the honourable member for Bennelong and for the qualities that he brought to the position of Treasurer. It is relevant, though, that the honourable member for Bennelong should have drawn attention to the fact that there are, as I have said, three items of legislation-three items out of 16 taxation measures which had been announced by the former Government-which the present Government has chosen not to pursue. It is also relevant that the honourable member for Bennelong then had primary responsibility as Treasurer of Australia not only to foreshadow the legislation which was proposed but also to bring that legislation into effect. Some of those 16 measures which still required legislative action by the previous Government were announced as long ago as December 1981. The former Treasurer must accept some personal responsibility for that. It was a shame that the members of the Liberal Party should have forgone the degree of substance which relates to the member for Bennelong in their election of a leader after the resignation of their former leader and Prime Minister, the Right Honourable Malcolm Fraser. Instead of going for a person with some substance the Liberals chose to select someone with plenty of veneer but lacking almost entirely in substance. I suggest that the members of the Liberal Party will have cause to regret the decision that they made.

The way in which that decision was made is very well indicated by the number of members who attempt to squeeze on to the Opposition front benches. We know why most of them are there. Most of them are there as a pay-off from the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the present Leader of the Opposition; those people may have been vacillating in the degree of support that they were prepared to show to him. That is the way in which the honourable member for Bennelong was betrayed and knifed by his colleagues. We look at the back bench on the Opposition side to identify some of those people who gave support to the honourable member for Bennelong, the man of substance. We look at the front bench for those people who obtained a pay-off for their betrayal of the man of some substance in preference for the man with plenty of veneer and plenty of show but not very much substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you back there? You are a Bill Hayden man.

—We have seen them. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) has seen them. They practically spill over the edge. There are more people on the front bench of the Opposition in order just to shadow Ministers than we have on the front bench to administer a government. The Opposition front benches are not big enough to accommodate them.
—Order!
—They spill over the edge. We know why they are there.
—Order!
—In deference to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will get back to the subject.
—I believe you have anticipated my remarks. I ask the honourable member to relate his remarks to the Bill.

—The fact that the previous Government failed to give effect to 16 taxation measures indicates the complete shambles that taxation legislation was in at the time of the change of government. It also indicates the fact that the former Government was preoccupied with the need to manipulate a favourable political climate for the election. It had abandoned any responsibility for effective government. Despite the very serious situation in which the Australian economy was placed, and the very serious impositions on the Australian people, the former Government reneged on its responsibility to provide effective government and effective administration. That is very well indicated by the fact that 16 taxation measures, which had been announced by the former Government, were not carried into legislation. Some of those measures were announced as long ago as December 1981. With great credit the present Minister for Finance has indicated that of those 16 measures nine will be ready for this May sitting. Of the 16 measures, four will proceed in the Budget sitting. That leaves the three- one of which the honourable member for Bennelong referred to-with which this Government has decided at this stage not to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: The general questions in this legislation with which we are concerned at present relate to provisions which will give authority to the Commissioner of Taxation to pay interest on certain refunds of tax made as a result of a successful objection or appeal by a taxpayer against an assessment or other specified decision of the Commissioner. It will apply to those taxes which will incur a penalty tax of 20 per cent if they are not paid by the due date. There are three particular areas in which that provision applies: First, to income tax including provisional tax; secondly, to recoupment tax which is payable under the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act; and, finally, to the bank accounts debit tax.

It is appropriate that a provision of this kind be made because during last year legislation was introduced in the Parliament by the former Government, supported by the Opposition and enacted, to increase the percentage of the penalty tax for those particular types of taxation from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. The honourable member for Bennelong has referred to the reason for that. In view of the substantial increase which had taken place in government bond rates, the 10 per cent rate ceased to be appropriate. That 20 per cent application became effective in February of this year. In the light of that higher penalty tax, it is appropriate that people who feel obliged, as a result of that higher penalty, to pay the tax which is under challenge or which is the subject of appeal and who pay that tax before the due date should expect that the Government or the Commissioner of Taxation would pay interest on that money if, finally, their appeal or challenge is upheld.

This indicates also that, while the present Government undoubtedly will be firm in its approach to taxation matters, as it indicated in Opposition, it will at the same time not be insensitive to the types of situations in which taxpayers often find themselves as a result of legitimate challenges and legitimate appeals which they may make against decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation. Of course, interest will also be payable where the tax which would otherwise be refunded is applied by the Commissioner against some other tax liability of that taxpayer. As the legislation indicates, the rate of interest initially will be set at 14.026 per cent per annum which results from the application of a formula which applies the weighted average of yields of the longest term Treasury bonds contracted for in the most recent bond tender. Subsequent variations of that percentage will be made by regulation. It will not be necessary for the Minister for Finance to come back to the House on every occasion when some adjustment needs to be made. Interest will accrue only in respect of periods since 14 February 1983 which is the date from which the increase of the penalty tax from 10 per cent to 20 per cent is to apply.

The question of taxation reform in Australia, and changes of the kind we are seeing introduced now, are matters of critical importance. The honourable member for Bennelong knows the frequency and the concern with which questions on taxation reform were raised by the Labor Party when it was in Opposition. I refer to a commitment, an undertaking, by the Labor Party as a political party on taxation reform. Just last year at our national conference the preamble of our taxation platform was varied and the new preamble which was adopted states in part:
Labor recognises that the tax system has become grossly inequitable since 1975.
I intercede that that is a very critical date. The preamble continues:

There has been a deliberate reduction in the progressivity of the tax schedule, rampant tax avoidance and evasion, provision of tax concessions to wealthy groups, and increasing reliance on indirect taxation.
The reworded platform from that national conference last year continues:

A Labor Government will change this situation by basing the tax system firmly on the principle of ability to pay, on the need for an adequate minimum standard of living, and on the desirability of reducing inequality in the Australian community.

It is quite clear that the Labor Party as a political party in Australia recognises the relationship between questions of taxation reform and the whole question of equity in the treatment of Australian citizens and in the standard of the material welfare that Australian families are able to enjoy. There is probably no more important factor in bringing about some social equalisation of material welfare in our type of society than that brought about as a result of the operation of the taxation system. It is interesting that during the period of the former Government from 1975 until last year the size of the Income Tax Assessment Act increased from in excess of 400 pages to 1,100 pages. That was the situation at one stage during 1982. In 1936, the Income Tax Assessment Act numbered 120 pages. Increasing the provisions in the legislation by way of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act not only increases the size and the complexity of that Act but also is responsible for creating a situation in which some people in the community are able to manipulate the provisions of the Act in order to take unfair advantage of the actual legal wording of the provisions. That is occurring as a result of the increasing complexity of the Act. It has become increasingly easy for those people to take advantage of it.

As long ago as 1980, during the Federal election campaign then, the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, criticised the Australian Labor Party's plan for a royal commission to be held on wealth and income distribution . On that occasion he said that already there had been a large number of inquiries into the taxation system and nothing could be gained by holding another inquiry. After the Labor Party had promoted the proposal to hold a royal commission and after the election was held, the then Treasurer confirmed that the Australian Taxation Office had been ordered to prepare a range of options on taxation. Mr Howard said:

I stress that it is part of the responsibilities of the Treasurer and of the Government . . . to have a look at our tax system from time to time and to ask a few fundamental questions as to whether we have the right taxation base.

It sounds very good that the former Treasurer should have said such a thing, but did he in fact from time to time ask a few fundamental questions as to whether we had the right taxation base? I would like to pay him the courtesy of suggesting that he did no such thing. Had he done so, how would it have been possible for Professor Russell Mathews at the Summer School, Australian Institute of Political Science, in January 1982 to have made the statement which he did? This was a good 12 months after the former Treasurer had said that from to time we should ask a few fundamental questions about the equity of the taxation system or whether we had the right tax base. I ask how it would have been possible, after six years of the former Government being in office and, I think, after four years of the former Treasurer having responsibilities in that area, for Professor Mathews, if the former Government had done the job properly, to have made the following statement:

If Governments and taxation authorities were to set out deliberately to design a taxation system which would erode the liquidity that small businesses need to function effectively, which would discriminate in favor of speculative activity and against enterprise and thrift, and which would give preference to foreign taxpayers over Australian residents, it would be difficult for them to improve on the existing Australian system.
He went on to say:

If Governments were to set out, deliberately to design a taxation system which would redistribute income from the poor to the rich, which would substantially relieve the rich of the cost of financing social welfare transfers and public services, which would consciously discriminate against wage and salary incomes in favor of other incomes and capital gains, which would distort the pattern of consumption and production, and which would provide a major stimulus to wage inflation and industrial conflict, it would be difficult for them to develop a set of tax arrangements that would be more successful in meeting such perverse objectives than the existing Australian system.

The former Government engineered the taxation system; it was its chief architect . The former Government put it in place. What an indictment of the former Government's approach to taxation questions and taxation reform, that it should ever have been referred by a responsible and very highly reputed academic such as Professor Russell Mathews in words such as those?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Bill, may I congratulate you, Mr Johnson, on your appointment as Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees. I pay tribute also to the former Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees, the honourable member for Wide Bay, Mr Millar, who is sitting in the House. I think it is fair that I should pay that tribute for I know that he would have been an example to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, in the short time that you served as his deputy in that position. Certainly I wish you all the very best in the chair of judgment that you occupy.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the Bill, I wish to add a few points which were neglected by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown). The Bill itself is a measure that was anticipated in the 1982 Budget and is just a flow- on of the practice of legislating subsequently for those measures foreshadowed in the Budget. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) raised several questions as to when some of these other measures will come through this Parliament in the manner anticipated in the Budget. I note a question that was answered by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) earlier this week or later last week in connection with the number of Bills that were left over from the taxation measures. He suggested that there was some considerable doubt whether the Government would get around to proceeding with that proposed legislation.

The main provision of the Bill is that the 20 per cent penalty tax for the late payment of income tax is being offset in certain cases where refunds are due to taxpayers because of dispute by the Australian Taxation Office or where the Taxation Office is waiting for the result of an objection to some decision. The rate of interest of 14.026 per cent will be paid, as is applicable at the moment . The second reading speech of the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) also indicates that that interest will be assessible as income. I ask the Minister for Finance whether the 20 per cent penalty rate, which is often paid in advance and, incorrectly, might be allowed as a taxation deduction.

This Bill, I believe, does redress some of the inequities that exist in the Income Tax Assessment Act. The honourable member for Hunter has referred already to the vast volumes of the Act. I have heard him speak in this House on many occasions with the freedom of Opposition membership. He was able to make rash statements and promises which do not have to be met now that he has been transferred to the Government benches. I intend to refer to that aspect later. Perhaps some of those inequities about which we spoke when we were in Government will be redressed in the term of his Government. Income equalisation deposits and the averaging system that is available to primary producers might be further extended to those service industries which deal predominantly with primary industries that are subject to the fluctuations in prices, the droughts, the floods and the bad times, as are their clients, the primary producers. Those are just one or two examples.

I am glad that the honourable member for Hunter has spoken on this Bill. Going back through the records, I find it would appear that the reason he mentioned the full front bench on this side of the House was that he now sits on the back benches on the other side. He was responsible predominately when in Opposition for taxation matters; he spoke on taxation matters when the present Government was in Opposition. I pay him credit for the fact that he was born in a good year and in a good month. He is slightly older than I am, but there the comparison ends. On the other hand, the Minister for Finance, when he was in Opposition, had very little to say about taxation matters. Perhaps it is only because of the strict adherence by the honourable member for Hunter to a political philosophy or because he followed too closely in the steps of the former Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, that he has been relegated to the back bench and is not a member of the front bench. I am very sorry about that. I would have thought that , not so much because of his knowledge but as a result of the great number of words of wisdom that he spoke from the benches of the Opposition he should have been relegated to the front bench. Then again that is another matter.

In that respect I refer to the great liberties that an Opposition can take from its position. I use as an illustration an extract from a speech made by the honourable member for Hunter on 27 October 1982 concerning the terrible things that were happening under our Government as far as tax evasion and tax avoidance were concerned. I think the honourable member would give us credit for the previous Treasurer putting tax avoidance measures, at some considerable extension of the Income Tax Assessment Act, into their proper perspective and closing them off as quickly as attention was alerted to them. The honourable member is reported on page 2627 of Hansard of 27 October as saying:

The position in Australia at present is that through tax evasion and avoidance the Treasury, the Commonwealth Government, and all of the taxpayers in Australia who meet their responsibilities are being ripped off--
They would be the honourable member's words, would they not-
to the extent of probably $7,000m every year. Of course these figures cannot be refuted. They have been supplied by much more eminent authorities than I would ever claim to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was being modest.
—The honourable member is even being modest on this occasion, too . The honourable member also said:

SPEECH.PARA: Whenever I say anything in this House I will be able to support it.

The honourable member pointed out that to compensate for this loss of revenue every household was paying $30 extra per week and every pay-as-you-earn taxpayer was paying an extra $25 per week. I just mention again the figure of $7 billion and the firm commitment that the honourable member has given to us that the Government will be firm in its total dedication to the eradication of this underground economy. What firmness! A question-I think it was a Dorothy Dixer- was asked earlier this week why the Minister for Finance was going soft on the cash economy. The marvellous answer came back that this was one of the uncompleted bits of business; that he had to put it into place, as though he were under some obligation to do so. However, the $7 billion that was being claimed by the honourable member for Hunter in 1982 turns out to be a miserable $300m under firm and total commitment of the Government to close this area of tax evasion. That is the amount of money that eventually the Government expects to get by way of a withholding tax on the building industry. What a firm and dedicated commitment that turned out to be! We are going to get $300m out of an amount of $7 billion which the honourable member said he could support as being the amount that was being ripped off. That is a great start! I hope the Government goes a little bit further than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They really believe in gradualism.

—Yes, it would be good if they started somewhere, would it not? If they did, they could be gradual. These allegations can flow very softly from the mouths of people in opposition. I am sure that we will not be accused of doing that. But when it comes to putting this into effect it is a case of too much rhetoric in opposition and too little action in government. That is one of the areas that I would just like to mention.

SPEECH.PARA: Within this House we have had plenty of comment by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke ) and his disciples and converts, who now represent the Government, in respect of the economic policy of the previous Government and the projected deficit of $ 9.5 billion. Perhaps if the Government got its act together $7 billion would be available to counteract that deficit. However, I doubt that the Minister for Finance has the capacity to come to grips with the rhetoric of previous statements.

Although the comments of the honourable member for Hunter might have been made in a different context, I agree with him that the cash economy is a growing industry and is undermining our total economy. The honourable member mentioned an amount of $7 billion. The Australian of 25 April reports that Craig Emerson of the Australian National University, in a paper entitled 'The hidden economy', estimates that the cash economy throughout the world varies from 4 per cent to 30 per cent but that in Australia there are estimates that this is as high as 36 per cent as compared with the legal economy. I think that itself is a matter of some grave concern for a government, for an opposition and for a parliament. There is no doubt that the stronger the cash or underground economy the more the poor have to pay. They are the ones who are dependent on tax payments; they are the ones who probably in their own way cannot avoid or evade the payment of tax. It is the poor of the country who are suffering in this regard.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take the opportunity afforded by your presence of congratulating you on your election and upon taking the chair as Speaker. It is probably the most important role in the House. I know from the way you filled the position of Deputy Speaker while you were in Opposition that you will do the same fine job as was done by your predecessors.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was able to give some figures on the cash economy. I reiterate that it is an area that both the Government and the Opposition should be considering and trying to come to grips with. Hand in glove with the cash economy are frauds on the social security system. Both operate as thieves of the common public purse.

The other matter to which I would like to address myself is failure to keep promises that the Labor Party made prior to the elections. I appreciate that much is attributed to the projected 1983-84 deficit of some $9.6 billion, but I explained that aspect before the sitting was suspended. I would like to reiterate some of the broken promises that were made on taxes. Firstly, an indication was given by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that tax reductions would become effective immediately; that he was not promising a handful of dollars that would be ripped back after the elections. Yet the latter is what has happened.

Secondly, there has been a diminution of the promised 3c a litre reduction in the price of fuel. We were also promised that devaluation would not take place. Those promises were broken. There has been only a 1 1/2c reduction in the price of fuel which, I might add, has not yet flowed through to the petrol bowser. Not only motorists but also those who live in outlying areas where fuel is a major consideration and source of cost are wondering just what Labor's promises will amount to. The third example of Labor's failure to honour promises concerns the imposition of sales tax on retreaded motor tyres. On 4 May 1983, in response to a question on the matter, concerning which there had been not merely a promise but a documented Cabinet indication that sales tax would not be imposed, the Prime Minister said:

Faced with that decision of the Commissioner of Taxation, the previous Government took no action to upset his finding, and in the absence of action the finding would have continued to have the effect which we are to continue to allow it to have. When members of the previous Government got towards an election, they said something like: 'We may not allow the finding of the Commissioner of Taxation to operate'.
He went on:
I acknowledge that there was an indication by one of the members of the then Opposition that, if we became the Government, we may take steps to reverse that decision of the Commissioner of Taxation.

That is a major departure from a very important election promise. Certainly, prior to the elections, in view of the undertakings given by the Labor Party, the contractors of Australia, the bus proprietors of Australia, the people who run the buses for school children, were of the opinion that, irrespective of who was elected, legislation would be put into effect to ensure that no sales tax would be imposed on tyre retreads. In his answer to that question the Prime Minister glibly attempted to get over the matter by saying that the previous Government had said 'something like' what he then stated; also, that some type of indication had been given by a member of the then Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —A very rubbery answer.

—It was a very rubbery answer. One might say that it was a retreaded promise. It is something that the Government will have to live with. How many more of its promises will it retread and put forward in a different fashion? It has not yet delivered upon a promise in this respect. Always the failure to do so is excused by the extent of the deficit. In that regard, I find it incomprehensible that the deficit projection for 1983-84 has not been put in its proper light. A forward projection of that nature, made six or eight months before the actual presentation of the Budget, can only be that-a projection or estimate. I suggest that programs would have been altered in one way or the other to ensure that a deficit of $9.6 billion would not eventuate. Every promise that the Labor Party made prior to the elections has been broken. In every case the excuse given has been the size of the projected deficit. On the other hand, while the Government cannot deliver the goods in that direction it has been able to pluck out of the air, pluck out of the bag or pluck out of somewhere or other $115m for Trans Australia Airlines, $60m for Qantas Airways Ltd and, in 1983-84, $90m for the Australian National Line.
—What would you have done?

—I am not questioning the right or wrong of what has been done. I am merely saying that while Labor has failed to meet definite promises such as I have described it now seeks to provide money for these other purposes, about which nothing was said prior to the election, where do the Government's priorities lie? The people of Australia might well ask why the promises on tax matters were not honoured. I repeat, the people were promised an immediate reduction in taxation, a reduction of excise on fuel and an absence of sales tax on tyre retreads. Why should it not deliver on those promises yet provide funds for purposes which, as far as I know, were not the subject of projections prior to the election. Again, one might ask why the promise to reduce taxation is not to be honoured yet, on the other hand, the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) is able to say: 'We will put our hands further into the public purse for the purpose of electioneering funding'. One could find no greater examples of hypocrisy than those that I have given.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the beginning of my remarks, this is a measure to which the Opposition will agree because it merely follows one of the avenues that were open to us under the Budget. But, speaking to it generally, I hope that the Government will apply itself to the problem of the Income Tax Assessment Act, at its volume, complexity and the manner in which it has been patched up ever since its conception back in the 1930s. I hope that it will do what it said it would do while it was in Opposition-deliver an Act that is comprehensible, fair, equitable and everything else that it promised. That is the challenge on which the Government will now have to deliver. I do not believe that it can because Labor had the opportunity to do so between 1972 and 1975 and did nothing about it. I support the Bill and ask the Minister to note the matters that have been raised by both the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and me in this regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duffy) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 as they are related matters. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these matters? As there is no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill constitute very significant legislation for the future of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. As that organisation occupies a central position for broadcasting in Australia, these Bills are also significant for broadcasting and for Australia generally. This legislation, apart from several major alterations, is the same legislation that was introduced into, and passed by, this House last September.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation followed a sequence of events commencing with the announcement in May 1979 by the then Minister for Communications in the Fraser-Anthony Government, the Honourable Tony Staley, that there would be a committee of review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission with Mr Alex Dix as the chairman. The then Government initiated the inquiry because of the considerable criticism of the role and performance of the ABC in general broadcasting. There were also demands for a better legislative base for the ABC and for its role and independence to be better defined. As the ABC was approaching 50 years of service to Australian broadcasting, it was an appropriate time to conduct a general review. The Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission reported to the Government in May 1981. After careful consideration the then Minister for Communications, the Honourable Neil Brown, published the Government's response to that report in July 1982. The ministerial statement provided those interested in the future of the ABC with an opportunity to comment on the attitude of the Government before the legislation was introduced by Mr Brown in this House on 9 September 1982. The legislation was passed by the House and later introduced into the Senate where the debate was adjourned after the reply by the then Labor Party spokesman, Senator Button.

One of the intriguing aspects of the furore over the past two weeks over the ABC Four Corners program and allegations of bias by Senator Button is that in spite of the official ministerial responsibility for the ABC being with the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) as the Minister for Communications, Senator Button seems to be unaware of this to his, the Minister's, and the Government's embarrassment. The major purpose of the Bills is to recognise the special role of the ABC in Australian broadcasting by providing it with special and separate legislation. For the first time there is to be a charter defining the program role of the ABC. There will be a new corporate structure including an Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council to be appointed by the Corporation. A complaints procedure is to be established. One of the amendments I will be moving on behalf of the Opposition in the Committee of the Whole will be to replace the internal arrangements proposed in this Bill with an ABC complaints commission.

The ABC will also be freed of Public Service control, restrictions on overseas travel will be removed and domestic news from non-ABC sources will be permitted. All of these proposals reaffirm the previous Government's commitment to an independent, publicly accountable ABC. The events and revelations of the past two weeks, however, indicate that the present Government is not so committed. That is the reason for the second reading amendment I will be moving at the conclusion of this speech. The Labor Government has, however, made several significant alterations to the Fraser-Anthony legislation. They are the deletion of the no work as directed, no pay clauses and, as I said earlier, the replacement of an independent complaints commission with an internally employed principal community affairs officer. We will oppose both of these changes and move appropriate amendments during the Committee stage.

A new clause has been inserted in the charter for the Corporation to take note of the multiculturalism of the Australian community. We support this clause. But its insertion creates suspicion about the long term attitude of the Labor Government to the Special Broadcasting Service. This Government has already announced the termination of a separate and identifiable ethnic radio by its amalgamation or, more correctly, its takeover by public broadcasting. Does this clause mean that Labor will also terminate the Special Broadcasting Service and place the 0-28 television network under the ABC? What of Labor's so-called commitment to the ethnic communities of Australia? Other changes include the appointment of a staff director, the appointment of a union representative to the various appeal boards, a further defining of the guarantee that the ABC must maintain an adequate news gathering staff and that there will be no transfer in the short term of staff from Telecom Australia to the ABC.

In addition to those aspects of Labor's attitude to the ABC which support the previous Government's legislation and those which are different, there is a third category about which the Labor Government is not sure what it will do. In fact, it has changed its mind three times on the issue. I refer to the method of appointment of the Board of Directors of the proposed new Corporation. Labor policy prior to the election was for its appointment by a parliamentary committee. As with so many of Labor's promises, the Minister announced a few weeks ago that this promise would not be kept. Following the immediate challenge by Senator Chipp, the Minister changed this position again to one that allowed the possibility of a committee. Now, in the second reading speech, the Minister has stated that the Government will be considering how consultations can be held with other political parties regarding nominations for the new board. Does this mean that a compromise acceptable to the Australian Democrats is being considered? What other political parties will be consulted? If it does not mean this, will the Minister please tell me what it does mean?

TALK.START.PARA: —What political parties are involved?

—When the Minister was talking about the appointment of directors to the new Corporation, he said in his second reading speech that the Government will be considering how consultations can be held with other political parties regarding nominations. Perhaps the Minister can explain in his reply what he really means by that? Does he just mean the Australian Democrats or is he referring to all political parties? I ask just what the intention of the Government is, because it has changed its mind several times on this point.
—Oh no, the Opposition will get a guernsey.

—I am just making the point that the Government has changed its position from one where there would be parliamentary appointments to there not being parliamentary appointments, and again in response to Senator Chipp, to a position where there may be parliamentary appointments. Now, it is said that perhaps the Government will talk to some political parties. I would like to hear the Minister's position, and whether it still remains the same by the time the second reading debate is wound up.

SPEECH.PARA: Before moving to the three major issues in this debate-the independence of the ABC, the removal of the no work as directed, no pay clauses and the need for an independent complaints commission-I want to draw the attention of the ABC commissioners and management to the concern in country areas that there may be a change to the Country Hour. This program has been the ABC's major and very successful contribution to Australian agriculture for about 40 years. From the comments of senior ABC management officials over the last few weeks, the Country Hour is now under threat. It is under threat in three ways. There is, I understand, a long term proposal to move the Country Hour from the second to the third or regional network. Thus, it will not be available for all Australians to hear. There is also the more immediate proposal to reduce the Country Hour to only half an hour and to change the commencement time to 1 p.m. I ask the ABC commissioners and management to retain the present arrangement and not to change , reduce or replace a popular and valuable program for country people.

This Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill has omitted all the no work as directed, no pay provisions that were in the original Bill. This is obviously a payback for the financial and general support given by the unions at the last Federal election. But it places the management of the ABC in an impossible position. Management must have some sanctions if it is to manage. I acknowledge that sanctions must be a last resort, and they are no substitute for sensible ongoing consultations between employers and employees whether they be in the public or the private sector. This particular deletion is the first of what will be an attempt by the Labor Government to remove this sanction from all Commonwealth legislation. For that reason, the Opposition will show its continuing strong commitment to the principle of no work as directed, no pay, by moving for its restoration at the Committee stage.

The continuing outbursts by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button), including one he made in the Senate today, and the revelations that have followed those outbursts have created the remarkable situation that at the very time we are debating and passing legislation to strengthen the independence of the ABC that very independence is being threatened as never before in its history. These revelations have shown to the Australian people not only the lie of the Labor Government's claim to consensus but also the bullying nature of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). As numerous media reports, commentaries and editorials have highlighted, the consensus is dead and, in fact, in reality it never existed. It was a sham because almost his first day as Leader of the Opposition the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) revealed his true approach by immediately attempting to heavy anyone who dared to disagree with him. The phone call of 8 May by Messrs Button and Hawke also destroyed another myth about the Australian Labor Party-that of supporting an independent ABC. Once again the Australian media has been unanimous in its reaction to that phone call. It was a blatant attempt to influence the programming policy of the ABC.

But political interference and bullying were not restricted to the present Prime Minister. The most extraordinary behaviour, then and now, belongs to Senator Button. He claimed in the Senate that Dame Leonie Kramer had not always acted without fear or favour. He insinuated that he had damning evidence of this but in fairness he would write to her and leave it to her to reveal the letter, implying that if she was game to do so-that is, to reveal the letter-it would be self-incriminating. However, he had miscalculated the character of the Chairman of the ABC which means that he must be a very slow learner after all the exchanges that obviously had taken place between the two people. Professor Kramer, acting without fear or favour, refused to be restricted to the one-sided rule Senator Button had attempted to impose and revealed the other and more significant complaint of bullying that the Australian Labor Party had attempted to make against her. He attempted to restrict the debate and the judgment of the people of Australia to an aside about President Reagan. Professor Kramer not only corrected the actual details of that aside but also revealed the far more significant issue of the heated phone call from the honourable member for Wills.

Day by day as the television, radio and Press confrontation developed between Senator Button and the Chairman several things became apparent. First, Professor Kramer was more than a match for Senator Button. She had the facts and the cool manner of someone who knew she had the facts on her side. She has won every round of the battle and the appointment of a royal commission vindicates her overall approach to the issue. If a popularity contest were held in Australia today the runaway winners would be Cliff Young, that remarkable long distance runner, and Professor Kramer. She has done more for the status of women in Australia in a week than all the rhetoric in this place for years. I will repeat that because so many women have said how proud they feel about the way Professor Kramer handled herself in the most unfair attack that was made on her as Chairman of the ABC. She has done more for the status of women in Australia in a week than all the rhetoric in this place for years.

The second is that Senator Button had attempted to discredit the Chairman and the commissioners of the ABC so that the Labor Government would be able to appoint, without criticism, a completely new chairman and commission. Well, Senator Button has lost that battle also because the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has been forced to indicate that Professor Kramer would be on any list he proposed. If the Minister has changed his mind on that he can say so when he sums up this debate. The third point is that more than ever there is a need for legislation and safeguards in that legislation not only to guarantee the independence of the ABC but also to guarantee it in such a way that it is obvious to all Australians that the independence is safe from the behind-the- scenes bullying of the Prime Minister of Australia. For this to happen, the first thing that the Government must do is not to proceed with this legislation until the legal action against the ABC by the stood-down Premier of New South Wales is concluded. The present Chairman and members of the Commission must be retained until that action is concluded. The best way to do this is not to proceed with this legislation for the time being and for the Minister for Communications to continue or to renew the appointment of the present commissioners.

Professor Kramer, in particular, must remain Chairman until the action is concluded and she must do so for the following reasons: If she is removed from office after this attempt by Senator Button to denigrate her impartiality it will be seen by all Australians as political assassination and there will be a dramatic loss of confidence in the independence of the ABC.

Secondly, the present commissioners must also continue in office so that the defence of the ABC against the legal action instituted by the stood-down Premier is resolutely maintained. If a new commission or corporation is appointed by this Government then there is a danger or at least a public suspicion that the new commission will not provide the necessary support for the action. There will be fear that a private deal will be made to settle the action. There would be apprehension amongst those in the ABC who so painstakingly pieced the Four Corners story together over four months, an apprehension that they would be deserted after all of those months of effort by a new commission appointed by this Government which would do a deal with the Premier of New South Wales.

Thirdly, because of Senator Button and the Prime Minister, there is also more than ever the necessity for a completely independent complaints commission to be set up not only to act independently but also to be seen to be independent. The sensible way to meet this requirement is to adopt the British Broadcasting Corporation complaints commission structure where the commissioners must be independent of the BBC or in our case any commissioners we appoint would have to be independent of the ABC. The Government's proposal, on the other hand, is, if this legislation is successful, for a community affairs officer who is appointed by and employed by the ABC. The Government, in reply, may say: 'Look at part of the legislation you had in 1982 and your complaints procedures at that time.'

The reality is that the amendments that I will be moving at the Committee stage are the very amendments that the previous Government had drafted for resubmission to the Senate. Those amendments basically incorporate the BBC complaints procedure for Australia and the ABC. There is no point in any honourable member on the other side of the House raising arguments about the original Bill and the complaints procedure incorporated in it. The previous Government rightly and in response, I think, to some justified criticism, had moved away from that position and had moved to the position of adopting the BBC complaints formula which anybody who has any knowledge of these procedures around the world acknowledges is not only a fair complaints arrangement but also , equally important, is seen to be a fair and independent complaints arrangement . Because of the extraordinary situation we have seen over the last two weeks of Senator Button attempting to discredit the Chairman and the commissioners of the ABC, a complaints commission is now an even more pivotal part of the legislation . I hope that the Government will see the sense of this proposal when the amendment is formally put in the Committee stage. Because of the disquiet that the people of Australia have about the attack by Senator Button on the ABC in the last two weeks and the revelation following that attack of the blatant attempt by the Prime Minister to bully the ABC, to influence it away from its ' without fear or favour' principles and practice, in an endeavour to settle that disquiet, I move the following amendment:
That all words after 'that' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'the House is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with until- (1) the legal action against the Australian Broadcasting Commission instituted by the Premier of New South Wales is concluded, and

(2) an assurance is given by the Government- (a) that no action will be taken to alter the existing membership of the Commission until the Bill is again before the House at the conclusion of those legal proceedings, and
(b) that there will be no Government interference with the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in its programming policy'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded.
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I enter the debate on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill this evening, I congratulate the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) for bringing this legislation before the House so promptly and so early in the life of this Parliament. So many conservative Ministers have sat on their hands not knowing what to do in regard to the many complex matters involved in the communications industry. When I say 'communications', I am, of course, speaking not only of telecommunications but also of the entire broadcasting and media industries. I wish to say a few words about those broader aspects later.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation came before this House in September last year. The present Government decided that before reintroducing this very complex and important legislation it would make certain changes to it. One important change is the new charter that the Australian Broadcasting Commission will have under this legislation which is, of course, its own Act of Parliament. A new provision in the charter requires the ABC to take account of the multicultural character of our community. This is a very important change considering the continually changing character of the society in which we live. Another change is the replacement of the commissioner for complaints with the more sensible introduction of Community Affairs Offices, which was recommended by the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission entitled 'The ABC In Review', more commonly known as the Dix report. That was recommendation 19, a fact that the now Opposition seems to forget. This new provision in the Bill relating to community affairs offices, which are to be established in each State cuts out the Buck Rogers nature of the commissioner for complaints section that the Fraser Government had inserted in the 1982 version of this legislation.
I quote from my speech on 16 September last year when this legislation was last before the Parliament. I said:

. . . I really doubt the wisdom of the provision for a Commissioner for Complaints. When all the pieces are put together it makes one's imagination run riot. Imagine a Commissioner for Complaints running around with his little notebook ready for action, firing bullets at any ABC person who zigs instead of zags. This position, as it is proposed, could also be used in a rather political way . . .

I still stand by those remarks this evening. I point out to honourable members that I believe the broadcasting industry now and over the next few decades will be an ever evolving industry and one that will need constant monitoring. I therefore believe that some of the sections of this very complex legislation may have to be reviewed from time to time in the next decade as the new Australian Broadcasting Corporation settles into its new charter and operation as a broadcasting corporation.
I refer now to the Dix report from which this legislation virtually evolved. There is quite an interesting piece of information on page 229 of that report. Paragraph 11.7 states:

Provided that the ratings are kept firmly in their place, the Committee of Review consider that the ABC should be free to serve 'the diversity of interests of the Australian public', as Justice in Broadcasting urges.
Justice in Broadcasting put forward submission No. 1509 to the inquiry. The report continues:

This means that the ABC should inform, illuminate, inspire, educate and entertain. In this way, it will do much to satisfy the demand evident in the ANOP survey findings that its programs should provide for the 'general community ' rather than for the sections of the community that the commercial stations do not cater for.

I turn to page 235 of the same report where, in discussing the report of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, commonly known as FACTS and the report of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, commonly known as FARB, the inquiry in part claimed this in paragraph 11.34:
The ABC on the other hand should be more limited in its aspirations, and should be constrained to concentrate on programming which is essentially aimed at minorities . . .

We see a divergence in opinion, one could say from vested interests, in an attempt to stifle the expansion of the ABC and its interests. I hope that is not the case. I believe that in the general thrust of the broadcasting industry we have to work together. There has to be a good and viable commercial industry but at the same time we must have an ABC which is also viable, strong and able to compete. Its new charter does not suggest that it should compete right across the board. But it does give it a fairly flexible mode of operation which, under the new set up of the Board of Directors of seven to nine people, I believe should streamline the operation and we should see a better run and more capable ABC competing in many areas. Also, as I mentioned in this House before, it could possibly move towards obtaining, at some time in the future, a second ABC television network run on similar lines to the two ABC radio networks we have in Australia. That is some time off, but I can see its occurring with one of the ABC television stations operating in a more general populous mode with the other specialising as occurs in the radio networks at present.

In addition to the new challenges which face the ABC, I mention also cable television, radiated subscription television and satellite television. Probably the latter two will very strongly bring the ABC to the fore in the next few years. Decisions will have to be made by this Government. They are decisions, as I mentioned earlier, which the previous Government did not want to make. It sat on its hands. Successive former Ministers did not really know what to do with RSTV. They were not quite sure what to do with satellite television, who it was to go to and what transponders were to be used, et cetera. Those complex questions are now a matter for this Government to determine and implement its decisions. I am quite sure that the Minister at the table has the capacity and the backup to do that. He has shown that by the early introduction of this Bill into the House.

I now move to the amendment moved by the Opposition. I always thought the Opposition was hypocritical in Government. But it never ceases to amaze me. It has outdone itself in Opposition. Here we have an attempt to hold the Government to ransom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member that he has used a term that has been ruled by the Speaker as being undesirable. The words 'hypocrisy' or 'hypocritical' are not accepted parliamentary parlance.

—With due respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, I always thought that that was in relation to individuals. That term has been used in the past with regard to governments. However, I shall adhere to your ruling.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Let us get the rules straight and fair for everyone. Did the honourable member withdraw?
—I understood that the honourable member withdrew.

—Yes, I withdraw. The turnaround and the continual somersaults of members of the Opposition are quite incredible. Here they are trying to hold the Government to ransom and to hold up the passage through the Parliament of the Bill to make the ABC a corporation, all because, as the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) said, the ABC must retain its independence. Yet we know, as the Minister pointed out last week, the number of times the previous Government attempted to interfere with the ABC verbally, when the former senior Cabinet Minister, Mr Peter Nixon, on several occasions attempted to interfere with the ABC. If the ABC is not in as good a state as it should be, let us remember that Opposition members were in government for 31 of the last 34 years. If things are not right, there is only one place to look.

SPEECH.PARA: But let us return to Peter Nixon and the ABC. When the previous Government introduced the Bill in 1982 it contained provision for a Commissioner of Complaints, which we have knocked off. Clause 83 of the Bill dealt with the Commissioner of Complaints. I shall not read out the whole clause, but the headline was 'Power to obtain information and documents'. Over the page, in clause 85, there was 'Power to enter premises'. There were all sorts of powers in that Buck Rogers-type legislation, for which there was absolutely no need when we were talking about a broadcasting industry, not some sort of Mafia that members of the Opposition, the then Government of a couple of months ago, wanted to bring into the ABC. Yet here they are tonight wanting to hold up the Bill to change it to a Corporation because of some litigation in connection with the ABC . As the Minister said last week, so be it.
