If the litigation goes ahead and the ABC does not win-we cannot comment on that; that is for the courts to decide-so be it. It is like any other broadcasting company. If it enters into that sort of area, if it wins, fine; if it does not win, it pays the penalty.

When the previous Government could not get to the ABC via words or other areas, as the previous member for Gippsland attempted to do on several occasions, it went to the Australian Broadcasting Commission's appropriations in the Budget. Let us look at the last appropriation of the Labor Government under Mr Whitlam in 1975. The appropriation then was $132.1m. After three years of the Fraser Government, in 1978, the appropriation was $141.5m. That is a rise of a little over 7 per cent. In fact, at that stage inflation would have been in excess of 33 per cent. So there was a real reduction of 26 per cent or 27 per cent in just three years of appropriations for the ABC under the Fraser Government. That Government did not interfere with the ABC-oh no; it just tried to strangle the ABC to death. Yet Opposition members have the audacity to come before the House tonight and support an amendment which the honourable member for Murray has moved, which will not be successful in trying to stifle the ABC once more. It is not on. This Government has a resolve to bring this legislation into operation and, thus, the new Corporation. It will be an independent corporation. It will not be interfered with by the present Government, nor, I hope, by successive governments, no matter what their political persuasion. It is a disgrace that we have this sort of amendment before us tonight. It really is getting down to the depths.

Rational debate from the Opposition is rather hard to get these days. The honourable member for Murray alluded to the nominations to the board. That is a separate issue. There will be fewer board members than there are members of the Commission, so someone will have to miss out. There will obviously be a reorganisation of that. But we have bowed to the greater wisdom on this occasion of the former member for Diamond Valley who included the nominations provision that exists in this legislation. We opposed it at that time, but we felt that that part of the Bill to set up this Corporation was best the way that it was.

However, I remind the House of what I said earlier: The broadcasting industry, more than any other industry, is an ever-evolving industry which will need to be monitored. There may well be changes in a number of areas as the ABC settles down to finding out what is really working smoothly and whether there are any hiccups. Then it would come back to the Government and say: 'Surely we can refine this area or that area for the betterment of the ABC and the broadcasting industry so that we can have a strong broadcasting industry with government and private enterprise working together'. Until we have that, and not self- interested parties trying to push their own barrow, we shall not have the sort of industry and the quality of program that I am sure we would all like. Once again, I congratulate the Minister. The amendment is a disgrace to the Parliament, and I am sure that it will be defeated. I strongly support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The events of the last two weeks have brought into focus the great need this country has to maintain the integrity and the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and how that integrity and that independence can be challenged and can be eroded by a determined government or by determined politicians. It is on the basis of that general principle that I support the amendment which has been moved and the amendments which have been foreshadowed to the Bill. It is impossible, as I think all honourable members would agree, to over-emphasise the importance of the ABC to the Australian community, and it is equally as impossible to over-emphasise the importance of its independence and its integrity and how independent and how honest it is judged to be by the Australian people. If the Australian people judge it to be wanting or judge it to be subject to political pressure, its stature will be eroded, and that will be a very great loss to all of us.

SPEECH.PARA: From looking at some of the clauses of the Bill, from what the Government itself proposes, it becomes quite apparent how important the independence of this organisation is. For example, in the charter of the Corporation, which is provided for in clause 6, provision is made for 'innovative and comprehensive broadcasting and television services of a high standard', which is what we have come to expect of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The Corporation shall take account of 'the responsibility of the Corporation as the provider of an independent national broadcasting and television service to provide a balance between broadcasting programs and television programs of wide appeal and specialised programs'. But the same clause provides that nothing in it shall be taken to impose an enforceable duty on the Corporation.

The duties of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Board are laid out in clause 8. They include the maintenance of the independence and integrity of the Corporation and ensuring that the gathering and presentation by the Corporation of news and information is accurate and impartial according to the recognised standards of objective journalism. That is precisely what we seek to maintain and it is precisely what the actions of the gentleman who may be described as the senior Minister for Communications, Senator Button, and the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) have called into question. So when we hear somebody from the Government benches saying that the ABC will not be interfered with by this Government and we recall what we have learned about the actions of the Prime Minister and about the actions of Senator Button, those kinds of statements can only be treated with the contempt that they deserve, not by this House but by the Australian people.

The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) said someone will have to miss out when the Board is constituted. One should ask: Who will that be? When one looks at the composition of the Board, one realises that it is in the composition of the Board that the rock is to be found on which the integrity of the ABC is to be set, and if that Board is not impartial, if that Board is not impeccably neutral, not only may the ABC become the subject of political influence but it may also be judged by the Australian people to be the subject of influence. That reinforces the reasons for the proposition which is advanced here by the Opposition. Indeed, Senator Button, in his capacity as senior Minister for Communications, reaffirmed the necessity for the impartiality of the Board when he said in the Senate that Mr Staley had a genuine concern for the independence of the ABC and that the proposed appointments were, to his mind , impeccable. That is the kind of situation that we look for in the ABC. But I wonder whether the Government will be putting forward to us proposed appointments which are impeccable or whether the Government will be seeking to put in place in the ABC as Board members individuals whose political sympathies lie with the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be people of integrity.

—There comes the interjection which indeed explains everything that we need to know about how the Labor Government would go about appointing people to the ABC. The honourable member says that they, that is to say, anybody who supported the Labor Government, would be people of integrity. That is the answer which comes out of a mind which one might say is constantly in neutral while the voice keeps going on.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to two major provisions which are foreshadowed as amendments by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). The first relates to the no work no pay provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not seen them yet. Have you got copies?
—I understand that these amendments have been foreshadowed and therefore I propose, subject to any direction, to speak to them.
—Are you going to give us a look at them at some stage?

—The Minister for Communications asks whether we will give him a look at the amendments at some stage. He is not going to tell me that he has never looked at them or that he has no understanding of what is contained in them, is he? No, he is not. We in this Parliament all understand what is meant by no work no pay provisions. But what is the converse of that proposition. If a person does not work in accordance with directions given to him-that is, no work as directed-he can be paid. That, as a proposition to be applied to any responsible group of people, is perfectly grotesque, as I think any honourable member here would agree. Would anyone here say that an organisation can be efficiently and properly run if those in it are entitled to ignore lawful directions and still be paid? On what possible basis of commonsense or logic can that kind of nonsense be supported? And yet that is what the Government will approve. It will propose that it does not matter whether a person ignores lawful directions; it does not matter indeed what a person does-that person will still be paid. That is the first of the massive capitulations to the Left, the first of the many that we will see in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: Does anyone suggest that that kind of conduct or approach would be tolerated anywhere else? Does anyone suggest that that is a rule that should be applied to private industry? Does anyone suggest that if an employee of a private organisation does not do what he was lawfully directed to do he should be paid? If it is not suggested that that should apply to private industry, there is no basis on which it can be applied to a public corporation, because that public corporation has great responsibilities to the Australian public, responsibilities which simply cannot be fulfilled unless those who work for the organisation obey lawful directions.

Lastly, let me come to the question of the complaints tribunal. What is proposed by the Government is that there should be an individual, quaintly entitled a community affairs officer who is, as I understand it, an employee of the ABC. What kind of independence, what kind of standing will he have to entertain serious complaints against the ABC? What kind of authority will he have? If the Government is serious about its expressed desire that the ABC should be independent, that it should be an organisation of honesty and integrity, why then would it resist the kind of complaints tribunal to which the honourable member for Murray has referred, a tribunal which is modelled on the British Broadcasting Corporation example and a tribunal which, by reason of the nature of the appointment of its members-that is to say, appointments by the Governor-General for a period not exceeding five years-is in a position of complete independence? If complaints are to be entertained and a member has a complaint to make against the ABC would he not prefer that that complaint go to a tribunal which was quite independent, whose integrity and authority could not be challenged? The greater the authority, the greater the independence of this complaints tribunal, the greater the public confidence in it. I believe that most honourable members hope that there will be great public confidence in the ABC and its future operations. That can be achieved only if its membership is not only independent but also seen to be independent and if there is a proper independent and authoritative means of dealing with complaints against the ABC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill 1983 and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, I recall my speech in this House in March last year and my considerable concern regarding the obvious intention of the Liberal Government to change the whole character of the Australian Broadcasting Commission as an independent public broadcaster. This Bill satisfies many of the problem areas which I outlined in my comments last March. Before commenting further on the new Bill I would like to make some comments about the present dispute between the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and the Chairman of the ABC, Dame Leonie Kramer. This particular dispute has been magnified and distorted beyond all reasonable limits by the national media and also by the Opposition. It is inevitable that there will be occasional disagreements between a government of the day and a national broadcaster over the political nature of the content of some programs.

SPEECH.PARA: What is not inevitable, what in my view is completely irresponsible, is the national media giving such a dispute the editorial and front page prominence which this particular aspect of the issue has received over the past week. I am not arguing that the content of the Four Corners program itself should not be given prominence by the media. What I am arguing is that the prominence given to the dispute is destructive and negative, and I strongly suspect that it is the beginning of a deliberately orchestrated attempt to destabilise the Government. That leading members of the Opposition, who themselves have been implicated in corrupt practices, should be heading the attack on the Government seems ludicrous in the extreme. These same people, who were decisively rejected by the Australian people just two months ago, are now trying to beat up an issue, to use the jargon of the media, in an attempt to prevent the Government carrying out its election program of economic reconstruction and a redistribution of wealth to the poorer sections of our community.

Now, to cap it all, we have the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). It is another blatant attempt to stop the Bills proceeding through the House. What is it in his amendment that has any relationship to the Corporation which we are setting up-a corporation which will give the ABC the independence it has needed for the past 50 years? This amendment will be rejected decisively by this side of the House.

The Bill will provide the Australian people with a public broadcasting media which will no longer be constantly under pressure to emulate the commercial broadcasting system. The charter of the Corporation, as set out in clause 6 of the Bill, explicitly states that the Corporation will provide programs which contribute to national identity and will inform, entertain and educate. It will provide overseas listeners with programs which reflect Australian attitudes and will promote music, drama and other performing arts in Australia. The charter requires the Corporation to uphold standards and to take account of the multicultural nature of Australian society. It is indeed an exemplary charter and will, subject to the necessary finance being provided by the Federal Government, mean that the Corporation has a firm base on which to build the new style of broadcasting more fitting for the social and political challenges of the next 15 years leading to the twenty-first century.

I have the hope and indeed the anticipation that many of the present programs which are mediocre-at the worst, plain bad-will disappear from the ABC. I hope that we will see news broadcasts which reflect the varying political strands of Australian society. For too long have we had to put up with a news service which reflects the views of the powerful establishment. We need more news commentaries which are challenging and innovative. The broadcasting of programs which attack leading political figures in our society might produce high ratings but I want to see more critical programs about the subversion and corruption of our society by powerful interest groups-the same interest groups that support members of the Opposition. For example, since the Four Corners program was cut from 45 minutes to 30 minutes it has been a shadow of its former glory. The extra 15 minutes makes all the difference between a program of some depth and one which is superficial and narrow in breadth. This has been particularly evident on the occasions when the program has been divided into two segments in order to cover an issue in some reasonable depth. I also hope that we will see a diminishing of the present constant repetition of overseas comedy programs.

I turn to the charter. It is interesting to note that the Australian Broadcasting Commission was originally created in 1932 because the existing commercial broadcasting system provided no national coverage for the less populated areas. Unlike the British Broadcasting Corporation, which was created for the public good, the ABC was created for pragmatic reasons. According to the BBC historian, Asa Briggs, Lord Reith, the founder of the BBC, and his colleagues were attributed with the view that 'wireless . . . was an instrument of public good, not a means of handling people or pandering to their wants'. To my mind, the charter of the ABC conforms to the high ideals attributed to Lord Reith. It has distressed me to note over the past few years an increasing tendency by the ABC to see the higher audience rating of commercial broadcasters as a reason for copying the mass entertainment style of commercial radio and television stations. Since the early days the ABC has had to face the superior coverage gained by the commercial broadcasters years before the ABC was created. The ABC has never been able to recover the lost ground and at present it commands only 15 per cent to 20 per cent of audiences as opposed to the 75 per cent to 80 per cent rating enjoyed by the commercial stations. ABC radio has always maintained a high standard in program content over the years although sporting coverage does seem to be one item which takes up too much program time, to the detriment of other programs. Unfortunately the ABC television programs have not followed the fairly high standards set by ABC radio. It has been quite evident that the ABC has been concerned about its low ratings to the extent that it has endeavoured to compete with commercial television by providing mass entertainment type programs. The charter as laid down in clause 6 (2) makes it clear that:
(a) the Corporation shall take account of-

. . . (iii) the responsibility of the Corporation as the provider of an independent national broadcasting and television service to provide a balance between broadcasting programs and television programs of wide appeal and specialised broadcast programs and television programs.

At present the ABC falls far short in its offer of television programs which provide material for minority interest groups in the community. The prime example is the constant emasculation of programs containing political comment either by shortening the program, by moving its time slot or by changing the reporters and commentators because they appear controversial to a shrill conservative minority. It is ironic that the present controversy over one Four Corners television program is the exception which proves the rule. The Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission stated that the ABC 'had failed to reflect the realities of Australian society, particularly the needs of Aboriginals and non-Anglo-Saxon Australians'.

I believe that ABC television has failed to reflect the needs of those groups in our society which challenge the Australian establishment- feminists, unionists, reformers and conservationists. They are all given as little attention as Aboriginals and non-Anglo-Saxon Australians. The ABC should not attempt to ape the commercial channels but should provide the type of intellectually stimulating material which the commercial channels, chasing as they do the advertising dollar, will not provide. I do not wish to go too far with my criticisms. Whilst I believe that the ABC should offer programs of intellectual quality, it is no good if those programs appeal only to an educated elite. Intellectual quality does not mean offering programs the aesthetic or educational content of which are so obscure to the average viewer that the viewer turns to the commercial channels for light relief. On the other hand, giving the public what it apparently wants in the form of trivial pop music or comedy shows is prostituting public broadcasting.

Turning now to the appointment of the board of directors and the managing director of the Corporation as set out in clause 12 of the Bill, we come to an area which produces a great problem for all governments dealing with national public broadcasting systems. In Holland, Germany and Italy different solutions have been attempted to deal with the problem of political balance and freedom of operation for broadcasting corporations. The ABC is modelled on the British Broadcasting Corporation and yet there has been far more criticism in Australia about the Government appointees to the governing board than in Britain. Generally speaking, the BBC has been far more non-political than the ABC. The reason for this must lie in the political nature of the appointments made by successive Australian governments. To that extent I hold conservative governments responsible in their blatant partiality, particularly in the rapid replacement of the Whitlam Australian Labor Party Government appointees by the Fraser Government in 1976.

An interesting thing is that the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender ) questioned the fact that we want to appoint people of integrity because he thinks those people will support the Labor Party. If that is what he thinks, that is up to him. I hope that it is true. We will be appointing people of integrity. Contrary to the exercise of naked power by the Liberal Government, the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has said that consultations will be held with other political parties regarding nominations to the board. From the interjections that the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has been trying to make I guess he does not want to be consulted. It seems to have escaped the notice of members of the Opposition, in their blind attachment to and obsession with the current disagreement between Senator Button and Dame Leonie Kramer, that this undertaking has been made. The public broadcasting system in Holland is fragmented because of the access of various interest groups. The systems in Germany and Italy are fragmented because of divided political loyalties. The Australian method of government appointees could work if there were good faith on the part of the Opposition. It has been suggested that the board of directors should be appointed by a public corporations appointments body but such a system is equally flawed by the problem of who makes the appointments to the public corporations appoinment body.

Incidentally, although it is a peripheral matter, with reference to sub-clause (5) of clause 12 of the Bill, why cannot the government draftsman get used to using the neutral gender? It is not good enough when we are all aware of the problems of sexual discrimination to say that he means he or she in legal documents. It is not a trivial matter. As I have mentioned earlier in this speech, the current unhealthy publicising of a disagreement between the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Chairman of the ABC is a blatant and historical attempt by the Opposition to lead the debate away from the importance of this Bill which will give independence to the Australian Broadcasting Commission. In my speech last March I mentioned a number of matters which I am pleased to note have been incorporated in the present Bill. I am particularly pleased to note the decision of the Government that one of the part time non-executive members of the Board will be a staff elected director. This will bring to the board the experience of a professional broadcaster who will at the same time represent the interests of the staff of the Corporation.

Industrial democracy is a vital part of ALP policy, and staff representatives should be appointed to the boards of all public corporations. In this respect the establishment of a joint consultative committee under clause 81 is also a welcome initiative. The consultative committee will comprise representatives of the corporation, staff association and officers and full time employees. It should be an excellent vehicle for the exercise of decision-making by employees in the day to day running of the Corporation.

Another matter on which the Government has quite properly taken action is the rejection of the proposed office of commissioner for complaints. As I mentioned in Committee last September, the sole purpose of the proposed commissioner for complaints was to provide an institutionalised channel for noisy, conservative and bigoted critics to organise campaigns designed to stop the ABC from reporting or commenting objectively on the political, social and economic aspects of Australian life.

Clause 82 refers to the appointment of a community affairs officer who would deal quite adequately with factual errors or invasion of privacy in the broadcasting of televised material. This clause has my full support. Clause 11 of the Bill deals with the establishment of advisory councils and committees which will advise the board of directors of the Corporation on matters relating to broadcasting and television programs in a State, Territory or region of Australia. I commend the Government on the introduction of the advisory councils which will enable the opinions of the societies represented by the councils or committees on programs of the ABC to be presented in an organised form for the ABC board. It is a system which will help rather than hinder the development of the ABC. In Britain the BBC has developed a large range of such advisory and consultative bodies and they prove a vital forum for people who are interested in improving public broadcasting. The creation of advisory councils was suggested by the Dix Committee but the previous Government ignored the recommendation.

Clauses 67 to 72 deal with financial matters, and I am quite sure that unlike the previous Government an ALP Government will ensure that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has adequate funding to support its important role as a national public broadcaster. In fact, in the seven years in which the Fraser Government was mishandling the Australian economy it deliberately cut the funds of the ABC to the extent that it was necessary to phase out programs and allow a rundown of staffing levels. Over the period of seven years of Fraserism the ABC budget was cut effectively by 28 per cent and there was a loss of 1,000 staff members.

I have not gone through the Bill clause by clause seriatim but rather I have highlighted certain aspects of the Bill which I believe to be important. I would not like to leave my comments on the Bill without referring to clause 28 which sets out the powers of the Corporation in relation to the establishment and maintenance of orchestras and the holding of public concerts. In this respect the ABC concerts and its general treatment of music has been exemplary. Unfortunately a lack of funding has forced the ABC to cut back on its musical programs but the existing concerts remain of high quality. It is a great relief to me that the Government rejected the retrograde recommendation of the Dix Committee to transfer the ABC orchestras to the States.

In concluding my remarks I want to make it clear that, whilst I have been critical of the ABC for pandering to the mass media entertainment, I also believe that the Commission has provided Australians with many good innovative programs over the years: Programs like Four Corners and This Day Tonight were copied by the commercial stations. There have been excellent documentaries, television plays and musical programs. Its news and current affairs programs, both on radio and television, and despite my earlier remarks, have set a very high standard. The ABC has achieved much in its role as the only national public broadcaster and the people on the opposite side of this House have been its enemies for many years. I believe it will be better with its new charter, and I commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I congratulate the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) on his election to the Chair and I also congratulate our two new lady Deputy Speakers, the honourable members for Henty (Mrs Child) and Lilley (Mrs Darling). As was noted in the Press, that was quite an historic occasion. I wish to mention all the new honourable members to this weird and wonderful place, the House of Representatives, on both the Opposition side and the Government side. There are quite a lot of new members on this side of the House and I as a very new 'old' member welcome them here.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the two Bills that we are discussing is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983. That is quite a mouthful but it really means that the title of the Australian Broadcasting Commission is to be changed by this legislation to become the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The Corporation will be an incorporated body coming under the jurisdiction of the companies legislation. This change will increase the accountability of the ABC as well as the level of information which it must provide to the public. I think it is important that the ABC should become more open to the public and that it should not be run as a commission and as a government body to the extent that it has been, although it will still have some direction from the Minister in charge. The ABC must provide access to the public. The public will be able to sue the Corporation and the Corporation will be able to sue the public, if necessary. Of course, one of those suits is in train right now. That is one of the reasons why we on this side of the House have moved the amendment. We do not wish this Bill to proceed in its present form. We think it is most important that the writ that has been issued against the ABC by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, should be heard before any basic changes are made to the structure of the ABC and in particular to its staff and management body.

The present Commission is subject to more government control than the present legislation proposes. The present Act gives the Minister direct access to programming. Under the provisions of clause 78 in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill, similar power is not proposed. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill gives the ABC a charter and empowers it to appoint a board of directors. The Managing Director will be appointed from within that board, which will comprise of six to eight people, and his term of office will be for a period not exceeding five years. The Bill provides the Corporation with full powers to operate as an effective and independent national broadcasting and television service.

The Corporation will have power also to make use of the new Domsat satellite system which will come into service in mid-1985. This project was one of the major initiatives of the previous Government. An amount of approximately $350m will be spent on that program from its commencement last year to 1985. This system will be a great benefit to inland Australia in which I and many other members have a direct interest. It is a fact of life that many Australians do not receive any television or wireless reception. Under the new technology which the satellite offers, those people who presently get no television reception whatsoever will receive some sort of reception.

The Domsat satellite and the HACBSS system-that is, the isololated homestead system which provides a service to children in outback Australia who presently have very little access to educational facilities-will provide television reception in those very isolated areas. Groups of small townships, stations, Aboriginal communities and all sorts of people scattered throughout inland Australia will be able to make use of that service. I hope the Government will stick to the promise it made at Griffith in the electorate of Riverina when the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, launched the Government's rural policy. The Government guaranteed it would use the concept of T.V. Australia, using the present Intelsat IV satellite for directing services into inland Australia. Presently we have use of Intelsat which gives an oval-shaped cover from Australia to Indonesia and Hong Kong. That presently provides various parts of Australia with ABC reception through the ground receiving dishes which are in place in areas such as Birdsville, Bedourie, Quilpie, Wandoan and Taroom. These are small areas of isolated pockets of people. They are able to receive ABC television through that system.

T.V. Australia offered to the previous Government and now to the Labor Government the concept of using the present Intelsat system at night to record and to rebroadcast the television programs that will be beamed from stations in our capital cities to inland Australia. I believe that this is a very worthwhile project. I know that the Labor Government has cut back on most of its promises. In fact, it has not kept any of its promises. The only promise it has kept is to increase taxes. Of course, that will happen at Budget time or in the form of a mini-budget at the end of this session. I hope that the Government will keep to its promise to provide inland Australia with a television service at this time. It is a very worthwhile service and many people are looking forward to seeing television in their own homes for the first time. As I say, lots of communities still have not seen it.
The other concept of communications which comes under the ABC's ambit is radio. At this time I wish to put in a plug for the Charleville radio station.

TALK.START.PARA: —Send a cheerio call.

—Yes, I will. Of course, people cannot get radio reception at Charleville. There is no radio reception at Charleville so nobody will hear my call. Charleville is a community of 5,000 people. In the middle of the day its residents cannot hear ABC radio. There is a small commercial transmitter there that has a broadcasting radius of about 50 miles. Once one drives out beyond that range one hears nothing except the chirp of the bullfrogs and the sound of the corroborees. While the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) is present in the chamber, I ask him to guarantee that the Government will provide an ABC radio station at Charleville. In last year's Budget, there was a provision of $ 30,000 for the purchase of property in Charleville. That land still has not been purchased. There was also an ongoing allocation of up to $800,000 for a radio transmitter in Charleville. I expect the Minister to commit himself to that project, because if he does not I might be thrown out of office! I expect the Minister to reply to that plea when he speaks. I hope that he will give me an absolute guarantee that that station will go ahead. It is most important that those people who do not have a television service at least have wireless facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Another change that will take place concerns the lifting of the ban on political broadcasting 72 hours before election day. No doubt most of the public -some of them are present in the gallery-welcome that pause in electioneering. I do not know why the ban is being lifted. I always think that as politicians we have more than adequate time to convince the public at large what great fellows we are. Can we not do that within the period before the 72-hour ban. I think the period of the blackout is a wonderful time to switch off, to settle down and to think again about for whom one will vote. I cannot see any rhyme or reason why that ban should be lifted.

In my part of the world those who receive television transmission get only the ABC. After one has watched half a dozen Four Corners programs, with Nationwide blasting at one every week night, one is quite keen to see a pause in the campaigning. Many people in my electorate said that they would vote for the Australian Democrats. They were sick of the polarisation of the electorate. They had only the ABC to watch, and the Liberals and Labor members were at one another's throats for three or four weeks. They were very pleased that the ban existed.

Some of the other amendments concern the integrity of the ABC. I believe this is something for which we can never really legislate. There is always controversy surrounding the ABC; and there always will be. There have never been two minds which think alike. It does not matter who is in charge of programming or who is the producer. Obviously those people are educated and they have some beliefs, be they religious, political or whatever. In such circumstances one cannot help but have a program slanted. I think it is most important that the directors are the people who really should be controlling what goes into programming. I think it is very important that we make sure that the right people are appointed. Now that the ABC will be a corporation I think it will be most important for us to see that the right people are appointed as directors and that from those directors we get the very best managing director that we can .

I get lots of complaints because, as I say, the ABC is really the base station in my electorate. I say to people that if they are really upset about the ABC they should phone the Commission, talk to its officers and see whether they can get their own point of view across. I tell these people that nine times out of 10 the Commission is quite happy to accept what they are saying and to put their point of view across. Most news gathering services are usually short of news. The exception is this place. This is probably the only place in Australia which does not run out of some sort of intrigue. However, I can assure honourable members that the electorate of Maranoa is not necessarily overrun with political intrigue all the time. As I say, news gathering services are really quite short of news. I find that they are always prepared to run the opposite side of the story.

I think that the ABC generally does a brilliant job for us. The Commission is really involved in a service industry. It is paid for by the taxpayer. The approximate allocation for ABC television last year was $127m. The allocation for radio was about $60m. In this year's Budget we will be looking at an allocation of about $200m for the public servicing of television and radio broadcasting. I think that the ABC does a brilliant job for people who are prepared to look at something different from the programs broadcast by commercial stations. Of course, the ABC goes in for a lot of current affairs programs. However, I believe that those of us who have nothing else to look at find those programs very interesting.

The Bill proposes that there will be no advertising on the ABC, and I think that is probably a good feature. I know that our Government talked about allowing advertising. However, I see in the Bill that no advertising will be allowed. The Bill also provides for the appointment of community affairs officers. I just wonder who they are going to be. Are they again going to be the local postmasters who also have the job of vetting people in respect of Australian citizenship? Nobody has told us just whom the people referred to in clause 82 might be. If this is the way the Labor Government is going to set up a complaints area, I think it is most important to establish just who the community affairs officers are going to be. Are these people going to be members of the Australian Labor Party?

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't be members of the National Party.

—I am hoping that they could be. It is most important that the right people are appointed. As I say, not only does the poor overworked postmaster have to run his post office but also he has to vet people for naturalisation purposes. It now looks as though he has to be the complaints officer for the local ABC radio station. His work is really going to be cut out if that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to mention a couple of complaints that people in the bush have with the ABC. We find it very difficult to get a coverage of the test cricket, the Melbourne Cup and now rugby league football. Of course, we play league in Queensland, not that aerial ping pong stuff that they play in the south. I would like to put in a complaint about the fact that no longer can the people of inland Queensland get a coverage of rugby league matches. I think that is no good for the football supporters. After the Minister for Communications has dealt with the establishment of a radio station at Charleville I would like him to solve the other problem. No rugby league matches are shown on television in that part of the world. At present there is none. I would like the Minister to ensure that sufficient funds are made available to allow the ABC to bid on league television rights so that the people in my part of the world, many of whom play rugby league, are able to see not only the local games but also the Sydney league replays.

The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) mentioned that all sorts of interested groups have access to the ABC. I would have thought that these groups get more than enough time. The greenies are on about kangaroos and God knows what. Every time one turns the television on one sees the greenies or radical groups. The same people are always involved. They are always involved in every march one sees on television. I can assure honourable members that these people get more than enough access. I think that rural programs should get a greater amount of time on television. They get only about a quarter of an hour every week on the ABC. I would have thought that the amount of time devoted to rural programs could be increased at the expense of all the greenie programs and nature programs, as good as they are. The ABC should be looking at giving a bit more time to some of the more constructive things that we do in life rather than spending so much time in news programs on marches and so on. That is all I have to say. I support the amendment and I would like to think that the Government would do the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it fascinating to follow in the debate the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). Of course, the honourable member has claimed, I think in his own words, that there are too many ratbag groups on the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I would have thought that for the honourable member to be aggrieved with ratbag groups is really talking against his own constituency. I would have thought that self-interest would have made him want to see more ratbag groups because if that were the case he might have more chance of getting on the ABC.

SPEECH.PARA: I was sad to hear that the honourable member found something lacking with the Charleville radio service. I must say that a year or so ago when I was there I was allowed to broadcast an excellent program which, if the honourable member had listened to it, might have provided a model for him. It was sad to hear this poor National Party member, this fellow who purports to represent outback Queensland, pleading with the new Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) for an ABC radio station in Charleville. I wonder what has happened in the last 34 years. The party of which this man is a member was part of the Government of this country for 30 of those 34 years. The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) and all members of the National Party sitting on the other side of the House belong to a party which for 30 years of the last 34 years had the chance to do something but did absolutely nothing for outback Australia. The honourable member for Maranoa nods his head. For goodness sake, I do not know why he is not on this side of the House, because the only government that ever did anything to provide any assistance to allow the Australian Broadcasting Commission to expand its coverage was the Whitlam Australian Labor Party Government. The Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair ), as Minister for Communications, was the Minister in charge of closing the ABC down-nothing more, nothing less. We got no outback radio stations from him. We got no ABC television coverage in the bush. He was too busy trying to get some private firm to put up a satellite so that the then Government could sell the whole box and dice.

The honourable member for Maranoa suggests that we ought to make sure that we do not stop some private enterprise group from having television coverage out in Western Queensland. My point of view, and I know the point of view of my Party, is that all Australians, whether they are in the outback or in the cities, whether they are in Tasmania or in Queensland or whether they are anywhere else in Australia, ought to have some equitable spread of facilities. We will be doing that. Indeed, in this Bill for the first time in a long while the Minister clears up the problem of the ABC having access to satellite stations and to having ground stations. The previous Government was not too keen about that. It was too busy selling the damn thing to Kerry Packer.

Before the honourable member becomes too carried away on the subject of why his constituents have not received cricket telecasts in the country he ought to think about the reason. The Government of which he was a supporter prevented the ABC from having enough money to buy the cricket programs. The previous Liberal- National Country Party Government prevented the people in the outback from having cricket coverage. The honourable member for Maranoa realises that; he sits there nodding his head. After hearing his interesting speech his electors should either get rid of him so that they can have in office someone who can get television and radio for them or he should get off his backside and try to deliver for his constituents when his party is in office. Unfortunately for the people of Charleville, neither of those things has happened. The honourable member comes into the Parliament, makes speeches but does nothing more. In that regard he is very much in the mould of supporters of the previous Liberal- National Country Party Government.

It is interesting to see the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) stand up tonight as some sort of an apologist for the Bill that the Government of which he was a supporter brought down. The proposals of the Minister for Communications are most sensible. This new Bill will provide many of the things that the ABC needs. One of its important aspects is that it will provide genuine independence for the ABC. In the past we have heard a lot from members of the Opposition about that. They seem to be pretty keen on it at present because they believe that it harms the Government but in the past, when the ABC was critical of some of the things that their more notorious members were up to, they were very upset. They did their utmost to try to curb the ABC. They had Ministers interfere in what the ABC was doing. They employed the late night phone call to commissioners. They attempted to stand over the ABC in every way, shape and form . Only under a Labor government would the ABC have been allowed to do what it did this week. The ABC would not have had the independence to bring on such an inquiry such as it has had in recent weeks if the present Opposition had still been in government.

Labor believes that, regardless of whether it is harmed or helped as a result, the ABC should have the independence to do what the national broadcaster must do . Hand in hand with that is the requirement that the national broadcaster have the highest ethical standards of any broadcasting organisation in the country. There can be no doubt that, with the passage of this legislation and the granting of the power that goes with it to the board of directors of the proposed Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the ABC will begin undertaking the type of activity that the British Broadcasting Corporation has built up for itself in London. I have no doubt that if this legislation were not passed the ABC would continue to become the victim of political pushing and pulling. We oppose that concept and will do our utmost to ensure that the ABC enjoys the independence that it should have.

The Minister for Communications outlined in the second reading speech the proposed new structure of the ABC and I am very pleased to note that the concept of having advisory councils is to be implemented. If the honourable member for Maranoa has a problem understanding what these advisory councils do, he should read the Bill or the explanatory memorandum. If he has difficulty in reading the written word, as do many of his colleagues, he could have had a talk with the Minister, who would have explained the Bill. No one is suggesting, in any way, shape or form, that the local postmaster ought to be vetting anyone or doing anything so absurd. What is being suggested is that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Board should receive a genuine input from a wide range of Australians-people in the city, people in the country, people who work in industry, people who are employed as managing directors, people who have all sorts of points of views that they would like the ABC to think about. The present structure of the Commission is rather restricted. Essentially, it is a small Commission that is drawn from the elite and in some ways it is out of touch with the views of the great bulk of the people to whom the Commission should be broadcasting.

I take some small issue with my colleague who said earlier that he did not believe the ABC should involve itself in too much popular programming. The national broadcaster has an obligation to provide excellence for not only narrow interests but also for a wide range of other interests. For instance, we should be expanding the activities of stations such as station 2JJJ and should be getting young people more interested in the ABC so that they transfer their interest to the other programs that are run by the national broadcaster-

TALK.START.PARA: —We want televison before that happens. We do not get it.

—The honourable member wants television for his constituents before that happens. He is about 30 years too late. Why did he not get the previous Government to do that? Quite frankly, he has raised a very important point. The important thing to remember in regard to his complaints is that the National Party could not give a damn about outback Australia. It is sad to see that this particular member of that party must plead with the new Minister in order to obtain television for outback Australia. The people of those areas have a far better chance of getting a television network from the present Government and Minister for Communications than they had of getting it from any of the previous Liberal-National Country Party coalition governments.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important issue to which I wish to address myself in the next few minutes concerns the obsession of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) with no work as directed, no pay clauses. We all know that the honourable member for North Sydney has earned a considerable amount representing people in the courts and has taken a keen interest in industrial legislation. Unfortunately, as is the case with most conservative members of this Parliament, he is obsessed with the concept of legislating attitudes. If the honourable member, other members opposite and indeed the honourable member for Mallee, who has moved the amendment in regard to no work no pay, had a look at the history of industrial relations--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I have not moved the amendment and I am not the member for Mallee.
—I think that the honourable member should realise that what he raises is not a point of order.

—I apologise for maligning the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher ). Far be it from me to be so unkind to him. Probably I could be sued by the people of Mallee for trying to foist the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) upon them. On the question of no work as directed, no pay, the Government has adopted the philosophical approach that it will not implement this type of clause. I would have thought that the Opposition would have learnt from its failures of the past in attempting to put such clauses in Bills in dealing with industrial relations. They encountered some incredible failures with Telecom Australia. Incredible industrial disputes were caused by their bloody-minded attitudes in legislation on industrial relations. Under the present Bill no constraint is to be placed upon the Corporation, when involved in an industrial disputation, approaching the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and applying for stand-down orders. The trouble with honourable members opposite is that they want to put these things in legislation so that management will be put in the invidious position of adopting a confrontationist approach to their employees over industrial relations. One has only to speak to any manager of a public or private corporation to learn that none of them want these absurd clauses to operate. These absurd clauses are only brought about by people who want to have confrontation. The present Government has quite properly deleted that clause from the Bill that was introduced in 1982. It will go a long way towards ensuring that the ABC is not racked by industrial disputation.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I commend the Bills to the House. I think they will give the Australian Broadcasting Corporation the independence it deserves. They will provide for the first time in the charter of the Corporation a recognition of the multicultural aspect of Australian society. They will provide for a Board which will represent the broad views of the Australian community and for an advisory council which will ensure that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation stays in touch with the broader Australian community. I can see a great deal of good coming out of the legislation. I can see it providing the integrity that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation needs. I think that the Minister should be commended for the changes that he has made; the legislation is far better because of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time forces me to be brief, and I will be brief. Therefore, I will not repeat much that has been said in the debate welcoming many of the measures in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. I will not repeat the high opinion and respect that I have for Dame Leonie Kramer. I will not go over those matters. I will concentrate on the matter of complaints, because I think that in this amendment not enough attention has been given to the full significance of the changes made in the proposed investigations of complaints.

SPEECH.PARA: It is agreed on all sides, I think, that it is desirable for the citizen to have the right to have his complaints seriously investigated. I do not think that anyone really challenges the need to have that right established. Of course , everyone agrees that there should not be time wasted on the investigation of frivolous, vexatious or anonymous complaints. Nevertheless, the whole subject of complaint is something that has achieved a seriousness and a respectability. Something has to be done about it because of the wide-ranging nature of complaints and the deep feelings that they arouse.

The original Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill created an ombudsman to look into complaints, a complaints commissioner with powers no more and no less than those of an ombudsman. Whereas the ombudsman has generally been regarded by people who are concerned with the rights of the citizen as a great innovation- something to be defended and praised at least among citizens, if not always in government circles-this was not the case here. It was felt that the ombudsman was not a good thing; it was a good thing for everyone else, but not a good thing in relation to the ABC. The Government bowed to the outcry and agreed to dilute its original plan and adopt the British Broadcasting Corporation system which involved a system of investigative complaints that was independent of the ABC.

The new Government has gone further and, organisationally, has watered down that provision still further. We are now to have under the legislation community affairs officers. The principal community affairs officer is to be an officer of the Corporation. That in itself is a significant weakening of the earlier plans. But the reason that I am speaking at this late hour is to draw the House's attention to something else-the change in the definition of 'complaint'. In the original Bill a complaint meant a complaint that the program was inaccurate, unfair, biased, or involved an invasion of privacy. Under the new Bill a complaint is one about an error of fact or an invasion of privacy. The reference to bias and unfairness is deleted. Therefore, under this Bill, one cannot complain about unfairness or bias.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to define bias and unfairness?

—I certainly think that people want to be able to have complaints about bias or unfairness seriously investigated. I do not think that they would have too much trouble about defining the matter. There might be disagreement, but I do not think it would be an insoluble problem. Complaints about inaccuracy or invasion of privacy are important. If inaccuracy or error of fact meant, for example, that a date was wrong, I do not think that is a very serious step forward. Invasions of privacy is a more grave matter. I served on the New South Wales State Privacy Committee for a while and media invasions of privacy were within its jurisdiction. During the couple of years or so that I served on it, there were no complaints whatsoever. We all know of famous cases of invasion of privacy by the media, but they are not all that frequent. Nevertheless, it is important and to be welcomed that there is provision for it in this legislation, but I think that the omission of any grounds of complaint on the basis of unfairness or bias is a very serious omission. That is the area which rouses the most indignation among a wide range of people who night after night or day after day hear the predictable, almost mindless bias of many programs. This, of course , does not mean that I am advocating an empty neutrality or an indifference to facts on our system of government. A belief in the value of fairness is part of a belief in a free society and a parliamentary democracy. We cannot be indifferent to threats to a free society and parliamentary democracy. I wish that the charter in this legislation had included such a commitment. I wish to quote from a report that Stephen Hearst, the chairman of the BBC's future policy group, published in Encounter magazine in 1979. After stressing that programs should be as free from bias as is reasonably possible, he then said:

SPEECH.PARA: Such a service, however, does not stand apart from parliamentary democracy and does not offer aid and comfort to its enemies. It needs to expose totalitarian forces that would extinguish the freedoms we cherish were they to take over power, and it cannot be part of its business to be morally neutral in the exposition of ideologies that regard our system of government and our order with disdain.

As I said, I wish that sort of idea from the BBC was in the charter of this proposed Corporation. In any case, I think that the House should be aware that the citizen can have no possibility of complaint about programs that, to quote Mr Hearst, 'give comfort to our enemies' unless they are based on an invasion of privacy or on an inaccuracy of detail. The complaints arrangements have watered down the citizen's rights far too much. I hope that the House will seriously consider the amendment to the relevant clause.
Debate (on motion by Mr Duffy) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Tax Agents-Burdekin Dam-Controlled Harvesting of Australian Fauna-Death of Mr Adair Macalister Blain-Second Airport for Sydney-Sunrise Industries-Australian Sugar Industries

PROCTEXT.PARA: Tax Agents-Burdekin Dam-Controlled Harvesting of Australian Fauna-Death of Mr Adair Macalister Blain-Second Airport for Sydney-Sunrise Industries-Australian Sugar Industries
Motion (by Mr Duffy) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many other honourable members have possibly received complaints as I have about taxation matters involving, in some cases, summonses for non-lodgment and non-response to departmental requisitions and the like. Certainly, in some instances, such action is warranted and deserved. However, a number of instances have come to my notice in which taxpayers have been sadly and unfortunately disadvantaged through no fault or misdemeanour of their own. I do not criticise the Australian Taxation Office because, in this instance, that is not where culpability lies.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years there has sprung up a number of bodies posing as tax experts under trade names; they impressively advertise their services and process tax returns on a sausage machine principle. They are not qualified accountants or auditors governed by the constraints, ethics and responsibilities of that profession. They are registered tax agents who operate during the flush of the tax season for a few months and for the rest of the year they close their offices, operate on a skeleton staff or have an answering machine telephone. They prepare a return, or fail to do so, and collect their fee. When the taxpayer receives an inquiry or requisition from the Taxation Office, he finds that the person who interviewed him when he sought help with his return is no longer in the office. The taxpayer finds that his returns have not been lodged and is summonsed, as happened recently to some people who brought their complaint to me. Such people have a great deal of difficulty in even obtaining a copy of their own return. They get final notices and do not know what to do about them. They can find no help and nobody to tell them. The Taxation Office queries claims and the taxpayer cannot find the person who advised him to assist with the answers.

The accountancy profession, whose practitioners have to observe standard and ethics, is undeservedly brought into disrepute. Its clients are poached by these operators who operate under national names; their service is often dilatory, inadequate and leaves the unwitting client in a mess. They are not registered accountants so they cannot be dealt with by the professional accountancy bodies. They hire on a casual basis for short periods people with a agent's certificate, and often they have no other qualifications. A taxpayer cannot find any permanent adviser. When he returns for help he finds a different face, an office girl or the office closed until the next tax season.

Honourable members know the people to whom I refer. They advertise on television. Practising accountants, of course, cannot so advertise. These people advertise in the newspapers and have great signs over their shop fronts extolling their services and hawking their wares. But their casualties are numerous. They must surely be causing considerable concern to members of parliament who often have to sort out the mess, to registered public accountants whose clients they pinch and often let down and to the Taxation Office which has no option but to pursue the taxpayer knowing quite often that he has been the victim of such operators. My plea is that something ought to be done to require standards and disciplines of such operators. There should be some registration procedure, some proper code of ethics as happens to registered public accountants or at least a warning to unwitting persons that they could be at risk if they succumb to the advertisement and blandishments of such operators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A report in the Australian newspaper of 11 May 1983 highlights a widely held view that unless there is an urgent and major injection of government funds into capital works programs thousands of jobs will be lost. The report claims that 9,000 jobs in the engineering construction industry were lost in the past 12 months and that a further 17,000 jobs will be lost unless State and Federal governments review their economic policies. It predicts a major decline at all levels in the engineering construction industry which includes roads, railways, ports, bridges, water sewerage and drainage facilities , power stations and mines. The engineering contruction industry is now suffering grievously the results of the Fraser Government's program of economic disarmament.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need in Australia to bring about urgently the co-ordinated, integrated and long-range development of the resources of the nation. The decision by the Chifley Government to proceed with the Snowy Mountains Scheme was an historic recognition of the significance to Australia of major capital works, developmental works. Following a visit to the United States of America by Dr Evatt and as a result of his appreciation of the accomplishments of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Snowy Mountains scheme became a cornerstone in the Curtin Government's plan for post-war reconstruction. The development of irrigation projects and closer settlement was to the forefront of the Government 's plans. The great Labor Prime Minister, Mr Chifley, who set up the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority in 1949 stated;
Our national productive capacity can be positively built up by public investment in developmental works in hydro-electricity, afforestation, soil and water conservation and transport development.

The Snowy Mountains scheme was completed in 1973 by a Labor government. The Murrumbidgee Irrigation area, a beneficiary of the development of the Snowy Mountains scheme, has had a tremendous and beneficial impact on Australia's primary industries. The early completion of the Burdekin Dam will confirm, once again, the Hawke Government as a government fulfilling the historic needs of Australians, a government pursuing a robust, confident and organised policy of national development. This dam's completion will contribute substantially to the industrialisation and strengthening of the North Queensland economy. It will provide an assured water supply to more than 100,000 Australians who have been plagued by years of conservative government neglect in the development of water resources.

It is helpful to reflect on the history of the Tennessee Valley Authority compared to the Burdekin Scheme. The Tennessee Valley Authority was plagued by interference by various interests in the United States of America over a period of more than 20 years. It was abandoned by two American Presidents. It was vilified at Congress. It was castigated in the Press. It was hindered at every direction by various interests in the American community and saved by the historic intervention of people like Senator Norris of Nebraska and other leading American influential politicians, including President Roosevelt. The Tennessee Valley Authority was made a reality in 1933 and brought to that nation the benefits of a major historic water resource scheme.

The public management of our resources must be pursued by all governments. All governments must collaborate in the funding of public works programs and must develop and foster opportunities to increase jobs. The Burdekin Dam is such a scheme. The Burdekin Dam must be completed to realise-I repeat this-the historic aspirations of the people of North Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the past few years there has been an enormous increase in the population in western Victoria of long-billed corellas and sulphur crested cockatoos. The population of long-billed corellas, in particular , has reached plague proportions and is causing widespread damage to crops, pastures, parks, gardens and recreation areas. The litany of sins that these birds have committed includes the demolishing of the judge's box at the Murtoa racetrack, pulling nails out of the roof of the Horsham grandstand and removing mortar from the Wimmera Base Hospital chimney and the chimney at the Stawell brickworks to the extent that falling bricks are now a hazard. As well, they have dug up softball pitches and lawn tennis courts and ruined malthoid cricket pitches. There has also been a major fire litigation case in Hamilton concerning a fire started after cockatoos chewed through an electric wire which burnt 1,200 hectares of farmland. The fire also caused losses to 15 people, burnt 1,000 sheep and seven cattle and destroyed 65 kilometres of fence, a woolshed, haystack, cottage and other sheds.

SPEECH.PARA: This increase in pest species has occurred because of ideal breeding conditions in this region which contains areas of swamp and numerous river systems and also because of the protection they have enjoyed in Victoria for many years. Presently in Victoria the Wildlife Act of 1975 provides a maximum penalty of some $5,000 plus an additional penalty of up to $500 for every head of such wildlife taken or destroyed. All of us, particularly those in responsible positions, must ensure the conservation of any species threatened in any way and must seek ways to ensure that the effects of commercial exploitation are humane and controlled and that the illegal practice of interstate and international bird smuggling and trafficking stops.

However, no government, State or Federal, should allow a situation to develop as it has in Wimmera in Victoria. It is now spreading to other regions where the economic viability of individual farmers is threatened with serious effects on the national economy. Grain is being eaten immediately it is sown as is grain being fed as dry feed to stock. At harvest time ripening crops are decimated and yield is seriously reduced.

What can we do? My State colleague Bill McGrath and I have obtained permission for a professional bird trapper to work under the supervision of the Victorian Fisheries and Wildlife Division. His work is proving to be most useful in dispersing the flocks but his effectiveness is limited by a number of factors. His Victorian quota of 10,000 corellas will be harvested in a few weeks. He also has to pay the Victorian Government $1 a head which means he is paying up to $ 400 a day which is a very large burden for a bird trapper who also must meet the cost of licences, permits, fuel and grain. This operation will not be able to continue effectively or efficiently unless there is a change in the Federal Government's export control.

In 1976 the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation tabled a report on the trafficking in fauna in Australia. One of the recommendations of this Committee, of which I was a member, recommended that the export policy on Australian fauna be relaxed to allow government-controlled export to individuals and institutions of wild trapped common and pest species of birds provided that such birds are trapped under the control of a State fauna authority and harvesting is based on sound conservation principles. The former Government did relax our export policy to some degree by allowing the controlled export to approved overseas recipients, such as zoos, parks, et cetera, but this has not been adequate. I now ask the Minister to review this decision. The present policy does not discriminate between rare and endangered species and pest species. Pest species are given the same export protection as our rare ones and so have the absurd situation of smugglers earning large sums for illegally sending abroad fauna which is being destroyed daily in Australia because it is a pest. By allowing such controlled exports, we would stop or at least stem the danger to our rare and endangered species and, at the same time, create an additional outlet for those species causing untold damage and hardship. If a sensible solution is not found, I am concerned that methods will be used either legally or illegally to reduce this plague population to the detriment of our wildlife and the credibility of rural people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reeves Mr J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The funeral will occur tomorrow in Sydney of the late Adair Macalister Blain. He was the member for the Northern Territory for 15 years from 1934 until 1949. He was an Independent. He defeated the late Harold Nelson in 1934 to become a member of this House. The Nelson family got its own back in 1949 when Harold's son Jock defeated Mr Blain for the seat. In the 15 years that Mr Blain was a member of this House he spoke out strongly for the Northern Territory. He spoke about the constitutional development of the north and also about the need for defence and security in the north. I use the word 'spoke' advisedly because at that time the member for the Northern Territory had no voting rights in this House. In fact he was not even counted when it came to counting quorums or majorities in this House. That situation applied until 1958 when the member was finally given a vote on matters affecting the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Blain served in the First World War in the 32nd Battalion of the Australian Infantry Force and he was twice wounded in 1918. He served again in the Second World War and, while still a member of this House, in 1942 he became a prisoner of war in Malaya. He was a surveyor by occupation. He worked at Cloncurry and Burketown in Queensland and he also did official survey work in the Northern Territory and in northern and central Australia. He was a true pioneer in the north and part of the territory's history. I offer my condolence to his wife and family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pay a compliment to the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) for his remarks regarding Mr Chilla Blain.
—Hear, hear!
—My colleague, the honourable member for Moreton (Sir James Killen), endorses his remarks and joins me in our expression of appreciation to the honourable member for the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening, I wish to set some facts straight regarding comments of the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) concerning Sydney's second airport. The Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee-the MANS Committee-that was established by the previous Government considered factors that it used to evaluate a decision on a prospective second airport for Sydney or the development of the Sydney ( Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The evaluation factors used by the MANS Committee were , in the environmental area, social and cultural factors, land use and development, geology and soils, air quality, water, flora and fauna and the noise factors. On technical areas it considered the number of new runways, the distance from the central business district by rail or road, bus travel times and rail travel times, conflict with defence facilities, conflict with other ground facilities, the effects on general aviation, safety factors and incidence of fog. Economic factors were also considered in the evaluation and they included the net present value, the net cost, economic timing of development and , in the financial area, the capital cost. All of those factors used by the MANS Committee led it to a conclusion which it set out in an abstract as a series of recommendations.
The recommendations of the Committee were these:

1. Action should be continued and extended to protect and facilitate the maintenance of scheduled air services at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport . . . and generally to ensure that usage of available facilities accords with the Government's economic and social priorities.
2. A decision in principle should be taken to develop KSA by construction of a close spaced parallel runway and associated facilities east of the existing north-south runway.

3. An airport master plan, detailed designs and an environmental impact statement should be prepared with respect to such development so that technical solutions and their environmental and social acceptability can be finally determined.
In regard to a second airport, the MANS Committee said this:

As part of the current review of the Sydney region outline plan a contingent site for a curfew-free second major airport, together with potential noise affected areas, should be protected through at least retention of existing land use planning controls and with consideration of acquisition in cases of hardship .
The sub-section of that recommendation was that Badgery's Creek-known as SW4-be the preferred site.

The Minister has been consistently saying in the House that both the previous Minister for Aviation and the MANS Committee recommended that a second airport be developed for Sydney. That is not true. The MANS Committee certainly does not express that view and its recommendations clearly show that the first consideration it thought was responsible, given all the factors for evaluation, was that there be a close spaced parallel runway and that secondly-I quote the words again-
. . . a contingent site . . . should be protected through at least retention of existing land use planning controls and with consideration of acquisition in cases of hardship.

That is very clear. I believe the Minister has not given the House the full story. The matter of concern to residents of western Sydney is that all the factors used to evaluate the decision by the previous Government have been set aside. A political decision has been made and none of the evaluation factors concerning the environment, technology, economy or finance has been considered. The bases for the forthcoming decision by the Government on a second airport for Sydney are not known. The concern of the residents of western Sydney-I know that the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Gorman) shares my view--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight, I address a few remarks to the House concerning the sunrise industries that today are very much a motherhood subject. I think everyone in the community applauds the growth of sunrise industries. We have a lot of nice words said in encouragement for them. They are to be encouraged because by and large they are industries that will not need any protection. They rely very much on the initiatives, the flair and the inventiveness of the people in our community. But it is wrong to think that all sunrise industries are necessarily high technology industries; they are in fact ones in which we have a natural advantage. Many of these could be developed in Australia today which would provide enormous employment prospects for people in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, I did an exercise some years ago in my home town of Kalgoorlie when we were faced with large and rapidly mounting electricity bills because we have a diesel powered power station. Our investigation showed that we could generate the required 15 megawatts of power on one million acres of timber, mainly from eucalypts of the salmon gum variety.
