One million acres of salmon gum would have replaced the deisel bill which was $1.5m annually-today that bill is about $3m-and would have provided an enormous amount of employment for particularly the itinerant and the young who otherwise would be unemployed.

Similarly, we could look at the future for eucalyptus oil. I believe that there will be a big market for that in the future. This is an area in which Australia has a natural advantage, and we could look at harvesting it much more efficiently than is done now. Other areas spring to mind, too. One was mentioned by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) tonight-the controlled harvesting of Australian fauna. This is an industry about which I know something . I was involved in it for many years. The honourable member omitted to say that it was a Liberal-National Party government which introduced the legislation from which we now suffer. My estimation is that an industry of this nature would produce, conservatively, $30m per year for Australian export earnings, which the Government could tax at the rate of 100 per cent, so the Government could get at least $15m in tax out of it.

Another area that should be looked at is the export of leather and the development of the leather market. There is a world demand for leather. It is a growing market. In Australia we have a leather, the kangaroo skin, which is the strongest and must durable leather for its weight in the world. It is a superb leather. It is very foolish that Australia is not looking at developing expertise in the manufacture and processing of kangaroo skins. It is simply not good enought to export them. Whilst there is certainly a market for their export as raw skins, this is an area in which Australia should be developing expertise so that we can sell to the world a finished product and get some of the labour and employment that is generated in countries such as Italy, France, India, and so on, which have the expertise.

I am alarmed at the emotion that this subject generates. I find the behaviour of the sundry 'Save the Kangaroo' lobbies quite appalling. I think that the people concerned are emotional, misinformed and knowingly misleading in much of their material and propaganda. I have shot kangaroos. I know that, as a kangaroo shooter, I shot kangaroos to kill them as quickly as possible. It is not a job that I enjoyed, but I made very sure that the kangaroos did not suffer, and I can say with authority that there is simply no value in any commercial shooter of kangaroos wishing to inflict any unnecessary pain on the animal. For that reason, I deplore very much the showing of the film Goodbye Joey in the United States. It does immense damage to Australia as a nation. It shows the citizens of this country in a very bad and incorrect light and does enormous damage to our trade potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the time of the House tonight to bring to the attention of this House, this Parliament and the Government the plight of the sugar industry in Australia at the moment. Some people feel that the recent rains in eastern Australia, while breaking the drought, have redressed the damage that has been done to the sugar industry over the last 12 months and have improved its prospects over the next 12 months. At present the sugar industry in Queensland and northern New South Wales directly supports 7, 000 suppliers or more, and the flow-on effects of this to the service industries and the people who populate the towns and cities along the Queensland and northern New South Wales coast means that it is the major contributor to population growth in that area. Anything that affects the sugar industry detrimentally will certainly affect the future of those people in the decentralised areas of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, because of the drought that persisted last year, while a full crop was taken off, the prospects for the coming season would indicate that only about 80 per cent of the peak crop would be available to Australian producers. The prospects for the coming 12 months, as far as the planter is concerned, have been improved because of the rain. However, I want to deal with the aspect of the present world stock situation. World stocks are at record levels. The percentage of stocks held in relation to world consumption is also at a record level, of about 35 per cent or 36 per cent of annual consumption. I am very happy to know that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), and a whole team of sugar industry people from right throughout New South Wales and Queensland, are at the European Economic Community talks trying to establish a new International Sugar Agreement. I certainly hope that they have success, because that is the most vital factor that is available to the sugar industry to push prices back to a reasonable and economic level. The fact is that the EEC, particularly France and Germany, is undermining the sugar industry's situation throughout the world because of its regard to the subsidies that are paid, and the consequent dumping of the product on the world market is undermining the whole industry. When the Minister returns, I hope that he will inform the House that the propects of an ISA are valid, with the EEC as a member on Australia's terms and not on the terms of the EEC.

There are other matters at which I believe the Government should be looking. A form commitment was given by the previous Government that an underwriting scheme would be entered into to assist farmers to get through the effects of the drought of the last season so that they can face up to the new season. Also, a pledge was given to increase rural adjustment funds so that more follow-on or follow-through funds would be available in the coming season for those farmers that were viable. I ask that the Minister, on his return to Australia, examine that commitment and look at what I feel was a tacit approval of his own to support the sugar industry in this way, remembering that any injection of funds into the pockets of the producer will have that follow-through effect on the cities and towns which are supported by the sugar industry.

I was rather amazed earlier in the debate to hear the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) indicate that the Burdekin Dam project was, perhaps, under question. It was never under question under the previous Government. The agreement entered into in 1980 was a valid one. It committed funds of $6.1m for the coming year. The honourable member's suggestion that it is under threat is news to me. I certainly hope that he is not suggesting that this might be another victim of the razor gang approach to government. I hope that that is not the case. The previous member for Herbert was the man who was mainly instrumental in getting this project up. If honourable members want to be committed to water programs, why not look at the bicentennial water program? That was one of the things which could have been of great assistance to the sugar industry, not only concerning the commitment to the Burdekin Dam but also to other areas, such as Bundaberg, Kincham Dam, Proserpine and all along the coast where we are looking at the total situation of the sugar industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
